urn:contentItem:5H7P-05N1-F0HW-50R8-00000-00Risk & Reward for October 23, 20152015-10-23T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:22:12ZLexisNexisRisk & Reward for October 23, 2015

DEIRDRE BOLTON, RISK & REWARD SHOW HOST: It is a rally three main indices closing higher up 1.5 percent, Facebook, Google, Amazon hitting record highs.

Welcome to Risk & Reward. I'm Deirdre Bolton.

Strong earnings results pushing tech stocks to new levels. Our market bull, our market bear with me now with their next moves. Market bull, Michael Lee, market bear Michael Chadwick.

Michael Lee on the bullish side. Alphabet, formerly known as Google. Amazon, Microsoft all exceeding expectations, is there a worry to you, even as a bull that only three to four stocks are really pushing this rally and everyone else is just jumping on a few winners?

MICHAEL LEE, TIGER WEALTH MANAGEMENT FOUNDER & MANAGING PARTNER: Well, what I would say here is these stocks are going push it higher because they're exceptional, and that's why they're going higher.

Google, if you look at them, they have over a billion users on six different platforms, and they're really just -- they're executing on a really high level now. Valuation with Google as with Microsoft one of the other big tech stocks that traded well today, you can look a little closer at, but Amazon and Facebook are almost impossible to value

And what I mean by that is Amazon is doing $100 billion a year in revenue, and growing at 20 to 25 percent, I mean, how do you put a number on that? And their goal is really not to make money. They're investing in all through it new technology.

And then Facebook, you know, not quickly the same top line of revenue, 15, around 15 to 16 billion, but they're growing the revenue at 35 to 40 percent. So, it's really difficult to value those stocks, but I would say that when you have an exceptional business model and you're best in class that you're going to deserve a premium.

And, you know, they say tech leads the market, I'm very bullish on the U.S. economy. And so, I think this is a good sign for things to come.

BOLTON: OK. Michael Chadwick, what the chances this is a bear market trap?

MICHAEL CHADWICK, CHADWICK FINANCIAL ADVISORS CEO: I think the chances are at a very, very high. In fact, as you said earlier, you've got four or five big names leading the market. Where is the overall participation? And in fact, yesterday, there was 1.7 stocks up for every stock down.

Now, on a big day, where the market is up 2, 3 percent, that's horrible participation. The reality is, those are great businesses. Valuations are out of hand on some of them, others are reasonable. But the reality is the economy runs on more than four businesses, and if we don't get the broad base and start catching up to these hot, hot names, then we're going to have a big bear trap.

And I think people need to be cautious, as Mike said, about valuations. People aren't thinking about valuations. And let's step back two days, what drove this rally? Draghi yesterday, and then China overnight.

So, once again, we're back to people acting like Pavlov's dogs and running on stimulus hopes. We're not running on fundamentals here. We're running on pipe dreams on accomplishing value.

(CROSSTALK)

BOLTON: All right. Well, I agree that obviously there are some macro moves and central banks are being supportive. But that said, at least for the three stocks we're talking about, they did actually exceed earnings expectation.

But I want to stay on the tech stock theme, because it's allowing one founder to give back to his employees. Twitter co-founder CEO, Jack Dorsey giving a third of his company stock to an employee equity pool. That by the way, is worth around $200 million, fittingly he announced it on Twitter.

He wrote, "I'm giving one-third of my Twitter stock, exactly 1 percent of the company to our employee equity pool to reinvest directly in our people. As for me, I would rather have a smaller part of something big than a bigger part of something small. I am confident we will make Twitter big."

So, Michael Lee, do you see this as incentive? I mean, this follows decision to cut jobs at Twitter following Dorsey retaking the CEO position, is this his insurance against other people leaving?

LEE: Well, what I would say is this is a nice sentiment by a very famous CEO, a tech all-star. But let's face it, if it was worth two or three times as much as it is now, why would he be giving it away.

And now I would love to get more stock. But Twitter is a portfolio company, it's going to have to be bought by someone for them to stay in business and I just don't know what that price is.

So, I can't imagine, you know, look, it's a good sentiment but I don't think it's a bullish sign for the stock or whatsoever.

BOLTON: Michael Chadwick does it change your view in any way about the future of Twitter?

CHADWICK: No, I don't think it changes my view of the company but I do love the move by the CEO, and I think more CEO's should be doing that. Because the reality is the CEO's are making so much and their average guy is really having a hard time.

Now, whether the CEO, whether this particular company's stock is worth all that more down the line or its toilet paper is anybody's guess, but I love the concept in the upper echelon of corporate America sharing the wealth with the average employee.

It's wonderful incentive. It lines up everybody's interests and people working a whole lot harder for you when you have that kind of behavior.

BOLTON: Market bull, Michael Lee. Market bear, Michael Chadwick, thank you for joining me.

LEE: Thank you.

BOLTON: We want to bring you now to world and national news, Secretary of State John Kerry meeting with the Russian Foreign Minister in Vienna, Austria. Topic number one, the four-year Civil War raging in Syria.

Russia, by the way, launching airstrikes that are hitting U.S. backed Syrian rebels.

With me now retired General Jack Keane. General, so glad to see you here in person. You told me that the White House National Security team is talking about safe zones and no-fly zones over Syria's airspace. This is a big move and if this is put in place, it's a huge shift in policy, right?

JACK KEANE, FOX NEWS MILITARY ANALYST: Yes, absolutely. A number of us to include Secretary Gates, Secretary Condi Rice, Secretary Clinton have all made these recommendations over the last year or two, Senator McCain goes back about three years.

And what this is as I already understand is a safe zone, we would put largely refugees in there. But once you put them in there, and you have to protect them with some kind of ground force, that would be a moderate opposition ground force that we have been backing, and then you have to protect them with air power because somebody could bomb that.

So, it gets more complicated to put it together and make sure it truly is, quote, "a safe zone."

BOLTON: But it would also, at least avoid what could be called a mistake. I mean, you remember when Russia, by mistake, hit a few targets that it said it was not intending to hit and what if Russian planes and U.S. planes collided, that could start an incident.

KEANE: Well, the good news is that the United states and Russia have had a meeting, a series of meetings actually where out of that came air procedures. So, we de-conflict our operations. So, I'm not too concerned about that.

The Russians will have to make up their mind if they are going to continue to bomb our moderate rebels that the CIA has trained and armed which they have been doing since they've been in there.

BOLTON: So, General, we just saw a picture of the Russian President Vladimir Putin shaking hands with Syrian President Assad. That meeting, a surprise meeting, Assad flew to Moscow and the world is very divided.

Russia and Iran think Assad belongs in power in Syria. Everyone else, Europe and the U.S., said no way. For there to be a peaceful situation in Syria, that guy has to go. What is your stance from a military point of view on how likely it is to remove him and then have peace.

KEANE: well, from a policy perspective, Deirdre, I mean, the reason why Russia is there and the Iranians are there so strongly is because actually Assad, this last year the rebels made a lot of gains and he was in a precarious position, that is over.

They're going to create a buffer zone there, that's why they're pushing back to rebels, they'll create an enclave. Syria only owns 20 percent of the country but they'll make certain that that's a solid 20 percent, and Assad is going to stay in power until such time as the Iranians and the Russians no longer want him in power. We are no longer influenced in that decision.

BOLTON: All right. Well, that is a sober comment, we will hear it, we'll digest it. Retired General, Jack Keane joining me. Thank you, sir, as always. We appreciate your perspective.

To domestic matters, Department of Justice announcing that former IRS official, Lois Lerner will not face charges for targeting political groups. "The probe found substantial evidence of mismanagement, but poor management. But poor management is not a crime."

That is actually a quote, that was the assistant attorney general, Peter Kadzik, who's making that statement. So, this closes a two-year investigation into whether or not the IRS improperly targeted the Tea Party and other conservative groups.

Columnist, Deneen Borreli with me now, democratic strategic Chuck Rocha. Deneen, what does this message send to any party, Tea Party included?

DENEEN BORELLI, CONSERVATIVE COLUMIST: Well, listen, this is the Friday afternoon dump on Americans, Deirdre. And basically, the Department of Justice has essentially said that the IRS can do and say whatever they want to intimidate Americans who want to use their political standards and statures across the country.

They can do and say whatever, and we can't challenge them or we can't hold them accountable. And I think this is really horrible that Lois Lerner was able to use her power in this position to make this happen.

BOLTON: Chuck, for your view, when the Department of Justice says that it found substantial mismanagement, does that require consequences? Is that a slap on the wrist? How do you see this?

CHUCK ROCHA, DEMOCRATIC STRATEGIST: I mean, I think it's what it states that it is. I mean, there's consequences in that she's no longer there. I think that there will probably be reviews, but I think if they use their own words if that you're a pretty bad manager, that will mean you got to go to jail.

I think that there's things that need to be accountable, I think that there's to be accountable to the American people. I think those are our tax dollars. But just because somebody is not good at running their department don't mean that they're a criminal.

BOLTON: All right. Deneen, what -- I know you want to say something, what is your follow-up to this idea of no consequences?

BORELLI: I've met the hundreds of patriots across the country, who are waiting for months, for years to file their paperwork in the proper manner and Lois Lerner used her power to intimidate these individuals, and I find it outrageous.

And that's why we have the wave of Americans tired of the politicians and individuals in government who are not being held accountable.

BOLTON: Well, Deneen, that is why we are seeing an outliers race as far as the presidential race goes. Deneen Borelli, thank you. Chuck Rocha, I know both of you will be joining me in a bit.

But in the meantime, we want to give you this update about this monster category 5 hurricane Patricia, barreling towards Southwest Mexico. The country on track to get hit with the strongest hurricane ever recorded in the Western hemisphere.

In fact, if you look at the winds right now, 160 miles per hour. Fox News meteorologist Rick Reichmuth is with me. Rick, when is this expected to hit?

RICK REICHMUTH, FOX NEWS METEOROLOGIST: Yes, it's getting very close. The winds are actually now at 190 miles an hour. And as far as records go across the globe, it looks like it's difficult to go through al of the records everywhere, but I think we're probably at about the fifth strongest storm we've ever seen anywhere, and the strongest anywhere in around the Americas in the Western hemisphere, and making landfall at a category 5.

Here's the center of the storm there just off the coast of Puerto Vallarta and Manzanillo, Mexico. And when you look at this one here, you can see it's been wobbling just as like if you had a top that you spun, the way it will wobble, and that's what normal.

But, likely making landfall somewhere here between Puerto Vallarta and Manzanillo within the next couple of hours. Very mountainous terrain, not a huge population right here, about 110 miles between these two cities and we might just thread the needle right between them, and that's important because hurricane-force winds only extend up 35 miles from the center.

So, if you get this in between, we could be looking at just tropical storm conditions in Puerto Vallarta and maybe Manzanillo as well. But any spots here right along the coast certainly we're going to be seeing storage surge and if you're right where this makes landfall, it's going to be one of the most extreme experiences that we've seen anywhere and landfall from any kind of a tropical storm.

Very incredible, it's also a quick mover, and that's good because it won't drop rainfall totals maybe in the widespread 20 inches. But we'll likely see a few spots in that range. And it's such a quick mover. Take a look at this, Texas still potentially looking at the remnants of that.

And I'll show you how that plays out. This is a future radar. So, that's what we think the radar is going to look like. Guadalajara getting a lot of rain, and by tomorrow from Monterrey, Mexico.

But you'll notice that moisture moving in here across parts of Texas, a different system that's been plaguing Texas since last week is going to pull that moisture in there, and we might be seeing some spots maybe up to a foot of rain, and this Texas' that will cause some flooding here.

So, even in the U.S., Deirdre, we're going to have some impacts from the storm.

BOLTON: OK. Rick, we will depend on you for updates. Rick Reichmuth, thank you so much, our meteorologist.

Well, when we come back, this video is going viral. A woman in China is destroying her husband's luxury BMW. There is more to the story and her motive.

We'll also talk about legal charges, would she face them if she did this in the U.S.? The answer might surprise you.

Aaron Sorkin's "Steve Jobs," movie enters wide release today. The actor who played Apple co-founder, Steve Wozniak, Seth Rogen is my guest.

Khloe Kardashian may have to pay up to $79,000 for Lamar Odom's brothel bill. We'll tell you why.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Blood is coming out of his nose, white stuff coming out of his mouth and can't get him to wake up. He's like, almost not breathing.

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Is he conscious?

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Excuse me?

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: Is he conscious?

UNIDENTIFIED FEMALE: No.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BOLTON: Jeb Bush is apparently struggling to galvanize his family's donor base, as a result, he is ordering across the board pay cuts and slashing positions at campaign headquarters.

Conservative columnist, Deneen Borelli, democratic strategist, Chuck Rocha back with me. Deneen, he has been trailing, Jeb Bush is been trailing in the national polls at fourth or fifth place, it almost seems like he just settled into that second tier of candidates.

So, is this just a consequence of failing to inspire, the idea of a successful run?

BORELLI: Well, listen, as they say in the business world, Deirdre, the trend is your friend. And Jeb Bush is not trending on the right side of the voters, especially grassroots voters. He is an establishment candidate, he's got the establishment name, political name, Bush. And this is the anti-establishment movement that is sweeping the country.

People are tired of what they're seeing represented in Washington today. And so, he's on the wrong side of the trend.

BOLTON: So, in this case, the last name and the connection to the family dynasty may be hurting him. But, Chuck, I mean, it seems as if he would have already spent something like more than $130 million to have to make these moves, right?

ROCHA: Right, and what he's doing is he's being accountable to his donors. So, he wants the donors to keep giving and he wants others to give because money is more than just the mother's milk in politics.

It's everything in a presidential race because you have to have the money to get up there to spread your message. So, he's trying to show his donors that, hey, I'm cutting back, I'm being more responsible, I'm going to wait this out, it's going to go up, it's going to go down.

So, he's trying to resurrect and show a change of all-around strategies doing his campaign.

BOLTON: But, Deneen, is this the beginning of the end?

BORELLI: Well, listen, anything is possible with politics, but the other thing with Bush is that he's on the wrong side of two issues that are really important to grassroots. And that's common core and immigration.

So, again, he's on the wrong side of the trend, wrong side on several issues as well, and it's hurting him.

BOLTON: All right. But yet, there are other candidates who say all kinds of outlandish things on those two topics and more and it only helps them.

In a new Des Moines Register poll, candidate Dr. Ben Carson actually surging past Donald Trump who is obviously been the most outspoken on numerous issues but it's worth noting has been in the lead for 100 days.

So, Carson now has 28 percent. Donald Trump coming in at 19 percent and Ted Cruz in third place with 10 percent.

Deneen, does this make sense to you, I know you say anything can happen, we're more than a year away. Does that photo, that image of who is where make sense to you?

BORELLI: Well, I don't think Trump is out at all, and you look at Carson trending in Iowa, for example, he's really tapping into the Evangelicals in that state. And so, he's a very religious gentleman. Individuals are really relating to him, and he's the anti-establishment individual.

He's not a career politician, so he's getting a lot of momentum, a lot of attention and a lot of money.

BOLTON: Chuck, what do you think about the republican field and what it means for the democratic competition, if you like?

ROCHA: Well, you know what, Pat Roberts and Huckabee and Santorum all have in common? And everyone like to be president but they all want Iowa. And there so much stuff going on in Iowa. And on the democratic side, you've got people dropping out left and right and pretty much left with Bernie Sanders and Hillary, so it will be interesting on seeing who's doing the better job in marketing.

But the key point here is it is an outsider's game right now, that's why you see that Donald Trump and Carson and even Bernie Sanders has touched a cord in trying to say we want something different.

BOLTON: All right. I thank you, both. Deneen Borelli, Chuck Rocha, great to have you both here.

BORELLI: Thank you.

BOLTON: And remember to tune into Fox Business republican debate, Tuesday November 10th.

Too close for comfort. Look at this midair close call. The story coming up.

Also, the Steve Jobs biopic out today, the actor who played the Apple co- founder, Steve Wozniak is my guest.

Seth Rogen is here to talk about everything from the movie to Sony's hack settlement. You don't want to miss that conversation.

First though, the Fox Business interview that is making headlines, Maria Bartiromo sat down with the infamous drug CEO, Martin Shkreli, he hired or rather, hiked his aids drug price by 5,000 percent.

We have a CEO who says if Martin won't lower the price on the treatment, he will. He is now selling his own version of the drug for just $1. He's my guest next.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

MARTIN SHKRELI, TURING PHARMACEUTICALS CEO: When people say 750, that sounds like a lot of money. But the reality is, 60 percent of our patients get it for it $1, one penny a pill.

MARIA BARTIROMO, MORNINGS WITH MARIA SHOW HOST: Listen, $750 doesn't sound like a lot of money, $750 is a lot of money. And when you're talking about a drug that people in this nobody else having the drug on the market, that's where the outrage came from.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BOLTON: There he is. But I know you need some money.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

SHKRELI: Put yourself in the shoes of someone who has this illness, this drug is 70 years old and it has terrible side effects and it's not that effective.

By taking the price up, we can actually afford to do real research to make a better drug. If you were a patient that have this illness, you wouldn't want a 70-year-old drug, most people don't want a 6-month-old cell phone.

So, for me, I think it's imperative for us to actually make the drug that a price that makes sense for us and is affordable to patients.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BOLTON: That is the CEO of Turing Pharmaceuticals defending his company's controversial decision to raise the price of aids drug, Daraprim, by 5,000 percent. He said once that he sold the drug for $13.50, then drastically increased it to $750 per tablet.

There is now a company that is offering a cheaper alternative $1 per pill. He is with me now, the CEO of the company that is doing that, Mark Baum, he is the CEO of Imprimis.

Mark, so glad you are joining us. Did you hear the CEO of Turing basically saying he is trying to raise the price on purpose to wash out a bad drug, it seems like faulty logic, and then increase R&D in a better one. Does that make sense to you?

MARK BAUM, IMPRIMIS PHARMACEUTICALS CEO: Well, you know, what is really interesting is, you know, in his press release when they acquired the drug, what was fascinating is he actually included information about additional drugs that should be taken or that could be prescribed and taken by patients in concert with his drug.

And one of them is the additional component of our compounded formulation. So, you know, it's interesting. Maybe when he's talking about, you know, new and better drugs, he might be talking about our compounded formulation, which includes this additional ingredient.

BOLTON: But would you ever charge more for a drug that you think is outdated anyway, and then after the fact say, well, the higher prices for the people who are almost kind of implied too stupid to keep paying it, that's going to help us with R&D?

BAUM: His logic, you know, listen, I'm no logician but it really doesn't make a lot of sense. I mean, what makes, and by the way, he's free to charge whatever he wants, God bless him. But, you know, we can act as an amazing counterbalance to what he's doing and what others are frankly doing beyond him. I mean, this is a much bigger issue from our perspective.

BOLTON: OK. So, you are offering, essentially, the same treatment for a dollar. Have people said to you is this really the same quality? Do people have that concern?

BAUM: Well, let me be clear. We cannot legally make this exact copy of his drug. That is illegal, federal law prevents us from doing that. So, we will absolutely not do that at all.

You know, and what we're committed to doing obviously is just is getting this drug out to patients at an affordable price. You won't see us raise the price up. I mean, frankly, we make a tremendous profit when we sell it at even 99 cents a pill.

So, we're quite happy to do that. But as I said, the bigger picture is this is happening across the board with a lot of these types of drugs and, you know, we're going to be there hopefully, to act as a counterbalance with the help, hopefully, of policymakers because we're not going to succeed unless we work with the FDA and others that regulate what we do.

BOLTON: So you think that the FDA and others are on your side or are they more going even though they may hate the CEO of Turing that they're saying, OK, what he's doing is not illegal, so we can't do anything about it?

BAUM: I think what's important is that we put, you know, FDA, and I know that's the FDA's mission and it's our mission as well. We have to put patients first. Our philosophy is when we put patients first, we're going to win as a company, and we're a public company. We have shareholders to account to.

So, we're committed to putting patients first. And if that's what the FDA wants to do, so we're aligned in that regard. We do need to work cooperatively with them though, to make sure that we can act as a counterbalance, you know, to this situation as well, as many others that we're going soon talk about.

BOLTON: Mark Baum, so grateful for you time. Thank you so much. We wish you all the luck. It seems like to root for people taking the high road. Thank you.

BAUM: Thank you, Deirdre.

BOLTON: Too close for comfort, an amazing midair close call. We're going to bring you more details. What is behind this brush with a huge jetliner?

Then, actor Seth Rogen joining me to talk about his new movie, it is called Steve Jobs, of course he plays the role of Steve Wozniak, the co-founder of Apple. We also talk about Sony's hack attack and Hollywood's challenge with equal pay.

Then a jilted lover smashing her husband's BMW, that is the video that is going viral, our attorneys have something to say, though, about property damage.

Khloe Kardashian may have to pick up the bill for her pro basketball husband, albeit estranged until now. Lamar Odom's $80,000 brothel bill, our legal guest says she might be on the hook for that. We'll bring you more details.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BOLTON: This video is going viral. The woman pictured with the hammer spent about 20 minutes trying to destroy the $150,000 BMW that belongs to her husband. So she was not arrested. Local security did not try to slow her down. Our legal panel is here, Deb Blum, also Evangeline Gomez, Evangeline, before we talk about liability damages there seems to be more to the story, apparently her husband was cheating on her that was a big part of her motivation. But does that change from a legal standpoint, charges -- potential charges for property damage?

EVANGELINE GOMEZ, ATTORNEY: No. And if there is going to be any charge, guess what? The money's going to come out of the same pot. They're not divorced that we know of, so they -- he and she are both going to pay for the damage.

BOLTON: And apparently, he said let her just smash it, I can get it repaired. So Deb, as far as legal -- there are no legal issues, right?

DEB BLUM, ATTORNEY: Well, I think if this happened here, she would absolutely be arrested. It's technically his property. He probably has title. She bashed his car with a hammer. There were children in the video, so you could say she's endangering their welfare because there are children nearby and there is glass flying everywhere. So I do think if this happened here, she would end up with a criminal case.

BOLTON: Ok, well, although her motivation probably -- I'm assuming somebody would take into consideration on. But on another topic that seems to be proving legally tricky, Khloe Kardashian may actually have to pay for her estranged husband's brothel bill which is about $80,000. The owner of the brothel says that is what he is owed and if Lamar Odom doesn't pay, he's going after Khloe Kardashian because she has the money. If they are not legally divorced, Deb, is that possible?

BLUM: Well, we don't know if they had a prenuptial agreement or what the settlement agreement said in their divorce. Although, it's now rumored that Khloe is not seeking the divorce.

BOLTON: I think that's off.

BLUM: That would probably invalidate their settlement agreement, although it would not invalidate a prenuptial agreement. So I'm not sure if she will be responsible for his brothel bill.

BOLTON: Evangeline, if they're not divorced, does she have to pay?

GOMEZ: This is the situation in California. When you get a legal separation, any debts or any property that you should amass after that date, it basically goes each person individually. So at this point, they were legally separated, they were not yet divorced because the judge had not signed off on it, based on reports, and he accrued this debt when they were legally separated, so he should be held responsible for this, not Khloe. And there seems to be this back between a brothel owner and between the Kardashians, and I think there's more here. Obviously, the brothel owner can sue her, but that doesn't mean he's going to get a recovery.

BOLTON: Yeah, I think he's just trying to get paid, I guess.

BLUM: He's definitely getting a lot of publicity from this.

BOLTON: Indeed. All right, well, we thank you both, Deb and Evangeline for your legal skills. Thank you.

GOMEZ: Thank you, Deirdre.

BOLTON: Another video that is trending on social media, a midair close call. We're going to give you more details on this story behind a brush with a jetliner.

Then forget student debt, apprenticeships are gaining popularity, in fact, some even lead to six figure salaries, one person who is capitalizing on that joining me.

But first, the actor who plays Steve Wozniak in the new Steve Jobs film is joining me. Seth Rogen weighing in on everything from North Korea to his bashing of Ben Carson and Hollywood pay inequality. He's my guest next.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: What do you do?

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I play the orchestra. And you're a good musician, you sit right there. You're the best in your role.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I got to get back on stage. You got two minutes of rehearsal time left. I don't want to see you get dragged off.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: I get free from you. You give them to me.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: You're going to have a stroke.

UNIDENTIFIED MALE: What did you do? What did you do?

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BOLTON: We are here now with one of the stars of the Steve Jobs movie released today, Seth Rogen plays Steve Jobs' longtime friend and Apple co- founder Steve Wozniak, Seth, so glad you could join us. .

SETH ROGEN, STEVE JOBS: Thank you for having me.

BOLTON: So Steve Wozniak, playing that role that's a bit of a departure from some of your previous roles, what made you want to do this project?

ROGEN: Honestly, I was skeptical that I would want to do it when I first heard about it, and then I read the script, and it really blew my mind, it's one of the best scripts if not the best written script I've read in my entire life. And as a writer, it pains me greatly to say that and fills me with both rage and jealousy.

BOLTON: Rage and jealousy, it's a good combo.

ROGEN: Yes, it really just blew my mind, and Danny Boyle is someone I'm a huge fan of. I really wasn't interested in Steve Jobs at all going into the movie, it was just the work itself was incredible to me, and so I wanted to try to be a part of it.

BOLTON: So let me pick up on something that you said, because some of the critics of the movie have said that it actually is too geek-focused, in a way that, for example, the Social Network was a little bit more accessible for people who didn't know the Facebook story. But I've seen people write and say with the Steve Jobs movie you really have to know the history of Apple. But it sounds like after you got to know the script, you were convinced?

ROGEN: Yeah, I disagree with that honestly. Again, I knew nothing about Apple. I didn't read the Walter Isaacson book. I really just read the movie and talked to the people involved, and did a lot of research about Steve Wozniak, and I find the movie incredibly interesting. I am in the movie which probably adds some bias to that opinion, but I feel as though personally, I don't feel you have to be at all interested in Apple or any computer to enjoy the movie, because I wasn't, and I did.

BOLTON: All right, and we know Steve Wozniak is particularly a fan of yours. But I want to ask you a little bit more of an emotional question. Steve Jobs' wife did not want this released. Did that color, does that color the way that you see it or that any of your co-stars see it?

ROGEN: No, honestly. I imagine that when most movies are made about public figures, their family has very conflicted feelings about that, and the people who knew them closely have very conflicted feelings about that, and I sympathize with that. But at the same time, once you cross a certain threshold of impact culturally, I think you kind of become everyone's to interpret in some way, and that doesn't mean it has to be a realistic interpretation, it just has to be a resonant interpretation, something that strikes a chord with people and has some honesty to it at least from the perspective of the person who is interpreting it.

So I sympathize with that, but I don't think that means that we shouldn't make movies about famous people and people who have impacted our culture basically.

BOLTON: All right, now speaking of culture and emotional connection, you recently hosted a big charity bar mitzvah for your buddy James Franco, whom we interviewed, and I actually asked him about the Sony hack. So this is going back a few months. And he said essentially, you were more connected to the Sony machine than he was. You told him not to worry, so therefore he didn't worry about it. I know that Sony settled this week for $8 million with its employees. Does that affect you? How do you see that settlement?

ROGEN: Honestly, I know nothing about it, I've been filming a movie all week, and just read that headline. But yeah, I'll read more about it and get back to you.

BOLTON: Yeah, I think James Franco's quote was don't worry, whatever, so we'll go with that, but we know the issue of course was identity theft. So Seth, I'm on twitter, I follow you, a lot of your recent comments have stood out to me, especially politically-based ones. I know you said f-you, I'm not going to say it, but to the real Ben Carson. What made you be so strong in your views to this presidential candidate?

ROGEN: Is that that strong? I don't know if it's that strong. I think it's all the language you choose to use in your daily life. To me that's not that strong a statement. It's marginal.

BOLTON: It's marginal. But I know you do take issues with -- I know this from following your account. For example, there was a man killed earlier today, three women wounded in a shooting at Tennessee State University, and I know that this is an issue that you feel passionately about.

ROGEN: I do feel murder is bad, yes, passionately. I didn't know about that specific story, but I am always on the anti-murder side of things.

BOLTON: All right, one more of your tweets here on the 7th, you tweeted out just when it seems like think the real Donald Trump cornered the market on saying insane B.S., I'm paraphrasing, real Ben Carson steps up to the challenge. Which candidate is more outrageous in your view, Carson or Trump?

ROGEN: That's a tough question. Honestly, I don't know, what do you think?

BOLTON: Well, it's a toss-up. But which of the candidates, any party, do you feel makes the most sense to you right now? I'm not saying who you're going to vote for, but which candidate out there right now makes the most sense to you?

ROGEN: I don't know, honestly, but I'm happy that Stephen Harper is out of the Canadian government. That I can speak very knowledgeably about.

BOLTON: All right, but if you could create one policy that would be adapted by the next President, no matter who he or she is, let's just say you get Carte Blanche, whatever you say right now would get passed into law, as a citizen, what would it be?

ROGEN: That's a tough question. I think America has a problem with imprisoning its own citizens, and I would probably push to reform that element of things.

BOLTON: All right, one more semi-political question here, more interpersonal politics.

ROGEN: Great.

BOLTON: Jennifer Lawrence wrote an open essay about equal pay, Bradley Cooper backed her up in GQ, then just this morning Jeremy Renner made a comment saying it's not my job to help female co-stars negotiate their salaries. Where do you stand on Hollywood's pay gap?

ROGEN: I think that it is real, and I think that I don't want to tell people what their responsibility is, but I personally view it as my responsibility to try to make, you know, that gap disappear as much as humanly possible. I think Hollywood has a lot of problems that, you know, obviously, involving race and gender, that you know, we, I know in my personal life we are trying to actively come up with ways to, again, to close those gaps and get rid of them altogether, because to me they're real. I see it, and yeah, I would advocate for trying to, you know, not have there be a massive gap between how much men and women get paid to do the same thing, and how many people of color are represented in films and television.

BOLTON: All right, we look forward to seeing it, Seth Rogen, thank you so much for the time, Steve Jobs actor Seth Rogen.

ROGEN: Thank you, hard hitting questions over here on Fox Business.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

BOLTON: Student loan debt is at a record high in the U.S., more than $1 trillion. More students are considering apprenticeships to avoid that financial burden. The appeal is that people get paid to learn, their college tuition is paid, and they have a greater chance of finding a job post graduation. Christopher Stone is with me now. He is a field engineer at a school in North Carolina. Christopher, welcome to the program, we are so glad to have you. What is a typical day like for you?

CHRIS STONE, FIELD ENGINEER APPRENTICE: A typical day for me, I normally I wake up about 5:00 a.m. start getting ready for work. I really try to make sure when I head into work, I'm set and ready to go. I normally work anywhere between 7:00 a.m. To 4:00 p.m., 8:00 a.m. to 5:00 p.m. I get to take a lot of the knowledge I'm learning in my actual college classes and apply them working some equipment for the printing industry. Normally, I get to work hands on with some mentors, get to learn a little bit of different fields that normally people don't get to see outside of the industry.

BOLTON: So will it take you longer to finish school?

STONE: It does. It's a two-year degree that I'll end up getting, it's stretched over the course of three years. I'm actually graduating a little bit earlier. I have been put on an accelerated path, trying to finish it up a little bit quicker than some people do, but three years for a two-year degree which is actually very productive for what we do.

BOLTON: I was going to say -- and with the work experience is great. What have your parents said about it?

STONE: My parents have been nothing but supportive. My senior year is when I really got into the program. You know it was either do military -- do a program or do a four-year college because that's the tendency in America. My parents were really supportive. They realized that I'm really good with my hands and I wanted to do something hands-on. So it worked out perfect for me because this program is nothing but hands-on experience and being able to use your education to do the work that you have to do.

BOLTON: So you are getting an education. You're getting paid, $13.50 an hour, and you're not going to graduate with any debt.

STONE: Yeah, exactly. I really cannot think of any other place you can get that. I'm actually making a little bit more than that, but just the fact that when I get out of there not only am I going to have no debt and a paycheck but I'm going to have experience that very few people will ever have in their life. And a lot of people are going to learn the book side of it and not actually get to apply it in real life, so it's going to be more difficult for them.

BOLTON: It makes all the sense in the world. Christopher Stone, thank you very much for the time. Congratulations, we are glad to have you with us.

STONE: Thank you very much.

BOLTON: When we come back, viewers are already speaking out about my interview with Steve Jobs actor Seth Rogen, some of your responses which are (Inaudible) after this.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

ROGEN: I think America has a problem with imprisoning its own citizens, and I would probably push through reform that element of things.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

ROGEN: I think that it is real. And I think that -- I mean, I don't want to tell people what their responsibility is, but I personally view it as my responsibility to try to make you know that gap disappear as much as humanly possible. I think that Hollywood has a lot of problems.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BOLTON: My interview with Seth Rogen provoking heated response on social media, seems like a lot of you will not be lining up to get tickets this weekend. Joseph said, Rogen looked best in Horton hears a Who. Seth Rogen is a Hollywood actor who has zero relevance when it comes to telling the rest of us how to behave. Of course, that was on equal pay. Thank you for joining us on Risk and Reward. Charles Payne is up next.

END

urn:contentItem:5VMJ-XS81-DY07-D1MX-00000-00Risks Hiding in Plain Sight2019-03-11T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:22:12ZLexisNexisRisks Hiding in Plain Sight

When an Italian man attended an art exhibit in the Serralves Museum in Portugal last year, he didn't expect to be hospitalized just for trying to view one of the works on display. But that's exactly what happened when a 60-year-old visitor and others were gathered around an installation called "Descent Into Limbo" by Anish Kapoor.

Viewing the exhibit involves staring down at a large black dot painted on the floor. There is an eight-foot-deep circular hole in the middle of the dot and the extremely black paint around the hole is meant to give "the illusion of a depthless void," according to reports of the back injuries sustained by the observer when he fell into the work of art. (Curious readers can see a photo of the installation on Facebook.) The hole within a circle of blackness was a risk hiding in plain sight-right in front of the art enthusiast but very easy to miss.

Why Only 22? What Else Should We Be Talking About?

Why not 25? Why not 50 or 100 risks? Twenty-two was the number of risks that we had room to publish here. But there are more. What underappreciated risks are on your radar screen? Share your ideas by contributing to a future Risk Alert. Submit your ideas to Susanne Sclafane at ssclafane@carriermanagement.com or Andrew Simpson at asimpson@wellsmedia.com

Even extremely vigilant insurers and reinsurers scanning the risk landscape for potential future liability problems are likely to fall into some landmines. What insurance and organizational risks of the immediate or distant future are being overlooked now?

Carrier Managementoffers its second look at some of the least visible risks, some that may not have surfaced in property/casualty C-suites or boardrooms, on insurance conference agendas, or in the mainstream press. So, there is nothing about drones shutting down airports, biometric privacy lawsuits or Alexa spying capabilities. This subjective list consists of items that intriguedCarrier Managementeditors for one reason or another. Some are worrisome; others perhaps laughable. But all triggered thoughts about insurance implications.

The editors invite feedback and suggestions for more "almost hidden" risks and urge readers to watch for CM Risk Alerts in a recurring series to be continued online and in print. Also, readers may wish to revisitCM's first publication of risk alerts: "67 Emerging Risks Nobody Is Talking About," Oct. 18. 2015 by Andrew G. Simpson.

Here are 22 risks hiding in plain sight:

1. More people are anxious and depressed. The World Economic Forum Annual Meeting in late January reported on the No. 1 mental health problem in the world: anxiety. According to 2016 data from the Institute for Health Metrics and Evaluation, anxiety impacted 3.83 percent of the world's population, or about 275 million people. Depression ranks second, affecting 3.77 percent. Are members of your workforce part of the statistics? What is your company doing to recognize the signs and help? Will depression and anxiety increase the cost of bodily injury liability and workers comp claims? The Forum's Global Risks 2019 report also discusses the ripples of individual anxiety on the global risk landscape. Psychological and emotional well-being is not just a risk for individuals in and of itself, "it also affects the wider global risks landscape, notably via impacts on social cohesion and politics," the report says.

("This is the world's biggest mental health problem-and you might not have heard of it," weforum.org, Jan. 14, 2019 by Sean Fleming; 2019 Global Risks Report, Jan. 16, 2019)

2. Is the ledger truly immutable? The question addresses one of a number of new risks arising from the use of smart ledgers, according to Michael Mainelli, executive chairman of Z/Yen Group. Others are: "Who indemnifies who for data entered on the ledger? What about systemic failure?" The risks, he said, suggest "some potentially big solutions...that insurers can provide."

("Unblocked by the Chain, Smart Ledger Systems Are 'The Thing' to Insure,"Carrier Management, Sept. 17, 2018 by Michael Mainelli)

3. ADA website accessibility suits. While not a new risk, the number of lawsuits alleging that business websites are not compliant with the Americans with Disabilities Act are reaching record levels, according to Seyfarth Shaw attorneys in theirADA Title III News & Insightsblog in mid-July last year. Plaintiffs with visual impairments and other disabilities filed more website accessibility lawsuits in federal court for the first six months of 2018 (1,053) than in all of 2017 (814). Will insurers continue to pay for defense? Under what policies? What about website modification costs?

("Website Access and Other ADA Title III Lawsuits Hit Record Numbers,"ADA Title III News & Insightsblog at www.adatitleiii.com/, July 17, 2018 by Minh N. Vu, Kristina M. Launey, Susan Ryan and Kevin Fritz)

4. Risks cemented; tall wood buildings get green light. The Portland Cement Association alertedCarrier Managementvia email about what it views as a threat to public safety: the potential approval by the International Code Council (ICC) of construction of tall buildings from wood products. The American Wood Council sees it differently, lauding the ultimate passage of a package of 14 tall mass timber code change proposals in December. "Mass timber has been capturing the imagination of architects and developers...ICC's rigorous study, testing and voting process now recognizes a strong, low-carbon alternative to traditional tall building materials used by the building and construction industry," AWC's president said. What about insurers? Portland Cement Association's alert said that "insurers recognize that there are greater risks with wood-frame construction buildings versus concrete buildings," citing a 2017 survey by the National Ready Mixed Concrete Association finding lower builders' risk and commercial property rates for concrete structures.

(Press Release: "National Poll: Three in Four Americans Think Tall Wood Construction Is a Threat to Public Safety," cement.org, Aug. 14, 2018; Press Release, "AWC: Tall Mass Timber code changes get final approval," awc.org, Dec. 19, 2018; "Survey of Insurance Costs for Multifamily Buildings Constructed with Wood frames and Concrete," Boston College, Dr. Pieter VanderWerf and Nicholas Haidari)

5. In the name of beauty: toxic trio. InsurTech analytics company Praedicat estimates that latent liability from dibutyl phthalate (DBP) affecting both consumers and workers has the potential to generate in excess of $100 billion in losses to the U.S. economy. DBP is one of three toxic chemicals commonly found in nail polish and other beauty products, Praedicat and Allianz Global Corporate & Specialty alerted in a September 2018 report. Whether the inclusion of the three chemicals is known and intended or it is unknown, general liability insurers may pay bodily injury claims and product recall costs. Also among the risks is the growing threat of product mislabeling. "Manufacturers who market their products as being 'three-free could be held liable if their products contain any of these chemicals, even if it is not their fault."

("Emerging Liability Risks: The 'Toxic Trio,'" by Allianz Global Corporate & Specialty and Praedicat)

6. Babies from human cells. A researcher at Japan's Kyoto University created stem cells from human blood cells and then guided them to develop into "primordial" reproductive cells at a very early stage of egg development.The Washington Post, reporting on the research published in the journalScience, describes this production of "a precursor" to human eggs in a laboratory as game-changing. Actual egg production is just "a matter of time," a former Brown University dean of medicine told the newspaper. Beyond the ethical concerns discussed in the article, a Harvard Medical School stem cell researcher said a major concern will be the possibility of cancers or other diseases that could arise in any babies created from such an egg, suggesting one scenario that might impact liability insurers for future egg developers.

("The 'game-changing' technique to create babies from skin cells just stepped forward,"The Washington Post, Sept. 20, 2018 by Carolyn Y. Johnson; "IVF moonshot takes step towards making human eggs from skin," Sept. 21, 2018)

Photo by Siemens

7. Here come driverless trolleys. Siemens Mobility demonstrated a test tram driving autonomously in real traffic last September on a six-kilometer section in Potsdam, Germany. According toThe Guardian, a staged emergency added drama to the demonstration when a Siemens employee pushed a pram onto a walkway running across the path of the tram, causing the vehicle to brake until a human conductor restarted the system after the track was clear. With multiple lidar, radar and camera sensors serving as "digital eyes" and complex algorithms functioning as the tram "brain," commercial insurers and reinsurers will need to respond with a complex collection of liability and technology E&O coverages.

(Press Release: "Siemens Mobility presents world's first autonomous tram," Sept. 3, 2018; "World's first autonomous tram launches in Germany,"MIT Technology Review Download,Sept. 24, 2018; "Germany launches world's first autonomous tram in Potsdam,"The Guardian, Sept. 23, 2018)

8. Keeping tech dinosaurs alive. According to aWall Street Journalreport, Cobol is still the most prevalent programming language in the financial services industry worldwide, with software programmed in Cobol powering millions of banking transactions every day and underpinning critical computer mainframes. What's in your mainframe? Are you ditching it? If not, you'll be on the hunt to find a programmer with a generation of Cobol specialists retiring.

("Do You Know COBOL? If So, There Might Be a Job for You,"Wall Street Journal, Sept. 21, 2018 by Max Colchester)

9. EEO language scares off minority candidates. "Job seekers believe that the inclusion of an EEO [equal employment opportunity] statement considerably raises the belief that African Americans and Hispanics are token hires," two university researchers said in a working paper released by the National Bureau of Economic Research. As a result, job listings with EEO language draw fewer minority candidates-in some cases, 50 percent fewer-than ads without the phrase. A novel starting point for EPL claims? How will you create a more diverse workforce at your company?

("A surprising way minorities are turned off by job postings,"Quartz, Sept. 25, 2018 by Oliver Staley, accessed via SmartBrief on Workforce)

10. But they're so cute. Doctors at Johns Hopkins Hospital in Baltimore report that therapy dogs visiting to cheer kids undergoing cancer treatment carried MRSA bacteria around the facility. Kids who spent more time with the dogs had a six-times greater chance of coming away with superbug bacteria. While the study came to a happy conclusion, and also found that washing the dogs before visits and using special wipes in the hospital took away the risk, liability insurers need to be on alert for other ways of spreading bacteria. Mobile devices, perhaps?

("Therapy dogs can spread superbugs to kids, hospital finds,"Associated Press, Oct. 5, 2018 by Mike Stobbe)

11. Silicon Valley bubble. The former head of PR at Google, Jessica Powell, has written a "totally fictional but essentially true" story of Silicon Valley, satirizing cultural stagnancy at what many think of as the world's most innovative companies. Instead, she finds an "engineering-and-data-obsessed monoculture that invites little input from people outside the bubble,"The New York Timeswrote in its account of the book. "If you have a hierarchy where engineers are at the very top and the people who are interfacing with the outside world are a couple rungs below that, you really miss something when those people don't have an equal voice at the table," Powell toldNYT, describing "a monoculture of thought" as a "real problem." As tech engineers invade the insurance space, will they bring an unwelcome culture with them?

("Silicon Valley's Keystone Problem: A Monoculture of Thought,"The New York Times,Oct. 2, 2018 by Farhad Manjoo, reporting on Jessica Powell's book, "The Big Disruption," available onMedium)

12. Get some sleep! "The amount of sleep as well as its quality is in decline across the globe. Increasing pressure at work and in our spare time, blue LED lights in our smartphones disrupting our internal body clock, and travel are among the many drivers that don't allow us to sleep enough or not well enough," warned Jeffrey Bohn, director of the Swiss Re Institute, in the September/October 2018 edition ofCarrier Management. Explaining why P/C insurers should care, he notes that two out of three losses worldwide are due to human failure. Based on Swiss Re's sigma research, this would mean that people trigger a loss volume of $3 billion per year. Separately, speaking at the World Business Forum in November, Arianna Huffington, co-founder ofThe Huffington Post,implored executives to recognize that "in the human operating system, downtime is a feature not a bug." Huffington, who founded Thrive Global, a wellness platform, after her personal experience of collapsing from exhaustion, is on a mission to change the habits that Bohn referred to, famously penning an open letter to Elon Musk about his "wildly outdated, anti-scientific and horribly inefficient way of using human energy."

("Emerging Risks: What's the Next Asbestos?"Carrier Management, Sept. 19, 2018 by Jeffrey Bohn based on Swiss Re Institute's May 2018 Swiss Re report "SONAR 2018: New emerging risk insights"; "An open letter to Elon Musk," Aug. 17, 2018, Thrive Global by Arianna Huffington)

13. Will it float? WhenBusiness Insidertweeted out the message, "In the future, floating islands could be considered home," on Oct. 8. 2018, the idea wasn't entirely new.Business Insider, the BBC,National Geographicand other media have described these artificial solutions to growing populations and rising seas for several years. In fact, the video accompanying the tweet was published by MARIN (the Maritime Research of the Netherlands) in July 2017, which tested the "first floating mega island" constructed of interconnected floating triangles capable of supporting housing, infrastructure or serving as places to generate renewable energy. "It is unknown how much wind and currents the islands can withstand,"Business Insidernoted, asking the types of questions insurers ask about coastal properties. What about people? Will half the population get sea sick? What types of insurers will cover floating cities and floating wind farms against those natural perils and manmade ones as well? Home insurers? Marine and energy underwriters? A new category of coverage?

(@businessinsider, https://t.co/lE9IZhnOFH; MARIN press release, July 13, 2017)

Photo by Lime

14. E-scooting on the job. "If an employee opts to use a motorized scooter for a work-related purpose and is injured, under certain circumstances a workers compensation claim could result." The warning from Colorado workers comp insurer Pinnacol Assurance is one of the most recent discussions of potential risk resulting from hopping on an e-scooter that can be unlocked from a smartphone app. While Pinnacol has yet to see a comp claim, scooter services Lime and Bird have already been hit with lawsuits, including a class action filed in Los Angeles accusing the firms of "gross negligence" and "aiding and abetting assault." Separately,MIT Technology Reviewcompiled more reports revealing how the promise of stress-free mobility is causing unintended problems: a potential software malfunction causing e-scooters to abruptly halt midride, throwing off and injuring passengers, which prompted Bird to stop operations in Switzerland; allegations that motorized vehicles violate the Americans with Disabilities Act by blocking access to San Diego's streets and sidewalks set forth in a lawsuit filed by Disability Rights California; battery fires prompting a partial recall of some scooters. "So if you cause an accident, are you covered?" The Insurance Information Institute addresses the questions in a September 2018 blog. Maybe by a personal umbrella, but not by homeowners or auto insurance, I.I.I. says.

("Class-action lawsuit accuses e-scooter companies of 'gross negligence,'"The Washington Post,Oct. 12, 2018 by Peter Holley; "Lime is pulling its scooters in Switzerland after a possible software glitch made people fall off,"The Download/MIT Technology Review, Jan. 14, 2019; "Disability advocates target city of San Diego and scooter companies in lawsuit,"Los Angeles Times, Jan. 12, 2019 by Greg Moran; "E-scooter sharing programs: are you covered?" The Triple-I Blog, Sept. 7, 2018 by Lucian McMahon)

See also, "15 Emerging Risks from Policies to Playgrounds, Sandboxes to Scooters," Oct. 18, 2018,Insurance Journalby Andrew G. Simpson; "First e-Scooter DUI Case for Los Angeles," Oct. 1, 2018,Insurance Journal/Associate Press.

15. Hacking a water disaster. Researchers from Ben-Gurion University found that popular commercial irrigation systems have security weaknesses, potentially allowing hackers to turn them on and off remotely. According to anMIT Technology Reviewreport on the research, the vulnerability means that hackers can trick the irrigation systems into watering by feeding IoT devices fake commands directly or by serving up bogus weather data. "The researchers claim a botnet of 1,350-odd sprinklers could empty an urban water tower in an hour, and around 24,000 could empty a flood water reservoir overnight," the article says, offering an example of a cyber physical damage disaster scenario that may not be insurable.

("Hackers could turn your garden sprinklers into a cyber weapon,"The Download from MIT Technology Review, Aug. 8, 2018)

16. Mountains of batteries. As polluting gas-powered vehicles are replaced with electric ones, another environmental problem will quickly emerge. "As the first generation of electric vehicles and stationary storage begins to phase out next decade, millions of lithium-ion battery packs will go out of service. BloombergNEF [New Energy Finance] estimates the total will reach one million metric tons in 2027 and keep growing, creating challenges and opportunities for regulators, manufacturers and recyclers."

("A World of Worn Out EV Batteries,"Bloomberg Businessweek, Jan. 11, 2019 by Richard Stubbe)

17. Blame it on climate change. A report from the Miami-Dade government in Florida finds that tens of thousands of county septic tanks are failing. "By 2040, 64 percent...could have issues every year, affecting not only the people who rely on them for sewage treatment but the region's water supply and the health of anyone who wades through floodwaters," aMiami Heraldarticle says, revealing that sea-level rise is contributing to the problem. Septic tanks need a layer of dirt underneath for final filtration work and to return liquid waste back to an aquifer. But sea-level rise is pushing the groundwater higher and soaking through dirt that was once dry. "Waste water doesn't filter like it's supposed to in soggy soil. In some cases, it comes back out, turning a front yard into a poopy swamp," the article says, putting the cost to rip out all the failing tanks and laying down new pipes at $3.3 billion. While home insurers aren't likely to cover septic problems, the murky situation could complicate other property insurance claims, and there might be scenarios where environmental insurers cover similar sea-level-induced problems for municipalities.

("A $3 billion problem: Miami-Dade's septic tanks are already failing due to sea rise,"Miami Herald, Jan. 10. 2019 by Alex Harris)

18. Cyber meets EPL. One-third of identity theft victims say they experienced difficulties at work-either with their boss or co-workers-as a result of the crime, according to an analysis of 2017 trends from The Identity Theft Resource Center, a consumer advocate. A CNBC report on the analysis says potential effects can include fights with the boss over time off, job loss and difficulties gaining new employment with employers who check credit score but don't ask why scores are bad. A clash problem with an insurance solution?

("What to do when personal identity theft becomes a professional problem," CNBC.com, Jan. 8, 2019 by Kelli B. Grant)

19. Are we getting dumber? In its May 2018 SONAR report, Swiss Re Institute suggested that "digital assistance systems make us complacent, obedient and less skilled." Kicking off the idea, the report asks: "Ever been impressed by a child using the latest tablet as if this were an instinctive skill? Maybe you have watched a child trying to swipe a finger across the page of a printed book only to learn it needs a different movement to turn the page. The more we digitize, the more our analogue skills atrophy." Among the hypothesized and observed insurance impacts: "Overreliance on digital assistance can increase the number of [motor] accidents," and "Catastrophic event losses may significantly increase should assistance systems fail and human skills are not available for workarounds." Says the report: "We see strange accidents where cars drive off a cliff or into a lake seemingly for no reason."

(Swiss Re Institute's May 2018 Swiss Re report, "SONAR 2018: New emerging risk insights," p. 28)

20. Restructuring leads to suicides. A cautionary tale on how not to handle a workforce reduction comes from France, where telecom executives were put on trial after a wave of staff suicides. "Management used 'pathogenic' restructuring methods such as forcing people into new jobs and giving unattainable performance objectives," said a report by labor inspectors. The restructuring plan aimed to reduce headcount by 22,000 while shifting 10,000 people into new jobs and recruiting 6,000 new employees.

("Orange, former executives to stand trial over staff suicides,"Reuters, June 16, 2018)

21. Smartphoneaholics anonymous. Even though a July 2018Financial Timesarticle reported that "serious legal threats or class action lawsuits have notyetemerged around smartphone addiction," with activist investors and pension funds demanding action to protect the youngest smartphone users earlier in the year, can legal actions be far behind? "There is a developing consensus around the world, including Silicon Valley, that the potential long-term consequences of new technologies need to be factored in at the outset, and no company can outsource that responsibility," Jana Partners LLC and the California State Teachers' Retirement Systems said in a letter to Apple obtained by theWall Street Journallast January. While the investor pleas centered around the negative consequences of obsessive smartphone use on children, behavioral addiction impacts people of all ages. "Researchers who study behavioral addiction see strong parallelsin how the human brain responds to addictive substances like drugs, alcohol and cigarettes and potentially addictive behaviors like gambling, shopping, exercise and, yes, smartphone use," reported Praedicat, an analytics firm, in a March 2018 blog item. Unlike substance abuse, which can undeniably be linked to serious harms, "the long-term tangible damages to human health and well-being (beyond accidents caused by distracted driving and walking) are not understood at this time," Praedicat's David Loughran wrote. "Given the role that addiction played in establishing liability in the $250 billion tobacco litigation, Praedicat is expanding its monitoring of the biomedical research and its implications for liability to include addiction, with analyses expected on a range of both substance- and behavior-related addictions such as opioids, sugar, gambling and the most quintessential of modern risks, smartphones," he said.

("iPhones and Children Are a Toxic Pair, Say Two Big Apple Investors,"Wall Street Journal, Jan. 7, 2018 by David Benoit; "Smartphone addiction: big tech's balancing act on responsibility over revenue,"Financial Times, July 23, 2018 by Tim Bradshaw and Hannah Kuchler; "What might smartphones, gambling, sex and exercise have in common: Behavioral addiction," Praedicat blog, March 12, 2018 by David Loughran)

22. Desks failing in fitness. The headline of a February 2018 article inThe Telegraphsays it all: "Standing desks 'increase pain' and slow down mental ability, study suggests." Touted by many as a way to combat the ills of increasingly sedentary lifestyles, the new study, published in the journalErgonomics, actually linked prolonged use of standing desks with lower limb discomfort and deteriorating mental reactiveness. The Australian researchers only observed 20 participants working at standing desks for two hours, with backaches and swollen veins-which can endanger the heart-being reported. "Mental reactiveness also slowed down after roughly an hour and a quarter; however, 'creative' decision-making was shown to marginally improve," the article said, without providing an example of either reaction. "They are not a panacea for back pain, yet companies are worried that if they provide them, they'll be sued," the article says, quoting a University professor. Or maybe their use will result in more workers comp claims. ("Standing desks 'increase pain' and slow down mental ability, study suggests,"The Telegraph,Feb. 23, 2018 by Henry Bodkin)

urn:contentItem:5WXK-W0M1-JBFS-C3W0-00000-00Rivals see a chance to unseat YouTube;FTC inquiry could set off a shift in the kids media landscape.2019-08-29T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:22:12ZLexisNexisBUSINESSBusiness DeskPart CPg. 1Rivals see a chance to unseat YouTubeFTC inquiry could set off a shift in the kids media landscape.Mark BergenBergen writes for Bloomberg.

Earlier this summer, the Federal Trade Commission began holding private talks with YouTube officials, part of a burgeoning investigation. The video service stands accused of breaking laws overseeing kids' web habits, placing a massive library of media and accompanying revenue in jeopardy. Neither YouTube nor the regulators have discussed the talks publicly.

Yet despite the secrecy, a small British marketing firm started emailing some marquee YouTube advertisers about the developments. Reports indicated that the FTC would hit YouTube with a record fine and force its operations to change -- something, the emails noted, that would "be of interest" to YouTube's sponsors. "Regardless of what size the fine actually is, it represents a shift in the world for children's digital privacy," read the message. "Look forward to seeing you soon."

The emails were from SuperAwesome Ltd. Toy makers, animators and other brands pay the company to place online ads or access tools such as the start-up's "safe, moderated" system for internet comments. In July, SuperAwesome added another offering: a video service, called Rukkaz, that works much like YouTube. Amateur broadcasters upload videos, sponsors back them and kids watch. Only the start-up pledged to work with only hand-picked broadcasters, and it pitched the service as a way to abide by privacy laws and avoid the demented footage lurking on the open web.

"This is something that Google and Facebook, and arguably Apple, should have been doing for the past five years," said Dylan Collins, SuperAwesome's chief executive. "And they haven't."

Waves of new media darlings have tried to unseat YouTube, with no success. But Collins is one of several entrepreneurs trying to strike while YouTube is in turmoil. The video behemoth, owned by Alphabet Inc.'s Google, has earned a reputation as a Wild West of media, a place where young viewers have too readily stumbled on footage of crass humor or bloody violence. Lawmakers have asked about this, part of the scrutiny of the privacy practices and dominance of big tech.

The FTC is probing whether Google violated the Children's Online Privacy Protection Act, or COPPA, which prohibits tracking the personal information of minors younger than 13. YouTube's frequent tweaks to its all-powerful algorithms and ads policies have left video creators disgruntled. A handful of upstarts are hoping this momentum will help their cause. They've roped in venture financing, licensing deals and customers with the promise of creating kid-safe internet real estate.

The FTC is inadvertently playing a role, too. Uncertainty over the case is producing panic in parts of the YouTube community, prompting some stars to hunt for alternatives. News reports surfaced that the FTC may force YouTube to move all children's videos to its Kids app or cut them off from ads.

"No one really has a sense of what is going to happen," said Michael, who runs KidCity and two other YouTube family channels. He is one of more than 150 YouTubers jumping to Rukkaz. He isn't moving off YouTube but will cross-post select YouTube clips with the start-up, which will share ad revenue. He asked that his last name not be revealed to protect the privacy of his children.

Kids media online is booming as millions of children swap Saturday morning cartoons for streaming and smartphones. Most streaming services, such as Netflix, run curated, slickly produced shows for kids, while YouTube relies on a mountain of unscripted, user-generated content. Multiple people who make these videos said that, in recent months, support representatives from YouTube have halted contact without explanation.

A chief concern for many creators is that their videos will be restricted to the YouTube Kids mobile app, a much less popular service, where Google runs fewer ads. "That would put everyone out of business. I mean, almost overnight," Michael said.

YouTube is unlikely to do that, or to cut off all its kids and family footage from ads. On Wednesday, YouTube said it would launch a separate website for children and change the age categories on Kids. Also, YouTube is planning to end "targeted" ads on videos kids are likely to watch. That solution would make it harder for the creators behind those clips to earn more from ads, although it's a less draconian move than some other rumored options.

A problem with this approach, though, is defining kids videos. COPPA applies to any web service "directed to children." While most clips on YouTube Kids, such as nursery rhyme cartoons, clearly are, other huge swaths of YouTube, such as footage of video game streaming, arguably aren't. Yet it's an open secret that younger viewers love watching people play video games. Roughly a quarter of the YouTube ads one major toy company buys run on "Minecraft" videos, according to a media buyer with knowledge of the matter who asked not to be identified discussing private data.

"The difficulty here is determining what is 'kids directed,' " said Ashkan Soltani, a privacy researcher who was previously the chief technologist for the FTC. "It's not a bright-line rule."

Once the line is drawn, YouTube creators do not want to fall on the wrong side. Many, like KidCity's Michael, now describe their productions as "family-based play" or "co-play" -- videos that feature adults and, the hope is, that adults watch.

YouTube is not the only major player in an uncomfortable spot. The FTC fined Bytedance Inc., the owner of popular app TikTok, for violating federal guidelines on minors. Critics have complained that Facebook Inc. illegally tracks children's online behavior. Many in children's media don't expect a viable solution to come from the household names.

"It doesn't make sense that big internet companies can take something they designed for grown-ups and make that for kids," said Kevin Donahue, an early YouTube executive who now runs Epic, an e-book start-up. "You have to create something new." (Donahue said he has no interest in rivaling his old company, though. "We're not at all doing that," he said.)

For most newcomers, that something looks like Netflix: A subscription service with a limited selection. The idea is that parents would pay for some parts of YouTube popular with kids -- the toy unboxers and niche animators -- without the pratfalls of an unlimited content library. Three years ago, Epic added video to its $7.99-a-month e-books app. It offers a few thousand clips, all reviewed by staff members. Kidoodle.TV, a Canadian company, offers children's videos on set-top box services such as Roku. Another, JuniorTube, had a slate of curated amateur videos available on a subscription-based app. Roku added a new curated kids and family section.

Highbrow, a London-based start-up, sells a $6.49 monthly service with the tagline "Trusted by schools and parents worldwide." Priyanka Raswant, a corporate lawyer, formed the company as she was preparing to have her first child. She found most videos available on YouTube Kids "nonsensical" and the app unhelpful for parents.

"If you see something outrageous, you have to report it," Raswant said. "They've put the onus on the parents. Most parents don't even have time to brush their teeth."

Highbrow has partnered with telecoms in Latin America and India for distribution, but it doesn't share sales data. The service carries videos from Pinkfong, the studio behind mega-hit "Baby Shark," as well as smaller shows such as "Travel With Kids" from PBS.

SuperAwesome is one of the few borrowing YouTube's model of free, ad-supported programming. It is set to book $60 million in revenue this year. (YouTube doesn't share sales, but estimates place the yearly sales from its kids content north of $700 million.) Collins said his company is profitable. Of course, the uncertainty surrounding kids online video could also threaten those profits. His ad business is competing against those at the twin giants of Google and Facebook. The benefits of SuperAwesome's ad services might not be as apparent if YouTube passes through the FTC probe unscathed and grows its Kids app.

That could mean that more is riding on Collins' video service. For Rukkaz, Collins is targeting YouTube's blind spots. Most of YouTube Kids caters to preschoolers, so Collins is recruiting creators aiming for an older audience. He's also approaching creators with between 500,000 and a million subscribers on YouTube -- enough to earn livings from the site, but not to be inoculated from its swings. "This entire community is really being orphaned by YouTube," Collins said.

Michael, who runs the KidCity channel, is optimistic about Rukkaz. He's planning to use SuperAwesome's feature for hosting video comments, which he finds useful for getting audience feedback. YouTube shut off comments on videos with children this year but allowed a select group of channels to keep them with the condition that they "actively moderate" the posts. Filtering those comments, though, requires using a manual system. "You have to go in there and spell the dirty words," he said.

His attempts to find footing beyond YouTube haven't succeeded in the past. On KidCity, the Texan father and his two children perform long skits dressed up as familiar cartoon characters -- Marvel Comics' Wolverine or Disney's Queen Elsa. They tried to post one of these clips on Amazon's self-publishing service, Prime Video Direct, but the company rejected the videos, citing intellectual property concerns. A KidCity clip of his son donning a Spider-Man costume and testing a Spider-Man toy has more than 85 million views on YouTube. YouTube's laissez-faire approach to media has brought scathing critics, but it has also enabled countless careers online.

"That's the creator platform for kids," Michael said. "The only one, unfortunately."

At least one would-be YouTube rival has already bit the dust. JuniorTube, a company based in Indiana, made a paid app and recruited a few established YouTubers. Like the others, it managed the costs of hosting video and other back-end services, splitting sales with video producers. In May, these producers received an email that JuniorTube had shut down "due to very poor business performance and audience interest."
