MCDOWELL: Because I just want to add one thing to what the judge was talking about, and this is these are two separate stories in The Wall Street Journal, the Justice Department, the broad review of the big tech companies for antitrust issues, and another story in The Wall Street Journal, mentioned earlier on the show, Apple dominates the app store search results, thwarting competitors. That's the gist of it. Search for music, audio book, other categories rank company apps first, developers find it is unfair. Apple says, "Oh, well, our algorithm doesn't do -- the algorithm's not written that way."

BARTIROMO: Yes, right.

MURPHY: Well --

MCDOWELL: But, again, blame the algorithm. How many times have we heard that?

BARTIROMO: Somebody programs the algorithm.

MURPHY: Somebody does, but when you -- Apple put up an Apple Store, they invested a lot of time and money into the Apple Store, so I think the argument can be made that they can promote their product, and as the judge was saying, if you don't like it, you -- as a developer, you can choose to only serve -- put your product on Android, or on Google's platform, so I think the ultimate thing here will be for the big tech companies like if you're aware, you the public know, you go on Google and you search for something, you're going to get a anticonservative bias or very left wing type bias, then you may choose to go to a different search engine.

So, I think the ultimate thing here will be them policing themselves and if Apple is going to promote their products above someone else's, now you know about it, so you can choose deal with it or go elsewhere.

NAPOLITANO: But the lynchpin of all criminal antitrust prosecution is, was the consumer harmed? And if government can't show harm to the consumer, it doesn't matter that Apple favors its own products.

BARTIROMO: Well, Devin Nunes was harmed.

NAPOLITANO: Well, that -- that's not criminal, now. The DOJ --

BARTIROMO: But he was harmed. There were -- there were texts and tweets - -

NAPOLITANO: Well, that's (INAUDIBLE) apples and oranges. Whether Devin Nunes was harmed is irrelevant to whether or not the DOJ is going to have a successful criminal prosecution of the four big tech ones.

MCDOWELL: All right. We'll take a break. When we come back, we are watching earnings this morning. A slew of heavy hitters like Boeing and Caterpillar all reporting before the opening bell this morning. The stocks are reacting. As you see, Caterpillar down better than 4-1/2 percent, Boeing down almost one percent next up.

BARTIROMO: Welcome back. We are awaiting Former Special Counsel Robert Mueller's opening statement before the House Judiciary Committee on Capitol Hill. What you're looking at right here is the hearing beginning. It is in progress right now. So far, here's what we've heard. Jerry Nadler, the Chairman, made his opening statement, Doug Collins, the ranking member made his. Let's listen in.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

NADLER: -- 2016 special election. He received his B.A. from Princeton University and M.A. from New York University in my district, and his J.D. from the University of Virginia. Mr. Mueller is accompanied by his -- by Counsel Aaron Zebley who served as Deputy Special Counsel on the investigation. We welcome our distinguished witness and we thank you for participating in today's hearing.

Now, if you would please rise, I will begin by swearing you in. Would you raise your right hand, please? Left hand. Do you swear or affirm under penalty of perjury that the testimony you're about to give is true and correct to the best of your knowledge, information and belief, so help you God? Let the record show the witness answered the affirmative. Thank you, and please be seated. Please note that your written statement will be entered into the record in its entirety. Accordingly, I ask that you summarize your testimony in five minutes. Director Mueller, you may begin.

ROBERT MUELLER, FORMER SPECIAL COUNSEL: Good morning, Chairman Nadler, the -- and Ranking Member Collins, and the members of the committee. As you know, in May 2017, the acting attorney general asked me to serve as special counsel. I undertook that role because I believe that it was of paramount interest to the nation to determine whether a foreign adversary had interfered in the presidential election.

As the acting attorney general said at the time, the appointment was necessary in order for the American people to have full confidence in the outcome. My staff and I carried out this assignment with that critical objective in mind, to work quietly, thoroughly and with integrity so that the public would have full confidence in the outcome.

The order appointing me as special counsel directed our office to investigate Russian interference in the 2016 Presidential Election. This included investigating any links or coordination between the Russian government and individuals associated with the Trump campaign. It also included investigating efforts to interfere with or obstruct our investigation.

Throughout the investigation, I continually stressed two things to the team that we had assembled. First, we needed to do our work as thoroughly as possible and expeditiously as possible. It was in the public interest for our investigation to be complete, not to last a day longer than was necessary.

Second, the investigation needed to be conducted fairly and with absolute integrity. Our team would not leak or take other actions that could compromise the integrity of our work. All decisions were made based on the facts and the law.

During the course of our investigation, we charged more than 30 defendants with committing federal crimes, including 12 officers of the Russian military. Seven defendants have been convicted or plead guilty.

Certain of the charges we brought remain pending today. And for those matters, I stress that the indictments contain allegations and every defendant is presumed innocent unless and until proven guilty.

In addition to the criminal charges we brought, as required by Justice Department regulations, we submitted a confidential report to the attorney general at the conclusion of our investigation. The report set forth the results of our work and the reasons for our charging and declination decisions. The attorney general later made the report largely public.

As you know, I made a few limited remarks -- limited remarks about our report when we closed the Special Counsel's Office in May of this year. There are certain points that bear emphasis. First, our investigation found that the Russian government interfered in our election in sweeping and systematic fashion.

Second, the investigation did not establish that members of the Trump campaign conspired with the Russian government in its election interference activities. We did not address collusion, which is not a legal term, rather we focused on whether the evidence was sufficient to charge any member of the campaign with taking part in a criminal conspiracy, and it was not.

Third, our investigation of efforts to obstruct the investigation and lie to investigators was of critical importance. Obstruction of justice strikes at the core of the government's effort to find the truth and to hold wrongdoers accountable.

Finally, as described in volume two of our report, we investigated a series of actions by the president towards the investigation. Based on Justice Department policy and principles of fairness, we decided we would not make a decision as to whether the president committed a crime. That was our decision then and it remains our decision today.

Let me say a further word about my appearance today. It is unusual for a prosecutor to testify about a criminal investigation. And given my role as a prosecutor, there are reasons why my testimony will necessarily be limited.

First, public testimony could affect several ongoing matters. In some of these matters, court rules or judicial orders limit the disclosure of information to protect -- to protect the fairness of the proceedings. And consistent with longstanding Justice Department policy, it would be inappropriate for me to comment in any way that could affect an ongoing matter.

Second, the Justice Department has asserted privileges concerning investigative information and decisions, ongoing matters within the Justice Department, and deliberations within our office. These are Justice Department privileges that I will respect.

The department has released the letter discussing the restrictions of my testimony. I, therefore, will not be able to answer questions about certain areas that I know are of public interest.

For example, I am unable to address questions about the initial opening of the FBI's Russia investigation which occurred months before my appointment or matters related to the so-called Steele dossier. These matters are subject of ongoing review by the department. Any questions on these topics should, therefore, be directed to the FBI or the Justice Department.

As I explained when we closed the Special Counsel's Office in May, our report contains our findings and analysis and the reasons for the decisions we made. We conducted an extensive investigation over two years. In writing the report, we stated the results of our investigation with precision. We scrutinized every word.

I do not intend to summarize or describe the results of our work in a different way in the course of my testimony today. And as I said on May 29th, the report is my testimony, and I will stay within that text.

And as I stated in May, I will not comment on the actions of the attorney general or of Congress. I was appointed as a prosecutor, and I intend to adhere to that role and to the department's standards that govern it.

I'll be joined today by Deputy Special Counsel Aaron Zebley. Mr. Zebley has extensive experience as a federal prosecutor and at the FBI, where he served as my chief of staff. Mr. Zebley was responsible for the day-to-day oversight of the investigations conducted by our office.

Now, I also want to, again, say thank you to the attorneys, the FBI agents, the analysts, the professional staff who helped us conduct this investigation in a fair and independent matter. These individuals who spent nearly two years of -- working on this matter were of the highest integrity.

Let me say one more thing. Over the course of my career, I have seen a number of challenges to our democracy. The Russian government's effort to interfere in our election is among the most serious. And as I said on May 29th, this deserves the attention of every American. Thank you, Mr. Chairman.

NADLER: Thank you. Thank you. We will now proceed under the five-minute rule with questions. I will begin by recognizing myself for five minutes.

Director Mueller, the president has repeatedly claimed that your report found there was no obstruction --

(END VIDEO CLIP)

BARTIROMO: Robert Mueller is -- just finished his opening statement now. You'll hear from Jerry Nadler followed by Doug Collins for five minutes, as you heard. Mark Penn is with us this morning. And, Mark, he was very clear, he's not going to go beyond that report, and, you know, he's talking about, the significance of Russia getting in the U.S.'s issues and meddling. What about the FBI meddling? What's your reaction?

PENN: Well, my reaction is, he's not giving much of anything to anybody, with the exception that he was ambiguous about Justice Department policy in terms of the president and obstruction. That will be the important and probably the only question that anybody will get out of him, and, of course, what he said is he's not going to talk about the dossier, the origins of the -- of the investigation or any of that, he is just going to pass the buck on that so Republicans are going to get -- be extremely frustrated by this. We're not going to get the straight story from him. And finally, he called the Russian intervention sweeping and systematic. I'm not sure he documented that it was sweeping, perhaps systematic, yes.

BARTIROMO: But, Mark, can he really get away with that? I mean, look, you know this better than anybody. You've written about it. I've written about it and we've talked about this for 2-1/2 years, we know what went down as a result of that cabal of individuals who tried to stop Donald Trump. Can he get away saying that? I'm not looking at the oranges of the Russia investigation, I'm not discussing with dossier, I'm not discussing the FISA abuse.

PENN: Look, this is a prosecutor who's gotten away with unfettered power investigating every associate and friend of the president who knew there was no underlying crime early in the investigation, and then prosecuted people by systematically looking for anything in their life to try to get leverage and threaten them to turn on the president. When you look at what this practitioner has gotten away with, it's a lot more than this testimony.

BARTIROMO: Chris Bedford, real quick.

BEDFORD: Yes, I think it looks like he's almost intentionally using a cadence that would make it so people won't be able to use his speaking in campaign ads interrupting himself coughing, going slowly, his word spacing, it's as if he's designing this to not be used politically, which is basically what the Democrats are hoping for. This is going to go back to politics and they're going to have to ask was the investigation launched, was Rosenstein fired, was Mueller fired, was the -- were the -- was the report released?

If all if that happened, then you're going to have to make the public case for a collusion, or obstruction, and that's going to be very difficult.

BARTIROMO: Yes. Mark Penn, stay with me because I have a question on Microsoft to you before you go. But, Dagen, that's exactly what you said earlier, watch his cadence, watch whether or not he's feeble.

MCDOWELL: Whether -- and it raises the question, Chris, whether it's intentional or not. Does he come across as if he's in command of the facts of the investigation? Again, he has this sidekick with him, for help, potentially. Does he come across like he was the man in charge of the investigation? Because then that raises issues about all the Democratic donors who were on his team. But, again, to quote that professor, William Howe, vague, cryptic, and at times convoluted, that doesn't make good campaign ad.

CUMMINS: But he did get a little bit, you know, emotional or put a little punch into his defense of the notion that, you know, obstruction of justice is a very serious thing, kind of a sanctimonious speech about that, and I think in doing so, he may you know, arguably open the door to answering questions about obstruction of justice.

For instance, who he has ever prosecuted for obstruction of justice that was legally entitled to do what they did? Did it openly and notoriously on -- most of it on T.V., and was not guilty of any crime and was being wrongly investigated?

BARTIROMO: Yes. But you just said a second ago in terms of the U.S., officials paying foreigners.

CUMMINS: Right.

BARTIROMO: Explain what you just said to me during the -- during the hearing.

CUMMINS: Well, I mean, yes, he -- they're investigating these allegations of collusion, but they seem to have completely ignored the fact that the other party was paying foreign citizens to create false information, which was knowingly injected, became the predicate for all of this, $40 million two years and who's holding them accountable?

BARTIROMO: You know what that sounds like? That sounds like collusion and obstruction, Bud.

CUMMINS: For real.

BARTIROMO: That's what it sounds like. All right. Let's quickly -- let me get to Mark Penn real quick because, Mark, you were the Chief Strategy Officer of Microsoft when Microsoft was being investigated. You worked with them through that case. Your reaction today to A.G. Barr starting this new antitrust investigation into the tech giants.

PENN: Yes. No, I was Chief Strategy Officer later, but worked with them through the case and remember, that was a tie-in case whether or not they were leveraging their market power in Windows to sell the -- to get people to use their browser. Remember, Facebook has Instagram. Google has Search, but they also have YouTube. So those same questions are going to come up whether they're using their market power to sell or launch and create huge market share for these other products.

And second, there's an enormous market power that they have in advertising so when the judge says there's no consumer harm, people are going to look at whether or not the advertising rates here are basically being set by an oligopoly and, therefore, may be costing consumers or not. So, there's a lot of big issues here that I think the DOJ could look at. And we'll find out, you know, how smart they are when they begin to open this onion.

BARTIROMO: Great insights from you on both subjects, Mark and Chris, as always, great to see you both, gentlemen. Thank you.

BEDFORD: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Christopher Bedford, Mark Penn, joining us there. Meanwhile, there's Boeing, earnings in focus this morning. The company reporting a massive loss, much worse than expected. Deirdre Bolton on the floor of the New York Stock Exchange --

DEIRDRE BOLTON, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Yes.

BARTIROMO: -- with those details. Deirdre.

BOLTON: Maria, this is sending the stock down premarket, $5.82 a share is what Boeing lost on an adjusted basis, so we knew this company obviously is having so many problems with that 737 Max model being grounded. As we recall, there were two deadly crashes within five months of one another. The company forced to ground the plane. If you want to look for a bright side, it's hard to find, but I can tell you the defense and the services unit did post -- basically posting profit.

So, a lot of analysts' saying, OK, once they get this 737 Max issues behind them, the company does have strengths -- pockets of strength in other areas. I'd be remiss if I didn't talk about Caterpillar as well, these two Dow Components obviously going to drive trade. Caterpillar missing heavily actually on the earnings. $2.83 a share is what they posted. Consensus was $3.12 a share. Ever so slight a miss on revenue, but a miss all the same when you can see essentially the red on your screens premarket for both of these Dow members.

Of course, so many of us in the community looking forward to after the bell, Ford, Tesla, Facebook, of course, also going to be posting earnings this afternoon. But I have to tell you, Maria, everyone here, every single T.V. is on this Mueller statement. In the meantime, back to you.

BARTIROMO: Isn't that interesting that all the T.V.s --

BOLTON: Yes.

BARTIROMO: -- are on the Mueller testimony? Thank you so much. Deirdre Bolton. We'll check in. Markets are down 102 points of the Dow Jones Industrial Average this morning. We're going into the open, Mike, with the lows of the morning right here.

MURPHY: We are right near all-time highs in the stock market.

BARTIROMO: True. True.

MURPHY: I'm looking past the Boeing and Caterpillar earnings, I'm looking forward to the Facebook earnings today after the close, but, really, this government investigation into big tech is -- can turn into a really big story because if they -- if they continue this, and these large growth companies that have led the market start to see selling coming into them, where does that money go? Does it rotate into other techs? Is it the newer techs, recent IPOs like the Ubers, the Lyfts, or is it companies that have been through this already like a Microsoft, does this benefit? Money won't leave the market, it will rotate but I think there's an opportunity for investors to watch that.

BARTIROMO: We'll see.

MURPHY: Yes.

BARTIROMO: We'll see if they go into manufacturing or the banks. Banks have had a pretty good run. Final thoughts? Bud Cummins, great to have you.

CUMMINS: I think -- I think Mueller's already confirmed what we suspected. There's going to be no new information today and the skilled interrogators like John Ratcliffe won't have a chance in this format to really get anything out of him.

BARTIROMO: Well, that will be a shame. Great show, you guys. Dagen, Mike, Bud, good to see you.

MURPHY: Thank you.

BARTIROMO: Have a great day, everybody. "VARNEY & CO." begins right now. Stuart, take it away.

STUART VARNEY, FOX BUSINESS NETWORK ANCHOR: Good morning -- good morning, Maria.

urn:contentItem:5BWD-KW81-F15W-H00J-00000-00ROBERT NARDELLI, FORMER CHAIRMAN AND CEO, CHRYSLER, IS INTERVIEWED ON BLOOMBERG TV REGARDING GM2014-04-01T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:22:12ZLexisNexisROBERT NARDELLI, FORMER CHAIRMAN AND CEO, CHRYSLER, IS INTERVIEWED ON BLOOMBERG TV REGARDING GM

April 1, 2014

NEWS PROGRAM

ROBERT NARDELLI, FORMER CHAIRMAN AND CEO, CHRYSLER,

BETTY LIU, HOST, BLOOMBERG NEWS: That's a great segue into Bob Nardelli, who is the former chairman and CEO of Chrysler. And Bob, by the way, you - you've been in this seat four times --

ROBERT NARDELLI, FORMER CHAIRMAN AND CEO, CHRYSLER: Yes, I have. I have.

LIU: - on the Hill.

NARDELLI: I have. And I think Matt poses probably one of the most challenging questions that Mary will face today. You've been there over 30 years. Is it possible that this never reached your level?

LIU: Is it possible?

NARDELLI: Setting that aside though, I - I agree with Matt. I think Mary's doing a great job. And it's unfortunate that as she's trying to get her arms around the CEO job that this now will totally consume her. I can tell you preparing for four of these, you are head down, locked up in a room trying to recall and recant everything that's happened during that period. So it certainly takes her off track relative to running the company to get ready for this grilling that will go on today.

LIU: Well how do you prepare, Bob, for something like this?

NARDELLI: Well, for me when I was at Chrysler and GM, when we were going through this hearings, it really was heads down, in a conference room with a dozen or so 4 or 5-inch binders going through every document, every email, everything that was turned over to the congressional committees so that you knew you were going to get grilled. They have armies of people going through here looking for questions to try and trip you up. Certainly - and I think will Mary will prepare appropriately for this.

LIU: Well, getting back though to that - that key question which I'm sure she's going to be asked over and over again is how did you not know, and if you knew, why didn't you do anything about it.

NARDELLI: Yeah. Again, I don't want to - it's hard for me to predict how that answer will come out. It's - there are situations where things are kept at the very lowest level to avoid disclosure and what have you. I'm not saying that's the case here, but it's possible in an organization of that site that something like this maybe didn't elevate itself to the CEO, which would be unfortunate.

I think Mary's taken a very positive forward step here in creating the vice president's office for safety. She's met with the families. She's been very forthcoming. She's been very open. You look at the number of documents that have been turned over. I think this is a critical moment for a new CEO, particularly Mary, to do what she's doing. So she - she certainly has broke with tradition, as Matt said, how maybe prior CEOs of various companies would have handled it. So I give her a lot of credit for stepping out.

LIU: She certainly broke with tradition also with the way how GM has traditionally been run and - and again, as you say, with this whole reorganization that she's going through right now as the CEO. One of the questions we - we were thinking about as we were preparing for the story is what exactly goes into a recall, Bob? You were - you did not oversee any recalls when you were at Chrysler, but - but what happens at a car company? What are the steps that take place until a car company decides, we've got to call these vehicles back?

NARDELLI: Yeah. One of the things we did when we acquired Chrysler from - from Daimler was we installed a very senior person that has a very successful track record. We were able to recruit him away from Nissan. And we put him in place and we started weekly quality tables. We would go through our tech center. We would find those things that were causing quality problems, performance problems. Obviously if anything would endanger life, then that was escalated.

So we made it a very important part of our culture. We did about 400 improvements in the first 90 days relative to quality and performance improvements. And I think you just have to instill in the DNA, the culture of the company that market focused, customer centric is critical, particularly if it's endangering lives of your customers.

LIU: Of course. And at what point do you - as a car company, at what point do you say, you know what? We have to actually issue - issue a notice, right, to our - to our consumers? That's a big decision and it's certainly not one that sheds any positive light on the company. So it's got - there's got to be a lot of thinking obviously behind that.

NARDELLI: I hope today isn't a case of he said, she said and between General Motors and the National Transportation Safety Board. There ought to be - there ought to be some cooperative tension between those two organizations, not combative. It ought not to be --

LIU: But is there a notice given to NTSB first?

NARDELLI: Yeah. There is a requirement that you have to notify them if you start to see fatalities or injuries of that kind. If it's a performance problem it's probably not as critical to get them involved. But obviously if it gets to the point where there are --

LIU: If we're talking seat belts or airbags or anything like that. OK.

NARDELLI: Exactly, exactly. Then you're required to notify them and then you want to work in a harmonious way with them, not in a combative way. And I hope this congressional hearing doesn't create that unnecessary tension and we don't get over regulated now. The pendulum tends to swing, as you know, when something like this happens.

LIU: It does.

NARDELI: Hopefully we can be constructive. Each of the committees will be - do their diligence and not trying to catch anything in their - in their depositions.

LIU: Well what about the relationship now between General Motors and the dealerships who now have to handle these recalls and who I'm assuming not happy with the fact that these recalls keep happening and their customers are angry with them?

NARDELLI: But again, I think Mary has really done a great job for the dealership relative to not creating angst against the brands.

LIU: Because you've got to take care of the dealerships, right?

NARDELLI: You must take care of the dealerships. And they're going to have to handle this plethora of recalls. I think it's important to say regardless of how aggressive and forward positioned she is with GM, chances are there's going to be another one. There are millions of cars in the system today. And let's be careful to say we will never have another recall because that is really going to be --

LIU: It's difficult to make that promise.

NARDELLI: When you think of the thousands parts and the tier one, tier two, tier suppliers and what goes into assembling a car, it is a huge challenge to make sure everything comes together appropriately.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

LIU: I want to bring back Bob Nardelli, the former chairman and CEO of Chrysler. Bob, you know this issue inside and out.

NARDELLI: Very cool.

LIU: What do you think about what Elon Musk is trying to do?

NARDELLI: Well on one - in one regard I think he's brilliant. And again, I've --

LIU: Brilliant for fighting the auto dealers or brilliant for -

NARDELLI: Well brilliant in his approach. If you think about it, a good friend of mine in Arizona traveled to California.

LIU: They banned Teslas.

NARDELLI: They banned it so he couldn't buy it in Arizona. He goes to California, puts his modest $40,000 down payment to hold a slot. Goes back to Arizona. The car is then delivered to him on a flatbed. A technician spends an hour with him going through how to operate it. Fast forward a few months later. Technician calls and says your 12-volt battery is not functioning appropriately. We'll be there to change it.

So if you think about the era of big data, certainly Tesla, market focused, customer centric in what they're trying to do to penetrate state by state.

LIU: So it's almost like they've built a customer for life given that kind of service. Hey, that's very tailored here. You can only dream of that with - with a - with a GM car or Toyota car.

NARDELLI: Yeah. And you think about - Betty, if you think about the business models we have here, certainly Jack Nasser tried this with Ford if you remember in the '90s.

LIU: The direct sales, right.

NARDELLI: The direct sales. Why? Because in manufacturing as an OE, you're looking for volume to absorb your fixed overhead, right? We all as - as manufacturers would love to have the margin that you get out of parts and service and used cars. So there was always that little bit of tension to the dealer network. Certainly if you think about the dealers and their franchise agreements state by state, they are - they have tremendous legacy. They are very highly regarded in the states. It's going to be very tough. So I think --

LIU: They're very powerful.

NARDELLI: Very powerful. But I think the dealers are approaching this appropriately. Let's not have a massive fight and maybe lose everything. Let's compromise and see what we can get done. And don't forget, for example, Ohio just accepted. So Elon has --

LIU: Limited, but yes.

NARDELLI: Limited - has a big trump card, right? I'm going to build a battery plant somewhere and I'm going to do it in a friendly state. But if you look - last night we were talking. There's a study out that showed state by state where he's approved relative to limited show rooms. Some as long as within the MSA no one else is doing it. If you think about Carlos Ghosn at Nissan with the Leaf, he could have taken that approach. But if you look at --

LIU: Why didn't he?

NARDELLI: Well, I think he looked at the business model for him and said, I've got all these dealers. I don't have to recreate a service organization. I don't have to spend a lot of capital on tools and facilities and brick and mortar. And - and I will benefit my dealers because I'll draw more traffic into my dealership. So that was the business model he elected as opposed to a startup.

LIU: Bob, but - but - but this only works though for Elon Musk and Tesla because they only sell less than 30,000 cars. If you're trying to sell 300,000 cars, you can't do that by yourself.

NARDELLI: The question will be if he grows to 300,000 cars, can he - can his margin cover the infrastructure that he's going to have to create to do the personal service that he's demonstrated? If he can, then he's got a very successful model. The key will be does he have enough margin in the auto to be able to cover those forward costs.

LIU: But do the automakers - when you were at Chrysler, did you want to sell directly to customers? Is that something that - that actually automakers eventually would like? They're just beholden to this dealership network.

NARDELLI: I think we all think about that. If you - if you look at what Fiat did, I'm sure Sergio would like to have had a separate dealership or a separate way to go to market on the (inaudible) the 500. What the compromise was, was the dealer had to spend X millions of dollars to create a studio within the current dealership.

So there's always that thought about we could take care of the customers better. The dealers though have done a remarkable job. I always try to have a great working relationship with those dealers. They are in place. They've invested a lot of capital. They've got tremendous loyalty within the communities. Softball team, political relationships. So it's - it's pretty embedded, Betty.

LIU: But on a personal front though, most people don't like going to dealerships and buying cars. Maybe on the high end it's a pleasant experience, but for most people it's a terrible experience and they feel like they're being bilked out of lots of dollars. Is there something more that should be done with regulating the dealer?

NARDELLI: Well there's been many attempts, right? The one price, the national price, the no haggling thing. And maybe Tesla's got it right that it's going to take something as dramatic and revolutionary as what he's trying to do to try to get a compromise. I don't think it's either or. I think in today's digital world you want to have optionality to buy the car the way you want to buy the car.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

LIU: I want to bring back my guest host for the hour, Bob Nardelli, the former CEO, as we mentioned, of Chrysler and Home Depot. Bob, what's your biggest question just as a private citizen around this healthcare exchange?

NARDELLI: Well I think - I think a couple of important points. Number one, if you ever wanted to learn how not to introduce a program, this is certainly a role model.

LIU: This is certainly the case.

NARDELLI: We were talking upstairs about General Motors. Could you imagine if this was a new platform with this many problems to launch a new car here? So lessons learned here. Program management, oversight, et cetera. Point number one.

Point number two. There were two very important words used in your exchange. One was visits. The other was enrollment. And having at Home Depot tremendous experience in online sales, we used to track visits, which was important, but most important were orders placed when you put down your hard-earned dollars for a product. So there's a big gap.

LIU: So you're skeptical of these numbers as well that the - that the government - that the White House is putting out?

NARDELLI: Depends on what word you're going to use. The visits may be right, but enrollment, if you mean paid, would be another perspective. And as just a common guy, I've gone through this myself with my family.

LIU: You're not a common guy, Bob?

NARDELLI: I'm very - I'm just --

LIU: You're no average Joe, but I get it.

NARDELLI: - Bob - Bob citizen. And I could tell you it was a harrowing experience to get insurance.

LIU: Have you tried to sign on - wait. So you tried to sign on to the exchange or your relatives did?

NARDELLI: Well, so we went through - first of all, we were terminated by - my - my - two of my children were terminated because the insurance company decided not to carry insurance on California. Then we went with the local provider, 30 percent increase first, another 30 percent increase. Then we were notified, two of my children, that they were canceled because the policies that they had didn't meet with the Affordable Care Act government requirements. So then we went back out in trying to find carriers that would --

LIU: That complied.

NARDELLI: - that would comply. So directionally, we went from like $160 a month to $600 a month per child with $5,000 deductible. And I can't tell you how many hours we spent trying to secure this.

LIU: You were shopping around (inaudible) insurance.

NARDELLI: If you like your doctors - they wanted to keep their doctors. And to do that, that's what we had to go through.

LIU: So this is - so this experience that you're talking about is exactly why the Republicans are making it a - a focal point of their - of their campaigns come election season, right? Tom Cotton, for instance, who's a Republican congressman in Arkansas, and let's pull up his website, has - when you go to this website - he's running for Senate now?

NARDELLI: Yes.

LIU: When you go to this website, he says Obamacare is so bad that Obama doesn't want it. And he - he's playing on - on - on essentially the anger among - that he believes voters have against - against Obamacare. Do you think that that is the right strategy? Are there enough Americans who are angry about this?

NARDELLI: Well let me say this. This is that old phrase politics over policy. I don't think anyone argues with trying to make sure affordable healthcare is available for all US citizens. I think that's an important thing and directionally right. I think it's the implementation. I think it's some of the controversy on how it's happened. I think some of the changing the goal posts as we went along to make sure. I just think there were a number of issues in the implementation that probably could have been better thought out.

LIU: But how else could it have been done though, Bob?

NARDELLI: I think certainly - certainly more on a bipartisan basis where we got more people in the room, more than just software developers, that we actually brought people in from the business community. What's the impact? How have you implemented major software changes relative to Ernst & Young does this, S&P does this, and really got more insight on people that have been through this relative to the magnitude of the challenge that has taken place here.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

LIU: I want to talk more about management because your former boss Jack Welch, who I know you have a very long history with, he actually just wrote this piece that we highlighted yesterday on LinkedIn where he spoke more about management and how to cultivate talent. And he said one of the things he believes companies not - they don't do enough of is they don't pay attention enough to their HR offices. And he was arguing for elevating the HR officer, for instance, to as high a level as a CFO, to be on the senior management team. You agree with this?

NARDELLI: Yeah, absolutely. First of all, Jack's a dear friend. He's been a great mentor to me. And obviously I can't thank him enough for the lessons I've learned working for him and being around him.

LIU: People look to him for management advice.

NARDELLI: Yes, always. He is the guru. So I totally agree with that position. As a matter of fact, when I went to Home Depot one of the first things I did was bring in probably one of the strongest HR chief human resources and we started to put process into place.

You've got human capital and you got physical capital. A lot of times you'll spend an inordinate amount of analysis on - on the physical capital, and yet it is your human capital that brings that to leaf (ph). So I think the chief human resource officer needs to have an equal share at your staff's roundtable.

LIU: Which they often don't.

NARDELLI: Which they don't. They're kind of second tier, back room. But there's nothing more important than talent. If you look at the history of GE and the ability to continue to have extremely strong talent on the bench, as talent left talent replaced it. So I think it's very important.

LIU: Well speaking about talent, there's so much fight for talent, right, on the West Coast. And there's a great story about how the chamber of commerce decided, hello, they're going to put an office now on the West Coast, that they're going to start transferring some of their resources there. And I imagine this is all also in - in time with the issues of the day, right? Immigration now for Silicon Valley companies, taxes, the privacy issue. And I'm assuming the chamber of commerce feels like, hey, there's a need now for our services.

NARDELLI: Yeah. I - I think it's an excellent decision by Tom and the chamber. You have to be immersed in the markets and in the environments of the issues so you have a sensitivity and an understanding. Now Tom doesn't have a glass jaw, so as he moves to the West Coast he's going to need all - and muster all -

LIU: I was going to say, yeah. Because some of their - you've had companies like I believe Yahoo did not renew their membership in the chamber and a couple of other big tech companies because they don't agree with some of the policies by the chamber, the environmental - environmental stance for instance by them. Are they - I'm not expecting a big red carpet rolled out for them.

NARDELLI: No, I wouldn't. I'm sure they'll move into a facility with high security. But Tom - I think Tom's doing the right thing. I think he's balanced. He's thoughtful in his positions in representing the chamber. He works both sides of the aisle. I think it's important.

I think that some of these larger corporations that have elected not to participate will rethink that decision because you'd rather be at the table than not at the table. We talked about in the last segment on the Affordable Care Act. So hopefully by them moving out there they're demonstrating their willingness to engage, listen, learn before you lead.

LIU: All right. Bob, it's been great to have you here this hour.

NARDELLI: Thank you. It's been great, Betty. Thank you.

LIU: Bob Nardelli, the former chairman and CEO of Chrysler and Home Depot.

Robert Nardelli is Interviewed on Bloomberg TV Regarding the Automotive Industry

ROBERT NARDELLI, FORMER CHAIRMAN AND CEO, CHRYSLER, IS INTERVIEWED ON BLOOMBERG TV REGARDING THE AUTOMOTIVE INDUSTRY

APRIL 1, 2014

SPEAKERS: ROBERT NARDELLI, FORMER CHAIRMAN AND CEO, CHRYSLER

BETTY LIU, HOST, BLOOMBERG NEWS

(This is not a legal transcript. Bloomberg LP cannot guarantee its accuracy.)

BETTY LIU, HOST, BLOOMBERG NEWS: That's a great segue into Bob Nardelli, who is the former chairman and CEO of Chrysler. And Bob, by the way, you - you've been in this seat four times --

ROBERT NARDELLI, FORMER CHAIRMAN AND CEO, CHRYSLER: Yes, I have. I have.

LIU: - on the Hill.

NARDELLI: I have. And I think Matt poses probably one of the most challenging questions that Mary will face today. You've been there over 30 years. Is it possible that this never reached your level?

LIU: Is it possible?

NARDELLI: Setting that aside though, I - I agree with Matt. I think Mary's doing a great job. And it's unfortunate that as she's trying to get her arms around the CEO job that this now will totally consume her. I can tell you preparing for four of these, you are head down, locked up in a room trying to recall and recant everything that's happened during that period. So it certainly takes her off track relative to running the company to get ready for this grilling that will go on today.

LIU: Well how do you prepare, Bob, for something like this?

NARDELLI: Well, for me when I was at Chrysler and GM, when we were going through this hearings, it really was heads down, in a conference room with a dozen or so 4 or 5-inch binders going through every document, every email, everything that was turned over to the congressional committees so that you knew you were going to get grilled. They have armies of people going through here looking for questions to try and trip you up. Certainly - and I think will Mary will prepare appropriately for this.

LIU: Well, getting back though to that - that key question which I'm sure she's going to be asked over and over again is how did you not know, and if you knew, why didn't you do anything about it.

NARDELLI: Yeah. Again, I don't want to - it's hard for me to predict how that answer will come out. It's - there are situations where things are kept at the very lowest level to avoid disclosure and what have you. I'm not saying that's the case here, but it's possible in an organization of that site that something like this maybe didn't elevate itself to the CEO, which would be unfortunate.

I think Mary's taken a very positive forward step here in creating the vice president's office for safety. She's met with the families. She's been very forthcoming. She's been very open. You look at the number of documents that have been turned over. I think this is a critical moment for a new CEO, particularly Mary, to do what she's doing. So she - she certainly has broke with tradition, as Matt said, how maybe prior CEOs of various companies would have handled it. So I give her a lot of credit for stepping out.

LIU: She certainly broke with tradition also with the way how GM has traditionally been run and - and again, as you say, with this whole reorganization that she's going through right now as the CEO. One of the questions we - we were thinking about as we were preparing for the story is what exactly goes into a recall, Bob? You were - you did not oversee any recalls when you were at Chrysler, but - but what happens at a car company? What are the steps that take place until a car company decides, we've got to call these vehicles back?

NARDELLI: Yeah. One of the things we did when we acquired Chrysler from - from Daimler was we installed a very senior person that has a very successful track record. We were able to recruit him away from Nissan. And we put him in place and we started weekly quality tables. We would go through our tech center. We would find those things that were causing quality problems, performance problems. Obviously if anything would endanger life, then that was escalated.

So we made it a very important part of our culture. We did about 400 improvements in the first 90 days relative to quality and performance improvements. And I think you just have to instill in the DNA, the culture of the company that market focused, customer centric is critical, particularly if it's endangering lives of your customers.

LIU: Of course. And at what point do you - as a car company, at what point do you say, you know what? We have to actually issue - issue a notice, right, to our - to our consumers? That's a big decision and it's certainly not one that sheds any positive light on the company. So it's got - there's got to be a lot of thinking obviously behind that.

NARDELLI: I hope today isn't a case of he said, she said and between General Motors and the National Transportation Safety Board. There ought to be - there ought to be some cooperative tension between those two organizations, not combative. It ought not to be --

LIU: But is there a notice given to NTSB first?

NARDELLI: Yeah. There is a requirement that you have to notify them if you start to see fatalities or injuries of that kind. If it's a performance problem it's probably not as critical to get them involved. But obviously if it gets to the point where there are --

LIU: If we're talking seat belts or airbags or anything like that. OK.

NARDELLI: Exactly, exactly. Then you're required to notify them and then you want to work in a harmonious way with them, not in a combative way. And I hope this congressional hearing doesn't create that unnecessary tension and we don't get over regulated now. The pendulum tends to swing, as you know, when something like this happens.

LIU: It does.

NARDELI: Hopefully we can be constructive. Each of the committees will be - do their diligence and not trying to catch anything in their - in their depositions.

LIU: Well what about the relationship now between General Motors and the dealerships who now have to handle these recalls and who I'm assuming not happy with the fact that these recalls keep happening and their customers are angry with them?

NARDELLI: But again, I think Mary has really done a great job for the dealership relative to not creating angst against the brands.

LIU: Because you've got to take care of the dealerships, right?

NARDELLI: You must take care of the dealerships. And they're going to have to handle this plethora of recalls. I think it's important to say regardless of how aggressive and forward positioned she is with GM, chances are there's going to be another one. There are millions of cars in the system today. And let's be careful to say we will never have another recall because that is really going to be --

LIU: It's difficult to make that promise.

NARDELLI: When you think of the thousands parts and the tier one, tier two, tier suppliers and what goes into assembling a car, it is a huge challenge to make sure everything comes together appropriately.

LIU: I want to bring back Bob Nardelli, the former chairman and CEO of Chrysler. Bob, you know this issue inside and out.

NARDELLI: Very cool.

LIU: What do you think about what Elon Musk is trying to do?

NARDELLI: Well on one - in one regard I think he's brilliant. And again, I've --

LIU: Brilliant for fighting the auto dealers or brilliant for -

NARDELLI: Well brilliant in his approach. If you think about it, a good friend of mine in Arizona traveled to California.

LIU: They banned Teslas.

NARDELLI: They banned it so he couldn't buy it in Arizona. He goes to California, puts his modest $40,000 down payment to hold a slot. Goes back to Arizona. The car is then delivered to him on a flatbed. A technician spends an hour with him going through how to operate it. Fast forward a few months later. Technician calls and says your 12-volt battery is not functioning appropriately. We'll be there to change it.

So if you think about the era of big data, certainly Tesla, market focused, customer centric in what they're trying to do to penetrate state by state.

LIU: So it's almost like they've built a customer for life given that kind of service. Hey, that's very tailored here. You can only dream of that with - with a - with a GM car or Toyota car.

NARDELLI: Yeah. And you think about - Betty, if you think about the business models we have here, certainly Jack Nasser tried this with Ford if you remember in the '90s.

LIU: The direct sales, right.

NARDELLI: The direct sales. Why? Because in manufacturing as an OE, you're looking for volume to absorb your fixed overhead, right? We all as - as manufacturers would love to have the margin that you get out of parts and service and used cars. So there was always that little bit of tension to the dealer network. Certainly if you think about the dealers and their franchise agreements state by state, they are - they have tremendous legacy. They are very highly regarded in the states. It's going to be very tough. So I think --

LIU: They're very powerful.

NARDELLI: Very powerful. But I think the dealers are approaching this appropriately. Let's not have a massive fight and maybe lose everything. Let's compromise and see what we can get done. And don't forget, for example, Ohio just accepted. So Elon has --

LIU: Limited, but yes.

NARDELLI: Limited - has a big trump card, right? I'm going to build a battery plant somewhere and I'm going to do it in a friendly state. But if you look - last night we were talking. There's a study out that showed state by state where he's approved relative to limited show rooms. Some as long as within the MSA no one else is doing it. If you think about Carlos Ghosn at Nissan with the Leaf, he could have taken that approach. But if you look at --

LIU: Why didn't he?

NARDELLI: Well, I think he looked at the business model for him and said, I've got all these dealers. I don't have to recreate a service organization. I don't have to spend a lot of capital on tools and facilities and brick and mortar. And - and I will benefit my dealers because I'll draw more traffic into my dealership. So that was the business model he elected as opposed to a startup.

LIU: Bob, but - but - but this only works though for Elon Musk and Tesla because they only sell less than 30,000 cars. If you're trying to sell 300,000 cars, you can't do that by yourself.

NARDELLI: The question will be if he grows to 300,000 cars, can he - can his margin cover the infrastructure that he's going to have to create to do the personal service that he's demonstrated? If he can, then he's got a very successful model. The key will be does he have enough margin in the auto to be able to cover those forward costs.

LIU: But do the automakers - when you were at Chrysler, did you want to sell directly to customers? Is that something that - that actually automakers eventually would like? They're just beholden to this dealership network.

NARDELLI: I think we all think about that. If you - if you look at what Fiat did, I'm sure Sergio would like to have had a separate dealership or a separate way to go to market on the (inaudible) the 500. What the compromise was, was the dealer had to spend X millions of dollars to create a studio within the current dealership.

So there's always that thought about we could take care of the customers better. The dealers though have done a remarkable job. I always try to have a great working relationship with those dealers. They are in place. They've invested a lot of capital. They've got tremendous loyalty within the communities. Softball team, political relationships. So it's - it's pretty embedded, Betty.

LIU: But on a personal front though, most people don't like going to dealerships and buying cars. Maybe on the high end it's a pleasant experience, but for most people it's a terrible experience and they feel like they're being bilked out of lots of dollars. Is there something more that should be done with regulating the dealer?

NARDELLI: Well there's been many attempts, right? The one price, the national price, the no haggling thing. And maybe Tesla's got it right that it's going to take something as dramatic and revolutionary as what he's trying to do to try to get a compromise. I don't think it's either or. I think in today's digital world you want to have optionality to buy the car the way you want to buy the car.

LIU: I want to bring back my guest host for the hour, Bob Nardelli, the former CEO, as we mentioned, of Chrysler and Home Depot. Bob, what's your biggest question just as a private citizen around this healthcare exchange?

NARDELLI: Well I think - I think a couple of important points. Number one, if you ever wanted to learn how not to introduce a program, this is certainly a role model.

LIU: This is certainly the case.

NARDELLI: We were talking upstairs about General Motors. Could you imagine if this was a new platform with this many problems to launch a new car here? So lessons learned here. Program management, oversight, et cetera. Point number one.

Point number two. There were two very important words used in your exchange. One was visits. The other was enrollment. And having at Home Depot tremendous experience in online sales, we used to track visits, which was important, but most important were orders placed when you put down your hard-earned dollars for a product. So there's a big gap.

LIU: So you're skeptical of these numbers as well that the - that the government - that the White House is putting out?

NARDELLI: Depends on what word you're going to use. The visits may be right, but enrollment, if you mean paid, would be another perspective. And as just a common guy, I've gone through this myself with my family.

LIU: You're not a common guy, Bob?

NARDELLI: I'm very - I'm just --

LIU: You're no average Joe, but I get it.

NARDELLI: - Bob - Bob citizen. And I could tell you it was a harrowing experience to get insurance.

LIU: Have you tried to sign on - wait. So you tried to sign on to the exchange or your relatives did?

NARDELLI: Well, so we went through - first of all, we were terminated by - my - my - two of my children were terminated because the insurance company decided not to carry insurance on California. Then we went with the local provider, 30 percent increase first, another 30 percent increase. Then we were notified, two of my children, that they were canceled because the policies that they had didn't meet with the Affordable Care Act government requirements. So then we went back out in trying to find carriers that would --

LIU: That complied.

NARDELLI: - that would comply. So directionally, we went from like $160 a month to $600 a month per child with $5,000 deductible. And I can't tell you how many hours we spent trying to secure this.

LIU: You were shopping around (inaudible) insurance.

NARDELLI: If you like your doctors - they wanted to keep their doctors. And to do that, that's what we had to go through.

LIU: So this is - so this experience that you're talking about is exactly why the Republicans are making it a - a focal point of their - of their campaigns come election season, right? Tom Cotton, for instance, who's a Republican congressman in Arkansas, and let's pull up his website, has - when you go to this website - he's running for Senate now?

NARDELLI: Yes.

LIU: When you go to this website, he says Obamacare is so bad that Obama doesn't want it. And he - he's playing on - on - on essentially the anger among - that he believes voters have against - against Obamacare. Do you think that that is the right strategy? Are there enough Americans who are angry about this?

NARDELLI: Well let me say this. This is that old phrase politics over policy. I don't think anyone argues with trying to make sure affordable healthcare is available for all US citizens. I think that's an important thing and directionally right. I think it's the implementation. I think it's some of the controversy on how it's happened. I think some of the changing the goal posts as we went along to make sure. I just think there were a number of issues in the implementation that probably could have been better thought out.

LIU: But how else could it have been done though, Bob?

NARDELLI: I think certainly - certainly more on a bipartisan basis where we got more people in the room, more than just software developers, that we actually brought people in from the business community. What's the impact? How have you implemented major software changes relative to Ernst & Young does this, S&P does this, and really got more insight on people that have been through this relative to the magnitude of the challenge that has taken place here.

LIU: I want to talk more about management because your former boss Jack Welch, who I know you have a very long history with, he actually just wrote this piece that we highlighted yesterday on LinkedIn where he spoke more about management and how to cultivate talent. And he said one of the things he believes companies not - they don't do enough of is they don't pay attention enough to their HR offices. And he was arguing for elevating the HR officer, for instance, to as high a level as a CFO, to be on the senior management team. You agree with this?

NARDELLI: Yeah, absolutely. First of all, Jack's a dear friend. He's been a great mentor to me. And obviously I can't thank him enough for the lessons I've learned working for him and being around him.

LIU: People look to him for management advice.

NARDELLI: Yes, always. He is the guru. So I totally agree with that position. As a matter of fact, when I went to Home Depot one of the first things I did was bring in probably one of the strongest HR chief human resources and we started to put process into place.

You've got human capital and you got physical capital. A lot of times you'll spend an inordinate amount of analysis on - on the physical capital, and yet it is your human capital that brings that to leaf (ph). So I think the chief human resource officer needs to have an equal share at your staff's roundtable.

LIU: Which they often don't.

NARDELLI: Which they don't. They're kind of second tier, back room. But there's nothing more important than talent. If you look at the history of GE and the ability to continue to have extremely strong talent on the bench, as talent left talent replaced it. So I think it's very important.

LIU: Well speaking about talent, there's so much fight for talent, right, on the West Coast. And there's a great story about how the chamber of commerce decided, hello, they're going to put an office now on the West Coast, that they're going to start transferring some of their resources there. And I imagine this is all also in - in time with the issues of the day, right? Immigration now for Silicon Valley companies, taxes, the privacy issue. And I'm assuming the chamber of commerce feels like, hey, there's a need now for our services.

NARDELLI: Yeah. I - I think it's an excellent decision by Tom and the chamber. You have to be immersed in the markets and in the environments of the issues so you have a sensitivity and an understanding. Now Tom doesn't have a glass jaw, so as he moves to the West Coast he's going to need all - and muster all -

LIU: I was going to say, yeah. Because some of their - you've had companies like I believe Yahoo did not renew their membership in the chamber and a couple of other big tech companies because they don't agree with some of the policies by the chamber, the environmental - environmental stance for instance by them. Are they - I'm not expecting a big red carpet rolled out for them.

NARDELLI: No, I wouldn't. I'm sure they'll move into a facility with high security. But Tom - I think Tom's doing the right thing. I think he's balanced. He's thoughtful in his positions in representing the chamber. He works both sides of the aisle. I think it's important.

I think that some of these larger corporations that have elected not to participate will rethink that decision because you'd rather be at the table than not at the table. We talked about in the last segment on the Affordable Care Act. So hopefully by them moving out there they're demonstrating their willingness to engage, listen, learn before you lead.

LIU: All right. Bob, it's been great to have you here this hour.

NARDELLI: Thank you. It's been great, Betty. Thank you.

LIU: Bob Nardelli, the former chairman and CEO of Chrysler and Home Depot.

***END OF TRANSCRIPT***
