ROBERT NARDELLI, FORMER CHAIRMAN AND CEO, CHRYSLER, IS INTERVIEWED ON BLOOMBERG TV REGARDING THE AUTOMOTIVE INDUSTRY

APRIL 1, 2014

SPEAKERS: ROBERT NARDELLI, FORMER CHAIRMAN AND CEO, CHRYSLER

BETTY LIU, HOST, BLOOMBERG NEWS

(This is not a legal transcript. Bloomberg LP cannot guarantee its accuracy.)

BETTY LIU, HOST, BLOOMBERG NEWS: That's a great segue into Bob Nardelli, who is the former chairman and CEO of Chrysler. And Bob, by the way, you - you've been in this seat four times --

ROBERT NARDELLI, FORMER CHAIRMAN AND CEO, CHRYSLER: Yes, I have. I have.

LIU: - on the Hill.

NARDELLI: I have. And I think Matt poses probably one of the most challenging questions that Mary will face today. You've been there over 30 years. Is it possible that this never reached your level?

LIU: Is it possible?

NARDELLI: Setting that aside though, I - I agree with Matt. I think Mary's doing a great job. And it's unfortunate that as she's trying to get her arms around the CEO job that this now will totally consume her. I can tell you preparing for four of these, you are head down, locked up in a room trying to recall and recant everything that's happened during that period. So it certainly takes her off track relative to running the company to get ready for this grilling that will go on today.

LIU: Well how do you prepare, Bob, for something like this?

NARDELLI: Well, for me when I was at Chrysler and GM, when we were going through this hearings, it really was heads down, in a conference room with a dozen or so 4 or 5-inch binders going through every document, every email, everything that was turned over to the congressional committees so that you knew you were going to get grilled. They have armies of people going through here looking for questions to try and trip you up. Certainly - and I think will Mary will prepare appropriately for this.

LIU: Well, getting back though to that - that key question which I'm sure she's going to be asked over and over again is how did you not know, and if you knew, why didn't you do anything about it.

NARDELLI: Yeah. Again, I don't want to - it's hard for me to predict how that answer will come out. It's - there are situations where things are kept at the very lowest level to avoid disclosure and what have you. I'm not saying that's the case here, but it's possible in an organization of that site that something like this maybe didn't elevate itself to the CEO, which would be unfortunate.

I think Mary's taken a very positive forward step here in creating the vice president's office for safety. She's met with the families. She's been very forthcoming. She's been very open. You look at the number of documents that have been turned over. I think this is a critical moment for a new CEO, particularly Mary, to do what she's doing. So she - she certainly has broke with tradition, as Matt said, how maybe prior CEOs of various companies would have handled it. So I give her a lot of credit for stepping out.

LIU: She certainly broke with tradition also with the way how GM has traditionally been run and - and again, as you say, with this whole reorganization that she's going through right now as the CEO. One of the questions we - we were thinking about as we were preparing for the story is what exactly goes into a recall, Bob? You were - you did not oversee any recalls when you were at Chrysler, but - but what happens at a car company? What are the steps that take place until a car company decides, we've got to call these vehicles back?

NARDELLI: Yeah. One of the things we did when we acquired Chrysler from - from Daimler was we installed a very senior person that has a very successful track record. We were able to recruit him away from Nissan. And we put him in place and we started weekly quality tables. We would go through our tech center. We would find those things that were causing quality problems, performance problems. Obviously if anything would endanger life, then that was escalated.

So we made it a very important part of our culture. We did about 400 improvements in the first 90 days relative to quality and performance improvements. And I think you just have to instill in the DNA, the culture of the company that market focused, customer centric is critical, particularly if it's endangering lives of your customers.

LIU: Of course. And at what point do you - as a car company, at what point do you say, you know what? We have to actually issue - issue a notice, right, to our - to our consumers? That's a big decision and it's certainly not one that sheds any positive light on the company. So it's got - there's got to be a lot of thinking obviously behind that.

NARDELLI: I hope today isn't a case of he said, she said and between General Motors and the National Transportation Safety Board. There ought to be - there ought to be some cooperative tension between those two organizations, not combative. It ought not to be --

LIU: But is there a notice given to NTSB first?

NARDELLI: Yeah. There is a requirement that you have to notify them if you start to see fatalities or injuries of that kind. If it's a performance problem it's probably not as critical to get them involved. But obviously if it gets to the point where there are --

LIU: If we're talking seat belts or airbags or anything like that. OK.

NARDELLI: Exactly, exactly. Then you're required to notify them and then you want to work in a harmonious way with them, not in a combative way. And I hope this congressional hearing doesn't create that unnecessary tension and we don't get over regulated now. The pendulum tends to swing, as you know, when something like this happens.

LIU: It does.

NARDELI: Hopefully we can be constructive. Each of the committees will be - do their diligence and not trying to catch anything in their - in their depositions.

LIU: Well what about the relationship now between General Motors and the dealerships who now have to handle these recalls and who I'm assuming not happy with the fact that these recalls keep happening and their customers are angry with them?

NARDELLI: But again, I think Mary has really done a great job for the dealership relative to not creating angst against the brands.

LIU: Because you've got to take care of the dealerships, right?

NARDELLI: You must take care of the dealerships. And they're going to have to handle this plethora of recalls. I think it's important to say regardless of how aggressive and forward positioned she is with GM, chances are there's going to be another one. There are millions of cars in the system today. And let's be careful to say we will never have another recall because that is really going to be --

LIU: It's difficult to make that promise.

NARDELLI: When you think of the thousands parts and the tier one, tier two, tier suppliers and what goes into assembling a car, it is a huge challenge to make sure everything comes together appropriately.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

LIU: I want to bring back Bob Nardelli, the former chairman and CEO of Chrysler. Bob, you know this issue inside and out.

NARDELLI: Very cool.

LIU: What do you think about what Elon Musk is trying to do?

NARDELLI: Well on one - in one regard I think he's brilliant. And again, I've --

LIU: Brilliant for fighting the auto dealers or brilliant for -

NARDELLI: Well brilliant in his approach. If you think about it, a good friend of mine in Arizona traveled to California.

LIU: They banned Teslas.

NARDELLI: They banned it so he couldn't buy it in Arizona. He goes to California, puts his modest $40,000 down payment to hold a slot. Goes back to Arizona. The car is then delivered to him on a flatbed. A technician spends an hour with him going through how to operate it. Fast forward a few months later. Technician calls and says your 12-volt battery is not functioning appropriately. We'll be there to change it.

So if you think about the era of big data, certainly Tesla, market focused, customer centric in what they're trying to do to penetrate state by state.

LIU: So it's almost like they've built a customer for life given that kind of service. Hey, that's very tailored here. You can only dream of that with - with a - with a GM car or Toyota car.

NARDELLI: Yeah. And you think about - Betty, if you think about the business models we have here, certainly Jack Nasser tried this with Ford if you remember in the '90s.

LIU: The direct sales, right.

NARDELLI: The direct sales. Why? Because in manufacturing as an OE, you're looking for volume to absorb your fixed overhead, right? We all as - as manufacturers would love to have the margin that you get out of parts and service and used cars. So there was always that little bit of tension to the dealer network. Certainly if you think about the dealers and their franchise agreements state by state, they are - they have tremendous legacy. They are very highly regarded in the states. It's going to be very tough. So I think --

LIU: They're very powerful.

NARDELLI: Very powerful. But I think the dealers are approaching this appropriately. Let's not have a massive fight and maybe lose everything. Let's compromise and see what we can get done. And don't forget, for example, Ohio just accepted. So Elon has --

LIU: Limited, but yes.

NARDELLI: Limited - has a big trump card, right? I'm going to build a battery plant somewhere and I'm going to do it in a friendly state. But if you look - last night we were talking. There's a study out that showed state by state where he's approved relative to limited show rooms. Some as long as within the MSA no one else is doing it. If you think about Carlos Ghosn at Nissan with the Leaf, he could have taken that approach. But if you look at --

LIU: Why didn't he?

NARDELLI: Well, I think he looked at the business model for him and said, I've got all these dealers. I don't have to recreate a service organization. I don't have to spend a lot of capital on tools and facilities and brick and mortar. And - and I will benefit my dealers because I'll draw more traffic into my dealership. So that was the business model he elected as opposed to a startup.

LIU: Bob, but - but - but this only works though for Elon Musk and Tesla because they only sell less than 30,000 cars. If you're trying to sell 300,000 cars, you can't do that by yourself.

NARDELLI: The question will be if he grows to 300,000 cars, can he - can his margin cover the infrastructure that he's going to have to create to do the personal service that he's demonstrated? If he can, then he's got a very successful model. The key will be does he have enough margin in the auto to be able to cover those forward costs.

LIU: But do the automakers - when you were at Chrysler, did you want to sell directly to customers? Is that something that - that actually automakers eventually would like? They're just beholden to this dealership network.

NARDELLI: I think we all think about that. If you - if you look at what Fiat did, I'm sure Sergio would like to have had a separate dealership or a separate way to go to market on the (inaudible) the 500. What the compromise was, was the dealer had to spend X millions of dollars to create a studio within the current dealership.

So there's always that thought about we could take care of the customers better. The dealers though have done a remarkable job. I always try to have a great working relationship with those dealers. They are in place. They've invested a lot of capital. They've got tremendous loyalty within the communities. Softball team, political relationships. So it's - it's pretty embedded, Betty.

LIU: But on a personal front though, most people don't like going to dealerships and buying cars. Maybe on the high end it's a pleasant experience, but for most people it's a terrible experience and they feel like they're being bilked out of lots of dollars. Is there something more that should be done with regulating the dealer?

NARDELLI: Well there's been many attempts, right? The one price, the national price, the no haggling thing. And maybe Tesla's got it right that it's going to take something as dramatic and revolutionary as what he's trying to do to try to get a compromise. I don't think it's either or. I think in today's digital world you want to have optionality to buy the car the way you want to buy the car.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

LIU: I want to bring back my guest host for the hour, Bob Nardelli, the former CEO, as we mentioned, of Chrysler and Home Depot. Bob, what's your biggest question just as a private citizen around this healthcare exchange?

NARDELLI: Well I think - I think a couple of important points. Number one, if you ever wanted to learn how not to introduce a program, this is certainly a role model.

LIU: This is certainly the case.

NARDELLI: We were talking upstairs about General Motors. Could you imagine if this was a new platform with this many problems to launch a new car here? So lessons learned here. Program management, oversight, et cetera. Point number one.

Point number two. There were two very important words used in your exchange. One was visits. The other was enrollment. And having at Home Depot tremendous experience in online sales, we used to track visits, which was important, but most important were orders placed when you put down your hard-earned dollars for a product. So there's a big gap.

LIU: So you're skeptical of these numbers as well that the - that the government - that the White House is putting out?

NARDELLI: Depends on what word you're going to use. The visits may be right, but enrollment, if you mean paid, would be another perspective. And as just a common guy, I've gone through this myself with my family.

LIU: You're not a common guy, Bob?

NARDELLI: I'm very - I'm just --

LIU: You're no average Joe, but I get it.

NARDELLI: - Bob - Bob citizen. And I could tell you it was a harrowing experience to get insurance.

LIU: Have you tried to sign on - wait. So you tried to sign on to the exchange or your relatives did?

NARDELLI: Well, so we went through - first of all, we were terminated by - my - my - two of my children were terminated because the insurance company decided not to carry insurance on California. Then we went with the local provider, 30 percent increase first, another 30 percent increase. Then we were notified, two of my children, that they were canceled because the policies that they had didn't meet with the Affordable Care Act government requirements. So then we went back out in trying to find carriers that would --

LIU: That complied.

NARDELLI: - that would comply. So directionally, we went from like $160 a month to $600 a month per child with $5,000 deductible. And I can't tell you how many hours we spent trying to secure this.

LIU: You were shopping around (inaudible) insurance.

NARDELLI: If you like your doctors - they wanted to keep their doctors. And to do that, that's what we had to go through.

LIU: So this is - so this experience that you're talking about is exactly why the Republicans are making it a - a focal point of their - of their campaigns come election season, right? Tom Cotton, for instance, who's a Republican congressman in Arkansas, and let's pull up his website, has - when you go to this website - he's running for Senate now?

NARDELLI: Yes.

LIU: When you go to this website, he says Obamacare is so bad that Obama doesn't want it. And he - he's playing on - on - on essentially the anger among - that he believes voters have against - against Obamacare. Do you think that that is the right strategy? Are there enough Americans who are angry about this?

NARDELLI: Well let me say this. This is that old phrase politics over policy. I don't think anyone argues with trying to make sure affordable healthcare is available for all US citizens. I think that's an important thing and directionally right. I think it's the implementation. I think it's some of the controversy on how it's happened. I think some of the changing the goal posts as we went along to make sure. I just think there were a number of issues in the implementation that probably could have been better thought out.

LIU: But how else could it have been done though, Bob?

NARDELLI: I think certainly - certainly more on a bipartisan basis where we got more people in the room, more than just software developers, that we actually brought people in from the business community. What's the impact? How have you implemented major software changes relative to Ernst & Young does this, S&P does this, and really got more insight on people that have been through this relative to the magnitude of the challenge that has taken place here.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

LIU: I want to talk more about management because your former boss Jack Welch, who I know you have a very long history with, he actually just wrote this piece that we highlighted yesterday on LinkedIn where he spoke more about management and how to cultivate talent. And he said one of the things he believes companies not - they don't do enough of is they don't pay attention enough to their HR offices. And he was arguing for elevating the HR officer, for instance, to as high a level as a CFO, to be on the senior management team. You agree with this?

NARDELLI: Yeah, absolutely. First of all, Jack's a dear friend. He's been a great mentor to me. And obviously I can't thank him enough for the lessons I've learned working for him and being around him.

LIU: People look to him for management advice.

NARDELLI: Yes, always. He is the guru. So I totally agree with that position. As a matter of fact, when I went to Home Depot one of the first things I did was bring in probably one of the strongest HR chief human resources and we started to put process into place.

You've got human capital and you got physical capital. A lot of times you'll spend an inordinate amount of analysis on - on the physical capital, and yet it is your human capital that brings that to leaf (ph). So I think the chief human resource officer needs to have an equal share at your staff's roundtable.

LIU: Which they often don't.

NARDELLI: Which they don't. They're kind of second tier, back room. But there's nothing more important than talent. If you look at the history of GE and the ability to continue to have extremely strong talent on the bench, as talent left talent replaced it. So I think it's very important.

LIU: Well speaking about talent, there's so much fight for talent, right, on the West Coast. And there's a great story about how the chamber of commerce decided, hello, they're going to put an office now on the West Coast, that they're going to start transferring some of their resources there. And I imagine this is all also in - in time with the issues of the day, right? Immigration now for Silicon Valley companies, taxes, the privacy issue. And I'm assuming the chamber of commerce feels like, hey, there's a need now for our services.

NARDELLI: Yeah. I - I think it's an excellent decision by Tom and the chamber. You have to be immersed in the markets and in the environments of the issues so you have a sensitivity and an understanding. Now Tom doesn't have a glass jaw, so as he moves to the West Coast he's going to need all - and muster all -

LIU: I was going to say, yeah. Because some of their - you've had companies like I believe Yahoo did not renew their membership in the chamber and a couple of other big tech companies because they don't agree with some of the policies by the chamber, the environmental - environmental stance for instance by them. Are they - I'm not expecting a big red carpet rolled out for them.

NARDELLI: No, I wouldn't. I'm sure they'll move into a facility with high security. But Tom - I think Tom's doing the right thing. I think he's balanced. He's thoughtful in his positions in representing the chamber. He works both sides of the aisle. I think it's important.

I think that some of these larger corporations that have elected not to participate will rethink that decision because you'd rather be at the table than not at the table. We talked about in the last segment on the Affordable Care Act. So hopefully by them moving out there they're demonstrating their willingness to engage, listen, learn before you lead.

LIU: All right. Bob, it's been great to have you here this hour.

NARDELLI: Thank you. It's been great, Betty. Thank you.

LIU: Bob Nardelli, the former chairman and CEO of Chrysler and Home Depot.

***END OF TRANSCRIPT***

ROBERT NARDELLI, FORMER CHAIRMAN AND CEO, CHRYSLER, IS INTERVIEWED ON BLOOMBERG TV REGARDING THE AUTOMOTIVE INDUSTRY

APRIL 1, 2014

SPEAKERS: ROBERT NARDELLI, FORMER CHAIRMAN AND CEO, CHRYSLER

BETTY LIU, HOST, BLOOMBERG NEWS

(This is not a legal transcript. Bloomberg LP cannot guarantee its accuracy.)

BETTY LIU, HOST, BLOOMBERG NEWS: That's a great segue into Bob Nardelli, who is the former chairman and CEO of Chrysler. And Bob, by the way, you - you've been in this seat four times --

ROBERT NARDELLI, FORMER CHAIRMAN AND CEO, CHRYSLER: Yes, I have. I have.

LIU: - on the Hill.

NARDELLI: I have. And I think Matt poses probably one of the most challenging questions that Mary will face today. You've been there over 30 years. Is it possible that this never reached your level?

LIU: Is it possible?

NARDELLI: Setting that aside though, I - I agree with Matt. I think Mary's doing a great job. And it's unfortunate that as she's trying to get her arms around the CEO job that this now will totally consume her. I can tell you preparing for four of these, you are head down, locked up in a room trying to recall and recant everything that's happened during that period. So it certainly takes her off track relative to running the company to get ready for this grilling that will go on today.

LIU: Well how do you prepare, Bob, for something like this?

NARDELLI: Well, for me when I was at Chrysler and GM, when we were going through this hearings, it really was heads down, in a conference room with a dozen or so 4 or 5-inch binders going through every document, every email, everything that was turned over to the congressional committees so that you knew you were going to get grilled. They have armies of people going through here looking for questions to try and trip you up. Certainly - and I think will Mary will prepare appropriately for this.

LIU: Well, getting back though to that - that key question which I'm sure she's going to be asked over and over again is how did you not know, and if you knew, why didn't you do anything about it.

NARDELLI: Yeah. Again, I don't want to - it's hard for me to predict how that answer will come out. It's - there are situations where things are kept at the very lowest level to avoid disclosure and what have you. I'm not saying that's the case here, but it's possible in an organization of that site that something like this maybe didn't elevate itself to the CEO, which would be unfortunate.

I think Mary's taken a very positive forward step here in creating the vice president's office for safety. She's met with the families. She's been very forthcoming. She's been very open. You look at the number of documents that have been turned over. I think this is a critical moment for a new CEO, particularly Mary, to do what she's doing. So she - she certainly has broke with tradition, as Matt said, how maybe prior CEOs of various companies would have handled it. So I give her a lot of credit for stepping out.

LIU: She certainly broke with tradition also with the way how GM has traditionally been run and - and again, as you say, with this whole reorganization that she's going through right now as the CEO. One of the questions we - we were thinking about as we were preparing for the story is what exactly goes into a recall, Bob? You were - you did not oversee any recalls when you were at Chrysler, but - but what happens at a car company? What are the steps that take place until a car company decides, we've got to call these vehicles back?

NARDELLI: Yeah. One of the things we did when we acquired Chrysler from - from Daimler was we installed a very senior person that has a very successful track record. We were able to recruit him away from Nissan. And we put him in place and we started weekly quality tables. We would go through our tech center. We would find those things that were causing quality problems, performance problems. Obviously if anything would endanger life, then that was escalated.

So we made it a very important part of our culture. We did about 400 improvements in the first 90 days relative to quality and performance improvements. And I think you just have to instill in the DNA, the culture of the company that market focused, customer centric is critical, particularly if it's endangering lives of your customers.

LIU: Of course. And at what point do you - as a car company, at what point do you say, you know what? We have to actually issue - issue a notice, right, to our - to our consumers? That's a big decision and it's certainly not one that sheds any positive light on the company. So it's got - there's got to be a lot of thinking obviously behind that.

NARDELLI: I hope today isn't a case of he said, she said and between General Motors and the National Transportation Safety Board. There ought to be - there ought to be some cooperative tension between those two organizations, not combative. It ought not to be --

LIU: But is there a notice given to NTSB first?

NARDELLI: Yeah. There is a requirement that you have to notify them if you start to see fatalities or injuries of that kind. If it's a performance problem it's probably not as critical to get them involved. But obviously if it gets to the point where there are --

LIU: If we're talking seat belts or airbags or anything like that. OK.

NARDELLI: Exactly, exactly. Then you're required to notify them and then you want to work in a harmonious way with them, not in a combative way. And I hope this congressional hearing doesn't create that unnecessary tension and we don't get over regulated now. The pendulum tends to swing, as you know, when something like this happens.

LIU: It does.

NARDELI: Hopefully we can be constructive. Each of the committees will be - do their diligence and not trying to catch anything in their - in their depositions.

LIU: Well what about the relationship now between General Motors and the dealerships who now have to handle these recalls and who I'm assuming not happy with the fact that these recalls keep happening and their customers are angry with them?

NARDELLI: But again, I think Mary has really done a great job for the dealership relative to not creating angst against the brands.

LIU: Because you've got to take care of the dealerships, right?

NARDELLI: You must take care of the dealerships. And they're going to have to handle this plethora of recalls. I think it's important to say regardless of how aggressive and forward positioned she is with GM, chances are there's going to be another one. There are millions of cars in the system today. And let's be careful to say we will never have another recall because that is really going to be --

LIU: It's difficult to make that promise.

NARDELLI: When you think of the thousands parts and the tier one, tier two, tier suppliers and what goes into assembling a car, it is a huge challenge to make sure everything comes together appropriately.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

LIU: I want to bring back Bob Nardelli, the former chairman and CEO of Chrysler. Bob, you know this issue inside and out.

NARDELLI: Very cool.

LIU: What do you think about what Elon Musk is trying to do?

NARDELLI: Well on one - in one regard I think he's brilliant. And again, I've --

LIU: Brilliant for fighting the auto dealers or brilliant for -

NARDELLI: Well brilliant in his approach. If you think about it, a good friend of mine in Arizona traveled to California.

LIU: They banned Teslas.

NARDELLI: They banned it so he couldn't buy it in Arizona. He goes to California, puts his modest $40,000 down payment to hold a slot. Goes back to Arizona. The car is then delivered to him on a flatbed. A technician spends an hour with him going through how to operate it. Fast forward a few months later. Technician calls and says your 12-volt battery is not functioning appropriately. We'll be there to change it.

So if you think about the era of big data, certainly Tesla, market focused, customer centric in what they're trying to do to penetrate state by state.

LIU: So it's almost like they've built a customer for life given that kind of service. Hey, that's very tailored here. You can only dream of that with - with a - with a GM car or Toyota car.

NARDELLI: Yeah. And you think about - Betty, if you think about the business models we have here, certainly Jack Nasser tried this with Ford if you remember in the '90s.

LIU: The direct sales, right.

NARDELLI: The direct sales. Why? Because in manufacturing as an OE, you're looking for volume to absorb your fixed overhead, right? We all as - as manufacturers would love to have the margin that you get out of parts and service and used cars. So there was always that little bit of tension to the dealer network. Certainly if you think about the dealers and their franchise agreements state by state, they are - they have tremendous legacy. They are very highly regarded in the states. It's going to be very tough. So I think --

LIU: They're very powerful.

NARDELLI: Very powerful. But I think the dealers are approaching this appropriately. Let's not have a massive fight and maybe lose everything. Let's compromise and see what we can get done. And don't forget, for example, Ohio just accepted. So Elon has --

LIU: Limited, but yes.

NARDELLI: Limited - has a big trump card, right? I'm going to build a battery plant somewhere and I'm going to do it in a friendly state. But if you look - last night we were talking. There's a study out that showed state by state where he's approved relative to limited show rooms. Some as long as within the MSA no one else is doing it. If you think about Carlos Ghosn at Nissan with the Leaf, he could have taken that approach. But if you look at --

LIU: Why didn't he?

NARDELLI: Well, I think he looked at the business model for him and said, I've got all these dealers. I don't have to recreate a service organization. I don't have to spend a lot of capital on tools and facilities and brick and mortar. And - and I will benefit my dealers because I'll draw more traffic into my dealership. So that was the business model he elected as opposed to a startup.

LIU: Bob, but - but - but this only works though for Elon Musk and Tesla because they only sell less than 30,000 cars. If you're trying to sell 300,000 cars, you can't do that by yourself.

NARDELLI: The question will be if he grows to 300,000 cars, can he - can his margin cover the infrastructure that he's going to have to create to do the personal service that he's demonstrated? If he can, then he's got a very successful model. The key will be does he have enough margin in the auto to be able to cover those forward costs.

LIU: But do the automakers - when you were at Chrysler, did you want to sell directly to customers? Is that something that - that actually automakers eventually would like? They're just beholden to this dealership network.

NARDELLI: I think we all think about that. If you - if you look at what Fiat did, I'm sure Sergio would like to have had a separate dealership or a separate way to go to market on the (inaudible) the 500. What the compromise was, was the dealer had to spend X millions of dollars to create a studio within the current dealership.

So there's always that thought about we could take care of the customers better. The dealers though have done a remarkable job. I always try to have a great working relationship with those dealers. They are in place. They've invested a lot of capital. They've got tremendous loyalty within the communities. Softball team, political relationships. So it's - it's pretty embedded, Betty.

LIU: But on a personal front though, most people don't like going to dealerships and buying cars. Maybe on the high end it's a pleasant experience, but for most people it's a terrible experience and they feel like they're being bilked out of lots of dollars. Is there something more that should be done with regulating the dealer?

NARDELLI: Well there's been many attempts, right? The one price, the national price, the no haggling thing. And maybe Tesla's got it right that it's going to take something as dramatic and revolutionary as what he's trying to do to try to get a compromise. I don't think it's either or. I think in today's digital world you want to have optionality to buy the car the way you want to buy the car.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

LIU: I want to bring back my guest host for the hour, Bob Nardelli, the former CEO, as we mentioned, of Chrysler and Home Depot. Bob, what's your biggest question just as a private citizen around this healthcare exchange?

NARDELLI: Well I think - I think a couple of important points. Number one, if you ever wanted to learn how not to introduce a program, this is certainly a role model.

LIU: This is certainly the case.

NARDELLI: We were talking upstairs about General Motors. Could you imagine if this was a new platform with this many problems to launch a new car here? So lessons learned here. Program management, oversight, et cetera. Point number one.

Point number two. There were two very important words used in your exchange. One was visits. The other was enrollment. And having at Home Depot tremendous experience in online sales, we used to track visits, which was important, but most important were orders placed when you put down your hard-earned dollars for a product. So there's a big gap.

LIU: So you're skeptical of these numbers as well that the - that the government - that the White House is putting out?

NARDELLI: Depends on what word you're going to use. The visits may be right, but enrollment, if you mean paid, would be another perspective. And as just a common guy, I've gone through this myself with my family.

LIU: You're not a common guy, Bob?

NARDELLI: I'm very - I'm just --

LIU: You're no average Joe, but I get it.

NARDELLI: - Bob - Bob citizen. And I could tell you it was a harrowing experience to get insurance.

LIU: Have you tried to sign on - wait. So you tried to sign on to the exchange or your relatives did?

NARDELLI: Well, so we went through - first of all, we were terminated by - my - my - two of my children were terminated because the insurance company decided not to carry insurance on California. Then we went with the local provider, 30 percent increase first, another 30 percent increase. Then we were notified, two of my children, that they were canceled because the policies that they had didn't meet with the Affordable Care Act government requirements. So then we went back out in trying to find carriers that would --

LIU: That complied.

NARDELLI: - that would comply. So directionally, we went from like $160 a month to $600 a month per child with $5,000 deductible. And I can't tell you how many hours we spent trying to secure this.

LIU: You were shopping around (inaudible) insurance.

NARDELLI: If you like your doctors - they wanted to keep their doctors. And to do that, that's what we had to go through.

LIU: So this is - so this experience that you're talking about is exactly why the Republicans are making it a - a focal point of their - of their campaigns come election season, right? Tom Cotton, for instance, who's a Republican congressman in Arkansas, and let's pull up his website, has - when you go to this website - he's running for Senate now?

NARDELLI: Yes.

LIU: When you go to this website, he says Obamacare is so bad that Obama doesn't want it. And he - he's playing on - on - on essentially the anger among - that he believes voters have against - against Obamacare. Do you think that that is the right strategy? Are there enough Americans who are angry about this?

NARDELLI: Well let me say this. This is that old phrase politics over policy. I don't think anyone argues with trying to make sure affordable healthcare is available for all US citizens. I think that's an important thing and directionally right. I think it's the implementation. I think it's some of the controversy on how it's happened. I think some of the changing the goal posts as we went along to make sure. I just think there were a number of issues in the implementation that probably could have been better thought out.

LIU: But how else could it have been done though, Bob?

NARDELLI: I think certainly - certainly more on a bipartisan basis where we got more people in the room, more than just software developers, that we actually brought people in from the business community. What's the impact? How have you implemented major software changes relative to Ernst & Young does this, S&P does this, and really got more insight on people that have been through this relative to the magnitude of the challenge that has taken place here.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

LIU: I want to talk more about management because your former boss Jack Welch, who I know you have a very long history with, he actually just wrote this piece that we highlighted yesterday on LinkedIn where he spoke more about management and how to cultivate talent. And he said one of the things he believes companies not - they don't do enough of is they don't pay attention enough to their HR offices. And he was arguing for elevating the HR officer, for instance, to as high a level as a CFO, to be on the senior management team. You agree with this?

NARDELLI: Yeah, absolutely. First of all, Jack's a dear friend. He's been a great mentor to me. And obviously I can't thank him enough for the lessons I've learned working for him and being around him.

LIU: People look to him for management advice.

NARDELLI: Yes, always. He is the guru. So I totally agree with that position. As a matter of fact, when I went to Home Depot one of the first things I did was bring in probably one of the strongest HR chief human resources and we started to put process into place.

You've got human capital and you got physical capital. A lot of times you'll spend an inordinate amount of analysis on - on the physical capital, and yet it is your human capital that brings that to leaf (ph). So I think the chief human resource officer needs to have an equal share at your staff's roundtable.

LIU: Which they often don't.

NARDELLI: Which they don't. They're kind of second tier, back room. But there's nothing more important than talent. If you look at the history of GE and the ability to continue to have extremely strong talent on the bench, as talent left talent replaced it. So I think it's very important.

LIU: Well speaking about talent, there's so much fight for talent, right, on the West Coast. And there's a great story about how the chamber of commerce decided, hello, they're going to put an office now on the West Coast, that they're going to start transferring some of their resources there. And I imagine this is all also in - in time with the issues of the day, right? Immigration now for Silicon Valley companies, taxes, the privacy issue. And I'm assuming the chamber of commerce feels like, hey, there's a need now for our services.

NARDELLI: Yeah. I - I think it's an excellent decision by Tom and the chamber. You have to be immersed in the markets and in the environments of the issues so you have a sensitivity and an understanding. Now Tom doesn't have a glass jaw, so as he moves to the West Coast he's going to need all - and muster all -

LIU: I was going to say, yeah. Because some of their - you've had companies like I believe Yahoo did not renew their membership in the chamber and a couple of other big tech companies because they don't agree with some of the policies by the chamber, the environmental - environmental stance for instance by them. Are they - I'm not expecting a big red carpet rolled out for them.

NARDELLI: No, I wouldn't. I'm sure they'll move into a facility with high security. But Tom - I think Tom's doing the right thing. I think he's balanced. He's thoughtful in his positions in representing the chamber. He works both sides of the aisle. I think it's important.

I think that some of these larger corporations that have elected not to participate will rethink that decision because you'd rather be at the table than not at the table. We talked about in the last segment on the Affordable Care Act. So hopefully by them moving out there they're demonstrating their willingness to engage, listen, learn before you lead.

LIU: All right. Bob, it's been great to have you here this hour.

NARDELLI: Thank you. It's been great, Betty. Thank you.

LIU: Bob Nardelli, the former chairman and CEO of Chrysler and Home Depot.

***END OF TRANSCRIPT***

urn:contentItem:5BWD-KV71-DXH2-6547-00000-00Robert Nardelli is Interviewed on Bloomberg TV2014-04-01T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:22:12ZLexisNexisBLOOMBERG TV12:00 AM ESTRobert NardelliNEWSDomestic040188cb.550Robert Nardelli is Interviewed on Bloomberg TVBetty Liu

Robert Nardelli is Interviewed on Bloomberg TV Regarding the Automotive Industry

ROBERT NARDELLI, FORMER CHAIRMAN AND CEO, CHRYSLER, IS INTERVIEWED ON BLOOMBERG TV REGARDING THE AUTOMOTIVE INDUSTRY

APRIL 1, 2014

SPEAKERS: ROBERT NARDELLI, FORMER CHAIRMAN AND CEO, CHRYSLER

BETTY LIU, HOST, BLOOMBERG NEWS

(This is not a legal transcript. Bloomberg LP cannot guarantee its accuracy.)

BETTY LIU, HOST, BLOOMBERG NEWS: That's a great segue into Bob Nardelli, who is the former chairman and CEO of Chrysler. And Bob, by the way, you - you've been in this seat four times --

ROBERT NARDELLI, FORMER CHAIRMAN AND CEO, CHRYSLER: Yes, I have. I have.

LIU: - on the Hill.

NARDELLI: I have. And I think Matt poses probably one of the most challenging questions that Mary will face today. You've been there over 30 years. Is it possible that this never reached your level?

LIU: Is it possible?

NARDELLI: Setting that aside though, I - I agree with Matt. I think Mary's doing a great job. And it's unfortunate that as she's trying to get her arms around the CEO job that this now will totally consume her. I can tell you preparing for four of these, you are head down, locked up in a room trying to recall and recant everything that's happened during that period. So it certainly takes her off track relative to running the company to get ready for this grilling that will go on today.

LIU: Well how do you prepare, Bob, for something like this?

NARDELLI: Well, for me when I was at Chrysler and GM, when we were going through this hearings, it really was heads down, in a conference room with a dozen or so 4 or 5-inch binders going through every document, every email, everything that was turned over to the congressional committees so that you knew you were going to get grilled. They have armies of people going through here looking for questions to try and trip you up. Certainly - and I think will Mary will prepare appropriately for this.

LIU: Well, getting back though to that - that key question which I'm sure she's going to be asked over and over again is how did you not know, and if you knew, why didn't you do anything about it.

NARDELLI: Yeah. Again, I don't want to - it's hard for me to predict how that answer will come out. It's - there are situations where things are kept at the very lowest level to avoid disclosure and what have you. I'm not saying that's the case here, but it's possible in an organization of that site that something like this maybe didn't elevate itself to the CEO, which would be unfortunate.

I think Mary's taken a very positive forward step here in creating the vice president's office for safety. She's met with the families. She's been very forthcoming. She's been very open. You look at the number of documents that have been turned over. I think this is a critical moment for a new CEO, particularly Mary, to do what she's doing. So she - she certainly has broke with tradition, as Matt said, how maybe prior CEOs of various companies would have handled it. So I give her a lot of credit for stepping out.

LIU: She certainly broke with tradition also with the way how GM has traditionally been run and - and again, as you say, with this whole reorganization that she's going through right now as the CEO. One of the questions we - we were thinking about as we were preparing for the story is what exactly goes into a recall, Bob? You were - you did not oversee any recalls when you were at Chrysler, but - but what happens at a car company? What are the steps that take place until a car company decides, we've got to call these vehicles back?

NARDELLI: Yeah. One of the things we did when we acquired Chrysler from - from Daimler was we installed a very senior person that has a very successful track record. We were able to recruit him away from Nissan. And we put him in place and we started weekly quality tables. We would go through our tech center. We would find those things that were causing quality problems, performance problems. Obviously if anything would endanger life, then that was escalated.

So we made it a very important part of our culture. We did about 400 improvements in the first 90 days relative to quality and performance improvements. And I think you just have to instill in the DNA, the culture of the company that market focused, customer centric is critical, particularly if it's endangering lives of your customers.

LIU: Of course. And at what point do you - as a car company, at what point do you say, you know what? We have to actually issue - issue a notice, right, to our - to our consumers? That's a big decision and it's certainly not one that sheds any positive light on the company. So it's got - there's got to be a lot of thinking obviously behind that.

NARDELLI: I hope today isn't a case of he said, she said and between General Motors and the National Transportation Safety Board. There ought to be - there ought to be some cooperative tension between those two organizations, not combative. It ought not to be --

LIU: But is there a notice given to NTSB first?

NARDELLI: Yeah. There is a requirement that you have to notify them if you start to see fatalities or injuries of that kind. If it's a performance problem it's probably not as critical to get them involved. But obviously if it gets to the point where there are --

LIU: If we're talking seat belts or airbags or anything like that. OK.

NARDELLI: Exactly, exactly. Then you're required to notify them and then you want to work in a harmonious way with them, not in a combative way. And I hope this congressional hearing doesn't create that unnecessary tension and we don't get over regulated now. The pendulum tends to swing, as you know, when something like this happens.

LIU: It does.

NARDELI: Hopefully we can be constructive. Each of the committees will be - do their diligence and not trying to catch anything in their - in their depositions.

LIU: Well what about the relationship now between General Motors and the dealerships who now have to handle these recalls and who I'm assuming not happy with the fact that these recalls keep happening and their customers are angry with them?

NARDELLI: But again, I think Mary has really done a great job for the dealership relative to not creating angst against the brands.

LIU: Because you've got to take care of the dealerships, right?

NARDELLI: You must take care of the dealerships. And they're going to have to handle this plethora of recalls. I think it's important to say regardless of how aggressive and forward positioned she is with GM, chances are there's going to be another one. There are millions of cars in the system today. And let's be careful to say we will never have another recall because that is really going to be --

LIU: It's difficult to make that promise.

NARDELLI: When you think of the thousands parts and the tier one, tier two, tier suppliers and what goes into assembling a car, it is a huge challenge to make sure everything comes together appropriately.

LIU: I want to bring back Bob Nardelli, the former chairman and CEO of Chrysler. Bob, you know this issue inside and out.

NARDELLI: Very cool.

LIU: What do you think about what Elon Musk is trying to do?

NARDELLI: Well on one - in one regard I think he's brilliant. And again, I've --

LIU: Brilliant for fighting the auto dealers or brilliant for -

NARDELLI: Well brilliant in his approach. If you think about it, a good friend of mine in Arizona traveled to California.

LIU: They banned Teslas.

NARDELLI: They banned it so he couldn't buy it in Arizona. He goes to California, puts his modest $40,000 down payment to hold a slot. Goes back to Arizona. The car is then delivered to him on a flatbed. A technician spends an hour with him going through how to operate it. Fast forward a few months later. Technician calls and says your 12-volt battery is not functioning appropriately. We'll be there to change it.

So if you think about the era of big data, certainly Tesla, market focused, customer centric in what they're trying to do to penetrate state by state.

LIU: So it's almost like they've built a customer for life given that kind of service. Hey, that's very tailored here. You can only dream of that with - with a - with a GM car or Toyota car.

NARDELLI: Yeah. And you think about - Betty, if you think about the business models we have here, certainly Jack Nasser tried this with Ford if you remember in the '90s.

LIU: The direct sales, right.

NARDELLI: The direct sales. Why? Because in manufacturing as an OE, you're looking for volume to absorb your fixed overhead, right? We all as - as manufacturers would love to have the margin that you get out of parts and service and used cars. So there was always that little bit of tension to the dealer network. Certainly if you think about the dealers and their franchise agreements state by state, they are - they have tremendous legacy. They are very highly regarded in the states. It's going to be very tough. So I think --

LIU: They're very powerful.

NARDELLI: Very powerful. But I think the dealers are approaching this appropriately. Let's not have a massive fight and maybe lose everything. Let's compromise and see what we can get done. And don't forget, for example, Ohio just accepted. So Elon has --

LIU: Limited, but yes.

NARDELLI: Limited - has a big trump card, right? I'm going to build a battery plant somewhere and I'm going to do it in a friendly state. But if you look - last night we were talking. There's a study out that showed state by state where he's approved relative to limited show rooms. Some as long as within the MSA no one else is doing it. If you think about Carlos Ghosn at Nissan with the Leaf, he could have taken that approach. But if you look at --

LIU: Why didn't he?

NARDELLI: Well, I think he looked at the business model for him and said, I've got all these dealers. I don't have to recreate a service organization. I don't have to spend a lot of capital on tools and facilities and brick and mortar. And - and I will benefit my dealers because I'll draw more traffic into my dealership. So that was the business model he elected as opposed to a startup.

LIU: Bob, but - but - but this only works though for Elon Musk and Tesla because they only sell less than 30,000 cars. If you're trying to sell 300,000 cars, you can't do that by yourself.

NARDELLI: The question will be if he grows to 300,000 cars, can he - can his margin cover the infrastructure that he's going to have to create to do the personal service that he's demonstrated? If he can, then he's got a very successful model. The key will be does he have enough margin in the auto to be able to cover those forward costs.

LIU: But do the automakers - when you were at Chrysler, did you want to sell directly to customers? Is that something that - that actually automakers eventually would like? They're just beholden to this dealership network.

NARDELLI: I think we all think about that. If you - if you look at what Fiat did, I'm sure Sergio would like to have had a separate dealership or a separate way to go to market on the (inaudible) the 500. What the compromise was, was the dealer had to spend X millions of dollars to create a studio within the current dealership.

So there's always that thought about we could take care of the customers better. The dealers though have done a remarkable job. I always try to have a great working relationship with those dealers. They are in place. They've invested a lot of capital. They've got tremendous loyalty within the communities. Softball team, political relationships. So it's - it's pretty embedded, Betty.

LIU: But on a personal front though, most people don't like going to dealerships and buying cars. Maybe on the high end it's a pleasant experience, but for most people it's a terrible experience and they feel like they're being bilked out of lots of dollars. Is there something more that should be done with regulating the dealer?

NARDELLI: Well there's been many attempts, right? The one price, the national price, the no haggling thing. And maybe Tesla's got it right that it's going to take something as dramatic and revolutionary as what he's trying to do to try to get a compromise. I don't think it's either or. I think in today's digital world you want to have optionality to buy the car the way you want to buy the car.

LIU: I want to bring back my guest host for the hour, Bob Nardelli, the former CEO, as we mentioned, of Chrysler and Home Depot. Bob, what's your biggest question just as a private citizen around this healthcare exchange?

NARDELLI: Well I think - I think a couple of important points. Number one, if you ever wanted to learn how not to introduce a program, this is certainly a role model.

LIU: This is certainly the case.

NARDELLI: We were talking upstairs about General Motors. Could you imagine if this was a new platform with this many problems to launch a new car here? So lessons learned here. Program management, oversight, et cetera. Point number one.

Point number two. There were two very important words used in your exchange. One was visits. The other was enrollment. And having at Home Depot tremendous experience in online sales, we used to track visits, which was important, but most important were orders placed when you put down your hard-earned dollars for a product. So there's a big gap.

LIU: So you're skeptical of these numbers as well that the - that the government - that the White House is putting out?

NARDELLI: Depends on what word you're going to use. The visits may be right, but enrollment, if you mean paid, would be another perspective. And as just a common guy, I've gone through this myself with my family.

LIU: You're not a common guy, Bob?

NARDELLI: I'm very - I'm just --

LIU: You're no average Joe, but I get it.

NARDELLI: - Bob - Bob citizen. And I could tell you it was a harrowing experience to get insurance.

LIU: Have you tried to sign on - wait. So you tried to sign on to the exchange or your relatives did?

NARDELLI: Well, so we went through - first of all, we were terminated by - my - my - two of my children were terminated because the insurance company decided not to carry insurance on California. Then we went with the local provider, 30 percent increase first, another 30 percent increase. Then we were notified, two of my children, that they were canceled because the policies that they had didn't meet with the Affordable Care Act government requirements. So then we went back out in trying to find carriers that would --

LIU: That complied.

NARDELLI: - that would comply. So directionally, we went from like $160 a month to $600 a month per child with $5,000 deductible. And I can't tell you how many hours we spent trying to secure this.

LIU: You were shopping around (inaudible) insurance.

NARDELLI: If you like your doctors - they wanted to keep their doctors. And to do that, that's what we had to go through.

LIU: So this is - so this experience that you're talking about is exactly why the Republicans are making it a - a focal point of their - of their campaigns come election season, right? Tom Cotton, for instance, who's a Republican congressman in Arkansas, and let's pull up his website, has - when you go to this website - he's running for Senate now?

NARDELLI: Yes.

LIU: When you go to this website, he says Obamacare is so bad that Obama doesn't want it. And he - he's playing on - on - on essentially the anger among - that he believes voters have against - against Obamacare. Do you think that that is the right strategy? Are there enough Americans who are angry about this?

NARDELLI: Well let me say this. This is that old phrase politics over policy. I don't think anyone argues with trying to make sure affordable healthcare is available for all US citizens. I think that's an important thing and directionally right. I think it's the implementation. I think it's some of the controversy on how it's happened. I think some of the changing the goal posts as we went along to make sure. I just think there were a number of issues in the implementation that probably could have been better thought out.

LIU: But how else could it have been done though, Bob?

NARDELLI: I think certainly - certainly more on a bipartisan basis where we got more people in the room, more than just software developers, that we actually brought people in from the business community. What's the impact? How have you implemented major software changes relative to Ernst & Young does this, S&P does this, and really got more insight on people that have been through this relative to the magnitude of the challenge that has taken place here.

LIU: I want to talk more about management because your former boss Jack Welch, who I know you have a very long history with, he actually just wrote this piece that we highlighted yesterday on LinkedIn where he spoke more about management and how to cultivate talent. And he said one of the things he believes companies not - they don't do enough of is they don't pay attention enough to their HR offices. And he was arguing for elevating the HR officer, for instance, to as high a level as a CFO, to be on the senior management team. You agree with this?

NARDELLI: Yeah, absolutely. First of all, Jack's a dear friend. He's been a great mentor to me. And obviously I can't thank him enough for the lessons I've learned working for him and being around him.

LIU: People look to him for management advice.

NARDELLI: Yes, always. He is the guru. So I totally agree with that position. As a matter of fact, when I went to Home Depot one of the first things I did was bring in probably one of the strongest HR chief human resources and we started to put process into place.

You've got human capital and you got physical capital. A lot of times you'll spend an inordinate amount of analysis on - on the physical capital, and yet it is your human capital that brings that to leaf (ph). So I think the chief human resource officer needs to have an equal share at your staff's roundtable.

LIU: Which they often don't.

NARDELLI: Which they don't. They're kind of second tier, back room. But there's nothing more important than talent. If you look at the history of GE and the ability to continue to have extremely strong talent on the bench, as talent left talent replaced it. So I think it's very important.

LIU: Well speaking about talent, there's so much fight for talent, right, on the West Coast. And there's a great story about how the chamber of commerce decided, hello, they're going to put an office now on the West Coast, that they're going to start transferring some of their resources there. And I imagine this is all also in - in time with the issues of the day, right? Immigration now for Silicon Valley companies, taxes, the privacy issue. And I'm assuming the chamber of commerce feels like, hey, there's a need now for our services.

NARDELLI: Yeah. I - I think it's an excellent decision by Tom and the chamber. You have to be immersed in the markets and in the environments of the issues so you have a sensitivity and an understanding. Now Tom doesn't have a glass jaw, so as he moves to the West Coast he's going to need all - and muster all -

LIU: I was going to say, yeah. Because some of their - you've had companies like I believe Yahoo did not renew their membership in the chamber and a couple of other big tech companies because they don't agree with some of the policies by the chamber, the environmental - environmental stance for instance by them. Are they - I'm not expecting a big red carpet rolled out for them.

NARDELLI: No, I wouldn't. I'm sure they'll move into a facility with high security. But Tom - I think Tom's doing the right thing. I think he's balanced. He's thoughtful in his positions in representing the chamber. He works both sides of the aisle. I think it's important.

I think that some of these larger corporations that have elected not to participate will rethink that decision because you'd rather be at the table than not at the table. We talked about in the last segment on the Affordable Care Act. So hopefully by them moving out there they're demonstrating their willingness to engage, listen, learn before you lead.

LIU: All right. Bob, it's been great to have you here this hour.

NARDELLI: Thank you. It's been great, Betty. Thank you.

LIU: Bob Nardelli, the former chairman and CEO of Chrysler and Home Depot.

***END OF TRANSCRIPT***
