urn:contentItem:58V4-3SD1-F0BB-S23F-00000-00Róisín Burke on Business2018-06-02T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:22:12ZLexisNexisRóisín Burke on BusinessRóisín Burke

In Miami’s property scene, former F1 star Eddie Irvine is flying off the grid

In the years after he retired from Formula One, Eddie Irvine invested in two Dublin pubs with mixed results, but in the decade since then he has emerged as a shrewd property speculator.

He capitalised on the glut of foreclosures in the US and bought up seafront houses in Miami that needed a bit of love a few years back. He would do them up – they were often 1930s builds that needed complete remodelling – and then sell them on for multiples of what he bought them for.

[caption id="attachment_417909" align="alignright" width="163"] Eddie Irvine[/caption]

The latest such prospect is 126 West San Marino Drive in Miami Beach. It has been sold for over $17 million by Irvine’s man on the ground in Florida, Julian Johnston, who tells me that it’s a sale price that equates to $2,300 a square foot.

It’s not quite the $20 million Irvine was hoping for when it went on the market but it’s still close to treble what a company controlled by him bought it for in 2015, which was just under $6 million.

In the last three years, Johnston has flogged about $60 million-worth of beach-front property in this area of San Marino, one of a chain of man-made islands in the Biscayne Bay called the Venetians, an area which is a particular favourite of Irvine’s.

Speaking of islands, Irvine lives on a private island in the Bahamas that he developed from scratch, sometimes taking to a digger himself, to build a luxury retreat in the location where some of the Pirates of the Caribbean movies were filmed.

In less palm-fringed property development news, Irvine recently told Property Week that he is ramping up his interests in his native North, now that prices are inching up there.

[caption id="attachment_417910" align="alignnone" width="300"] Paul Tweed: kept busy with social media work Pic: Stephen Davison/Pacemaker[/caption]

A Zambia-based business family has launched a High Court action in Dublin against Facebook in what is likely to be part of a growing trend.

The Yousuf family, who have investments in mining, energy and consumer goods in Africa and the Middle East, are seeking the removal of material on Facebook that they say is defamatory and are also considering seeking damages.

“Facebook has been repeatedly requested to take down untrue and highly defamatory material but has failed to do so, leaving our client no alternative but to seek the assistance of the courts,” their lawyer, Paul Tweed, tells me. (Facebook’s legal team acknowledged the case, but didn’t want to comment further.)

Best known for pursuing print publications like the National Enquirer on behalf of Britney Spears and Jennifer Lopez, Tweed has pivoted now to focus more on defamation actions against Facebook, Twitter and other social giants. Last week, he told the New York Times that he thinks the sites should be treated in a similar way to publishers of newspapers and other traditional media in libel matters.

Social media behemoths are increasingly finding themselves caught in the crosshairs of regulators in relation to defamation and privacy issues for which they don’t have to answer to press complaints or advertising bodies in the way that traditional publications do. That means that often the only resort for those affected is the courts. If the social media companies don’t react faster to complaints, they could start getting legally clobbered.

In a similar move to the Yousufs, Liam McCaffrey, a director of a company formerly owned by Cavan businessman Sean Quinn, unleashed his own High Court action against Facebook last week. He is seeking to have taken down material posted on a Facebook page set up by supporters of the Quinn family that he thinks is libellous.

The problem is that, once the material is taken down by Facebook, similar pages simply crop up again in another guise, and the people behind them are difficult to trace. McCaffrey, whose company Quinn Industrial Holdings has previously taken Facebook to task on similar matters, took this High Court case after his lawyers wrote to Facebook several times, but made little progress in having the issue tackled, sources said.

Also being shaken out of its sleepy norms is the credit union movement.

While there is a long-held ambition to enter the mortgage and banking fields, and a more recent one to get involved in backing social housing, the Central Bank is seeking better governance, systems and attention to regulatory matters from the movement.

Patrick Casey, the Central Bank’s credit union registrar, is bypassing boards and even the main umbrella group, the Irish League of Credit Unions, and seeking to engage directly with the chief executives of the country’s biggest branches about setting up a chief executive steering committee that would drive future direction in a focused way.

Casey wrote to the chief executives of the country’s biggest credit unions recently and requested a response from them with their insights by this coming Tuesday.

Close observers see this as a sidelining of a rather sleepy League and the boards of directors of local credit unions in favour of a more dynamic way of getting things done.

 

A well-known Dublin business name was on the receiving end of a Nama legal suit recently.

For some time now, Nama has been pursuing cinema tycoon Tom Anderson over monies in a case dating back to 2015.Now Nama offshoot NALM has obtained a judgment against Anderson in the amount of €776,727, which I understand relates to a personal guarantee. Anderson denied owing the money at all when contacted, though clearly Nama disagrees.

The Andersons are a very well-known Dublin business dynasty who run cinemas north and south of the border, as well as having other private investments.

Another well known business family are the Beshoffs, since their ancestor Ivan Beshoff, the last known survivor of the Battleship Potemkin mutiny, arrived here in the early 20th century.

Jeremy Beshoff i a scion of the family best known for their legendary fish and chip shops.Nama initiated a High Court case against Beshoff Motors and Jeremy, a businessman with a luxury second-hand car dealership company in Howth.

Nama owns the dealership site, which is part of two sites assembled during the boom by Ray Grehan, just before the property market apocalypse in 2007.

Grehan paid a cool €62 million for the adjoining Techrete and Teeling sites. He had form for such zinging top-of-the-market deals, having already famously bought the former UCD veterinary college for a record price at the top of the market, though it soon slumped spectacularly.

The former Techrete plant is where Beshoff Motors is renting, which suited it fine during the years when you wouldn’t have had a hope in hell of selling the place. Now, though, I understand that Nama wants to sell this lucrative property on but is in dispute with Beshoff about the move.

The matter was due to go to mediation, but subsequently appeared before the courts. It has been adjourned until October.

[caption id="attachment_417911" align="alignnone" width="300"] Filip Syta, author of The Show[/caption]

Former Google Ireland staffer Filip Syta, whose racy, Penguin-published book based on a tech giant that is definitely not Google, but “inspired by real events”, as he puts it, has now had his tome made into a TV show, he tells me.

Syta worked at Google HQ Dublin for two years before leaving to pursue his dream to be an author and write The Show, a work of fiction about the party lifestyle at a multibillion search technology firm.

Now The Show is a glossy-looking TV series being streamed on Apple TV and Blackpills with plenty of topical (and scary) data-themed storylines.

“It’s about Big Tech’s collection of personal data, just like the current Facebook and Cambridge Analytica scandal in reality,” Syta says.

Apr 27, 2016( Techdirt: http://www.techdirt.com Delivered by Newstex) As we've been discussing, the FCC is cooking up a plan to open up[1] the closed cable set top box to third party competition. As we've also been pointing out[2], the cable industry has been throwing an absolutely epic hissy fit about this plan, given it would destroy the $21 billion in annual revenues cable operators make off of cable box rental fees. Since it can't just admit this is all about protecting set top rental fees, the cable industry has been pushing an endless wave[3] of editorials in newspapers and websites nationwide, claiming more set top box competition will hurt consumer privacy, increase piracy, harm diversity[4], and rip the very planet from its orbital axis.Most of these editorials are being penned by the usual assortment of entertainment industry and telecom hand-wringers, the majority of whom have a vested financial interest in the status quo and as such have been happy to repeat the talking point that the FCC's well-intentioned plan is just a secret plan by "big Tech" (aka Google) to treat the noble and ultra-innovative cable industry unfairly.Back in March we noted that despite the fact that such rules would obviously help streaming set top vendors, Roku had come out in defense[5] of the cable industry, rather timidly saying it wouldn't be supporting the FCC's plan because it has been trying to secure new, semi-exclusive deals with cable providers: "We have not been advocating for a rule making in this area at this time,' Tricia Mifsud, a Roku spokeswoman, told IBD.

'While we are known for selling streaming players, it is only one area of our business. Customers also access our platform through smart TVs and streaming players that operators deploy."Roku's opposition to the FCC's plan became a little clearer last week, when Comcast (trying to preempt the FCC's plan), announced it was launching an initiative to let some Comcast customers access cable content via Comcast apps[6] on third party devices. Comcast's partners in this new initiative? Samsung and Roku, who'll be offering the Comcast Xfinity app on smart TVs and streaming devices. And while Comcast's plan is certainly a step in the right direction, Comcast being Comcast you can be fairly certain that there will be caveats when the program launches to ensure the impact to set top box revenue is minimized. Comcast's plan obviously also doesn't impact other pay TV operators, so it doesn't really change things for the overall industry.Trying to defend the company's self-immolating position, Roku CEO Anothony Wood decided last week to write an editorial over at the Wall Street Journal[7], breathlessly insisting the FCC's plan would hurt consumers. And, as with every editorial of this type, Google is trotted out as the bogeyman pulling the FCC's strings in a plan to somehow treat cable companies unfairly:"...With prodding from Google and TiVo, the FCC is proposing new 'set-top-box' rules that would force cable companies to make their video services available as an 'open' set of streams. In other words, companies like Comcast or DirecTV would be required to provide their video, guide data and encryption for use by other companies who could then create their own hardware and software to deliver cable content. As Google argued in an FCC filing last year, the intent is to 'unleash competition in the retail navigation-device market' and drive down costs.This might seem like a great deal for consumers and companies like mine, but once you start peeling back the layers, the picture changes. The proposed regulation would—as we say in the industry—'decouple the user interface' from the video and data itself. This would allow a company like Google to do to the TV what it did on the Web—build an interface without the 'inconvenience' of licensing content or entering into business agreements with content companies such as ABC, FOX, HBO, or video distributors like pay TV operators. The unintended consequences of circumventing these kinds of arrangements are likely to include increased costs for consumers, reduced choices and less innovation."But if you actually read the FCC's proposal so far[8] (pdf), you'll notice the plan does nothing of the sort. In short, customers will still have to pay their cable provider to access cable content, it will just be delivered to additional hardware platforms -- using copyright protection standards determined by the cable industry. The content can't just be repackaged without cable companies getting compensation. How letting consumers have access to more, better and cheaper methods to access the same content results in "reduced choice and less innovation" is a logical leap that makes no coherent sense whatsoever. Similarly, this repeated claim that this is some secret cabal by Google -- when the quest for clunky cable set top box reform is decades old -- remains a bizarre narrative unsupported by reason. Would Google benefit from open set top boxes? Yes. So would countless other hardware vendors and developers.Woods also tries to argue that regulation isn't necessary, because we're already seeing innovation in the streaming set top box market:"Regulating the set-top box is unnecessary in the modern age of Internet streaming. Consumers now have tremendous choice for their TV operating system and interface. Robust competition among companies like Roku, Apple, Amazon and Google is already driving rapid innovation and pushing costs down.Right, but we're not talking about streaming players and services, we're talking about the traditional cable set top box. You know, the cable boxes that consumers, on average, pay $231 to rent annually (and thousands of dollars for over the life of the hardware) despite most boxes being worth a fraction of that? And while we have seen some innovation in recent years on the set top box front (voice search, marginally less archaic GUIs), by and large the cable box remains a clunky relic of a bygone era and a cornerstone of the cable industry's antiquated and uncompetitive walled garden approach to customer services.The thing is that if anybody should know better, it's Roku. The company had to file a complaint with the FCC[9] (pdf) after Comcast spent years refusing to let its customers access HBO Go on Roku devices (in order, of course, to push those users toward Comcast's own Xfinity set top boxes and apps). Roku also expressed concerns in net neutrality filings with the FCC[10] that Comcast was using TV Anywhere authentication as yet another way to inhibit Internet video competitors; Roku included:"A large and powerful MVPD may use this leverage in negotiations with content providers or operators of streaming platforms, ultimately favoring parties that can either afford to pay for the privilege of authentication, or have other business leverage that can be used as a counterweight to discriminatory authentication. Additionally, MVPDs with affiliated ISPs can abuse their power over authentication by choosing to authenticate only their own or affiliated offerings."Yet here we are, with Roku's CEO now playing kissy face with that same company because they've struck a new deal that will give Roku its own, special advantage in the pay TV market.It should be noted that Woods wasn't entirely willing to pledge unwavering fealty to Comcast. Nor is his editorial entirely devoid of good points. Though Woods isn't willing to mention his new BFF by name, he does make some vague references to Comcast's decision to give its own content an unfair advantage[11] via usage caps and zero rating:"...the FCC proposal is distracting from the leading risk to the continued evolution of TV—open and fair broadband Internet access for all consumers. In particular, cable companies often control their customers' broadband access and can take measures against competing streaming services and devices to give their own streaming services and devices an advantage. FCC regulations banning the discriminatory use of data caps and 'zero-rating' schemes that selectively exempt certain content from data limits are far more important to the future of TV than 'opening' the cable box.If broadband Internet services are accessible and affordable to consumers and there is a level playing field for content providers and devices makers, then consumers will benefit from a revolutionized television experience. Let's not bog down the revolution with an unnecessary government intervention in a dynamic marketplace.In other words, while Woods is perfectly happy to blow a few kisses to protect his new business relationship with the Philadelphia-based cable giant, he's not willing to entirely sell himself and his company down river by ignoring the problems Comcast is causing on the net neutrality and zero rating fronts. And this is actually the one area I don't disagree with Woods on. With Internet video disrupting traditional cable anyway, it might make more sense for the FCC to focus its efforts on improving broadband competition. And, more specifically, the telecom industry's use of usage caps and zero rating[12] to protect legacy TV from Internet video.By the FCC's logic however, the glacial pace of cord cutting means that traditional cable and ye olde cable box will still be a dominant force for much of the next decade -- and consumers could still benefit from increased cable set top box competition during that period. The problem is that the cable industry clearly intends to fight this proposal tooth and nail, by dragging the FCC's effort out via lawsuit[13], and funding a major PR offensive in the hopes of convincing the public the FCC's gone power mad. With so many efforts on its plate (from municipal broadband[14] to new broadband privacy rules[15]), the FCC may have to seriously consider just which battles are truly worth fighting, and which problems, like the cable box, may be resolved organically by the market.All of that said, it remains more than a little embarrassing that Woods and Roku are so eager to sell their longer-term success -- and the overall viability of the broader streaming industry -- downriver just to snuggle up a little closer to one of the most anti-competitive companies in the television industry.Permalink[16] | urn:contentItem:5SYY-GPH1-F0C5-X43F-00000-00Roku headquarters relocation extends San Jose 'hot streak' of landing tech companies2018-08-06T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:22:12ZLexisNexisRoku headquarters relocation extends San Jose 'hot streak' of landing tech companiesGeorge Avalos

Prior to the Roku lease, several big tech companies revealed plans this year to relocate major operations to San Jose, including 8×8, Hewlett Packard Enterprise, Bloom Energy and Micron Technology.

SAN JOSE - San Jose officials hope the Bay Area's largest city can extend a winning streak for landing tech companies and their headquarters, an aspiration bolstered by a recent Roku mega-lease.

This news organization reported Aug. 3 that Los Gatos-based Roku had signed a lease to move its headquarters to 472,000 square feet of offices at a San Jose campus near the city's airport. Several other tech companies also have signed leases this year to relocate major operations to San Jose - in some cases even their headquarters.

"We're thrilled to welcome an innovative industry leader like Roku to San Jose," Mayor Sam Liccardo said in emailed comments. "This headquarters move by Roku extends our extraordinary hot streak of high-profile announcements from leading companies that recognize the extraordinary opportunity that San Jose offers for attracting talent and scaling growth."

Roku's deal in the Coleman Highline complex, detailed in a Securities and Exchange Commission regulatory filing, enables it to move into several buildings in the project. The square footage could accommodate 2,100 or more Roku employees.

8×8, Hewlett Packard Enterprise, Bloom Energy and Micron Technology also struck deals this year to relocate major operations to San Jose.

Like Roku, 8×8, HPE and Bloom are all shifting their headquarters to San Jose. Idaho-based Micron Technology is moving large operations from Milpitas to San Jose, but is keeping its headquarters in Boise.

Separately, Adobe Systems is actively working on a plan to expand its three-building downtown San Jose headquarters by adding a fourth office tower at an adjacent property.

Nearby, Google plans a transit-oriented community of offices, residences, stores, restaurants and open spaces where 15,000 to 20,000 of its employees would eventually work near the Diridon train station in downtown San Jose.

"Tech companies are starting to figure out the increasing benefits of putting jobs near where people live," said Bob Staedler, principal executive with Silicon Valley Synergy, a land-use and planning consultancy. "Most of the employees of a lot of these companies live in San Jose."

Locating jobs near workers' homes could have multiple advantages.

"It's better for employee morale and it's better for traffic," Staedler said.

In the latest big win for San Jose, Roku leased two full office buildings at 1167 Coleman and 1173 Coleman; half of a third office building at 1155 Coleman; and all of an amenities building at 1161 Coleman, the SEC documents show.

Roku also is eyeing potential future expansions in three other buildings in the project, depending on availability, according to the documents.

The complex is owned by Hunter Properties, which is also developing the property. The lease was arranged through Newmark Knight Frank brokers Phil Mahoney, Jeffrey Rodgers and Andy Hueser, and CBRE brokers Jeff Houston and Mike Benevento.

"San Jose is well-positioned to get more of these deals, and we will see more of them," Staedler said.

urn:contentItem:5PH8-1J31-F05M-K3BH-00000-00Roku more than doubles IPO targets, hopes to raise up to $252M2017-09-18T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:22:12ZLexisNexisRoku more than doubles IPO targets, hopes to raise up to $252MCromwell Schubarth

Roku Inc.set a price range for its upcoming IPO that more than doubles the amount it hopes to raise in the offering and could increase its valuation by about a third.

The leading maker of streaming media players said in a regulatory filing on Monday that it plans to sell about 18 million shares for between $12 and $14 each.

Click here to get the free TechFlash Silicon Valley newsletter.

That would raise up to $252 million and give the 15-year-old Los Gatos company a market cap of about $1.3 billion. It was valued at $1 billion when it last raised private funding in November 2015.

The IPO is shaping up as the next big tech offering from the Bay Area in what has been the slowest going-public season since the financial crisis of about 10 year ago. There have been only four in the region in 2017, with Mountain View-based Tintri Inc. the most recent one at the end of June.

A Palo Alto-based special purpose acquisition corporation named Social Capital Hedosophia raised $600 million last week to help an as-yet-unnamed unicorn go public through a reverse merger.

Roku plans to list on Nasdaq with the ticker symbol of ROKU.

CEO Anthony Wood founded Roku in 2002 as a TV set-top box provider and shifted to its current streaming media player form since.

Net revenue from the Roku platform rose by about 91 percent in the first six months of this year to about $82.4 million.

The company's net loss in the first half of this year declined by about 27 percent to $29.2 million.

Roku has raised about $200 million in funding, with Menlo Ventures as its largest shareholder with a 35.3 percent stake. It plans to sell 6 million shares in the offering, which could bring it $84 million if the IPO prices at the top of its range.

Roku itself is selling 9 million shares which could bring the company $126 million at the top of the targets.

Sky Ventures Limited, which owns 3.9 percent of outstanding shares, is selling 668,000 of them, worth about $9 million at the high end of the range.

The other big outside investors are Fidelity with a 12.9 percent stake, Twenty-First Century Fox(7 percent) and Globespan Capital Partners (6.1 percent). Neither is selling stock in the offering.

Founder and CEO Wood owns 28.4 percent of the company's private stock.

The company is creating a dual class structure for shares in the offering, with the Case A shares offered having one-tenth the votes of Class B shares held by insiders.

Despite selling some of its Class A shares in the offering, Menlo Ventures will still have 30 percent of the voting power after the offering.

urn:contentItem:5WCJ-FR31-JD6R-T4F3-00000-00Rolling in the deepfakes2019-06-19T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:22:12ZLexisNexisRolling in the deepfakesCrikeyABSTRACT

This week: how deepfake is your love, the worm turns, where the moonshots came from, and a solitary life in the army of shadows.

FULL TEXT

THE WEEK IN DEEPFAKE

In the Good Luck With That department, US Congress will consider a bill to regulate the threat of deepfakes (someone made an acronym out of "DEEPFAKES", believe it or not) amid concern they will be used to   subvert the 2020 elections - except maybe the real threat is   they'll be used as an excuse to deny that a politician said something.

Except, wait, in fact deepfakes aren't a threat at all. But we should use deepfakes to attack   Big Tech leaders anyway. Here's my We're Already Stuffed take: plenty of voters are happily fooled by low tech lies because they complement their prejudices, so why go the trouble of manipulating video in ways that algorithms will easily spot?

IT'S NOT EUROPE

How to protest in a surveillance state: Hong Kong protesters are using a variety of toolsto make it harder for HK police and the Beijing tyranny to identify them. But in France, the gilets jaunes, never very clear exactly what they were protesting about,   have run out of outrage. Berlin, like many Australian cities, is grappling with housing affordability. But the   solutions being considered show up how narrow public policy debate is here.

"Driven by duty, they move inexorably towards their fate, which is often death." That's Adam Schatz on Jean-Pierre Melville and how life in the Resistance shaped his work.

Le Samourai (1967) by John-Pierre Melville. HEALTHY TRANSPORT SOLUTIONS

Fewer people are running, and more slowly, or so the data suggests. (You'd think this has implications for the shoe industry, but the running shoe sector has   long since been liberated from any connection with actual usage). And that's before we get to the systematic ways we make running   difficult for women. As my friend and co-author Helen Razer has long pointed out, capitalism has eagerly exploited female empowerment to market bullshit products to women. Now the scam known as the wellness industry is   getting in on the giggle.

Here's an excellent piece on the invasion of the commons by scooter companies - although capitalism was not "kickstarted by the enclosure of the commons" thanks very much. For a different perspective on the bane of dockless bikes and scooters, here's an   irresponsible clown advocating vandalism.

MURICA!

With the fiftieth anniversary of the moon landing approaching, there's a spate of books, and the political history of the Apollo program summons a range of mid-twentieth century giants. The American Conservative   continues its relentless battle against Trump's efforts to invent a pretext for war with Iran. Of course, other interventions in the Middle East continue: Mother Jones   has a long read on the American role in Syria, and where that wretched conflict currently rests.

White supremacist groups and right-wingers in the US are trying to deflect increasing attention on the terrorist threat posed by the right by insisting the real threat is from the left - while preparing for the civil war they claim is inevitable. Plus, US mega-churches are borrowing an idea from the corporate world   and using contracts to silence parishioners over sexual abuse. And economic prospects for young Americans without degrees   are poor and getting worse.

STAT OF THE WEEK

It's a shame the Australian Institute of Health and Welfare didn't prepare a nice time-series graph in its latest Burden of Disease report (which covers 2015). But the following extract tells the same story pretty well. Australians continue to get healthier - both because we're living longer, and because the lives we live are less affected by disease. (For those not across health speak, a DALY is a disability-adjusted life year.)

MISC

Mind the gap no more: the major economic shift that has roiled the media for the last decade or more is over. And for media careers

Death came with it. William Parker champions intestinal worms as a weapon against autoimmune conditions and mental illness (waiting to see how long before there's pushback on this).

Mark Pesce argues Facebook's Libra will "transform the daily lives of billions" (I prefer to see it as "   the most invasive and dangerous form of surveillance they have designed thus far").

And how lotteries sell entertainment to the innumerate: the entertainment of thinking about how we'll spend winnings we'll never get.

The end of a wild week on Wall Street, as scores of companies serve up earnings. Mr. Greenspan set the tone for the economy, sending the markets higher yesterday. And will economic sanctions against Cuba continue? Tally the votes. Plus, plenty of economic factors are at play in one classroom, where kids run a bank, a post office, a court system, and even the EPA: a grade school where students are learning the ABCs of making money. And there are no rules where the weather is concerned. A look at the damage from some severe overnight storms.

THIS IS A RUSH TRANSCRIPT. THIS COPY MAY NOT BE IN ITS FINAL FORM AND MAY BE UPDATED.

TERRY KEENAN, CNN ANCHOR: The end of a wild week on Wall Street, as scores of companies serve up earnings. Mr. Greenspan set the tone for the economy, sending the markets higher yesterday. Can it continue?

BILL TUCKER, CNN ANCHOR: Will economic sanctions against Cuba continue? We'll tally the votes.

KEENAN: Plus, plenty of economic factors are at play in this classroom, where kids run a bank, a post office, a court system, and even the EPA: a grade school where students are learning the ABCs of making money.

TUCKER: And there are no rules where the weather is concerned. We'll show you the damage from some severe overnight storms.

ANNOUNCER: From CNN and CNNfn, this is IN THE MONEY with Bill Tucker, Terry Keenan, and Daryn Kagan.

TUCKER: Good morning, everyone, and welcome to IN THE MONEY.

Technology stocks are pressuring the markets at this hour. Investors taking some profits after yesterday's big rallies.

KEENAN: That is right, and today's move is expanding the Nasdaq's losses on the week. It's already down about 1 1/2 percent since Monday morning.

TUCKER: Yes, Wall street digesting specific earning news this morning, and let's take a look at what's happening. Hewlett-Packard, the biggest loser on the Dow side of the ledger here. Hewlett-Packard down more than nine. That after Agilent, its spin-off, announced that it would be missing quarterly expectations by, oh, half of what analysts had expected. Agilent also taking a big hit on the Street today as well.

Technology stocks on the Dow now under pressure. IBM down 2. Intel down 2. You can see the pressure being reflected in the technology sector in the Nasdaq, which is down 74 1/4 points.

KEENAN: That is right. And, as Bill mentioned, shares of Agilent reeling after a warning that it will not meet analysts' expectations for its third quarter. Let's get all the gory details from Christine Romans at the New York Stock Exchange.

And this stock is active and down hard?

CHRISTINE ROMANS, CNN CORRESPONDENT: It is very active and it is down very hard, Terry, a big crowd around that post from the get-go earlier today after the company, the Hewlett-Packard spin-off that makes testing and measurement equipment, it said its third-quarter earnings would be 18-22 cents a share and sales also to be disappointing. The First Call consensus estimate was for 35 cents a share. So, wow, investors really selling off shares of Agilent.

Now, as I said, Agilent is a spin-off of Hewlett-Packard, and you are seeing some sympathy selling in Hewlett-Packard as well. It is one of a handful of big tech losers in the Dow Jones industrial average. Hewlett-Packard stock hurt by those Agilent losses. Merrill Lynch says that Hewlett is also seeing some weakness in its printer business. However, the company maintains that other areas of the business will offset that weakness.

Another stock that we are watching, Lexmark International. LXK is the ticker symbol. This company misses its second quarter, warns about its third quarter. These are all earnings-related stories here today. It said its second quarter profit rose about 13 percent, but that misses the Street's estimates of 64 cents a share.

So this is what we're watching here today. It is really a tech story. Financials, interestingly enough, are holding up. Lots of folks have been saying, if we are going to see a resumption or a continuation of the summertime rally, you got to have financials and techs maybe moving higher together. So while the techs are faltering here today, Terry and Bill, we are seeing some stability at least in the financial sector.

Back to you guys.

KEENAN: And Chris, maybe you can just clarify for our viewers that Agilent quote, because we had that on the screen as down 5. Though when business wrapped up there yesterday, the stock was trading a lot higher; right?

ROMANS: Yes, definitely. I mean, when you look at from the way it was trading from the New York Stock Exchange close, the stock was off more than $20 in the early going. Big losses there for Agilent shares. It's interesting too, SalomonSmith Barney cutting its price target on the stock from $120 a share to $50 a share. There you go.

KEENAN: Ouch, OK, thanks Chris, Christine Romans.

TUCKER: All right, it doesn't look any better on the technology side either. Mr. Softy, otherwise known as Microsoft, looking softer again today, down a buck and a half. Charles Molineaux is following the action on the Nasdaq for us.

Good morning, Charles.

CHARLES MOLINEAUX, CNN CORRESPONDENT: Good morning, Bill. Well, yes, we are sliding down, and actually not too far from our session low. We hit a new one, down 83 points, at 4101, within the last half hour, Earnings is of course the big story today, and most of the earnings news is more or less good and so the selling continue. Right now, we are off by 74 point.

Check out Ericsson for one, which is off by 10 percent, almost 11, at 2 7/16 loss, that is at $20 a share. Now, Ericsson reportedly made more than $1 billion in the second quarter, $1.1 billion. That is better than the analysts' forecast, but the company also says its third-quarter profits are going to fall. Ericsson's mobile phone division is still suffering losses and it is now launching some changes. For one thing, it will be outsourcing both its design and production of its low-end phones for the first time ever. Prudential is reiterating a rousing accumulate rating on Ericsson.

Sun Microsystems is the happy story of the day for the Nasdaq. This is one of our biggest big caps, up by 6.50, or 6 1/2 percent. at 104 a share. It made 39 cents a share. It beat the analysts' forecasts by six cents a share. For the first time its sales came in at more five billion dollars and the analysts coming out positive on the stock. Donaldson, Lufkin & Jenrette, Merrill Lynch, and Credit Suisse First Boston, are all raising their targets for a stock price. SalomonSmith Barney is calling this a core tech holding.

Xilinx, however, is off $13 or 15 1/2 percent after rolling out its earnings, 27 cents a share on the first quarter. That's two cents above the projections. But after yesterday's run-up, some analysts figured it was going to sell off today. Deutsche Banc Alex. Brown says this kind of selling is a buying opportunity, because Xilinx is showing good growth.

And Ventro, here we go again, down by six dollars or 30 percent on the day. Yes, its bottom line beat the Street. But its sales don't look so hot. Ventro is a business-to-business e-commerce company. It lost 74 cents a share in the second quarter. That is a smaller loss than the market had expected. But its revenues fell below some of the analysts' expectations, US Bancorp, Piper Jaffray, Credit Suisse First Boston, and Deutsche Banc Alex. Brown, as well as Prudential have all cut their ratings on this stock. And down it goes, a 30 percent loss.

One of the worst performers on the Nasdaq today, while the composite continues to look down, down 74 points at the moment at 4109. And again we're looking at bad breadth on this market, too. The number of stocks going down outnumber those going up by two to one -- Bill, Terry.

TUCKER: All right, let's hope for a rally. Hate to end the week on a down note, thanks, Charles.

KEENAN: Well, Verizon Communications is guiding the Street about its upcoming earnings. The company, recently formed by the merger of Bell Atlantic and GTE, says that it will announce second-quarter earnings next month when it will talk about its post-merger financial outlook. Now Verizon says it's confident to meet each of the company's earnings estimates. It's going to be a nice boost to its shares today. The stock initially shot up on June 30, when the merger was completed. But it's dropped 13 percent ever since. And currently, that stock trading up 3 7/8.

TUCKER: And there is a reason for that. And Andy Serwer of "Fortune" magazine has been taking a look at Verizon, VZ, the ticker.

Andy, what's going on here?

ANDY SERWER, EDITOR-AT-LARGE, "FORTUNE": Yes, well, first of all, I promise to call it Verizon and not "Varizon," Terry. Remember I did that the other day.

KEENAN: You called it "Horizon."

SERWER: Yes, right, Horizon, Verizon.

Anyway, the stock, as you mentioned, was a nice one when it came out on June 30. It got up to 57 bucks and promptly fell down as low as 43, I believe. Real questions about post-merger charges, that's the problem here. And you know, a bunch of issues surrounding this story, very complicated. Again, they spun off Genuity, and so a real difficult situation. We'll get back to that, more maybe later.

TUCKER: Andy? yes, I was going to say, I'm sorry we have to cut into you. We need to go down to Bill Hemmer in Atlanta. There are some developments at Camp David we need to be brought up to speed on -- Bill.

BILL HEMMER, CNN ANCHOR: Terry and Bill, thank you.

Quickly, to our viewers, up to Camp David, Richard Boucher, now, before the microphone there.

We'll listen.

(JOINED IN PROGRESS)

RICHARD BOUCHER, STATE DEPARTMENT SPOKESMAN: … people sat together. Both Chairman Arafat and Prime Minister Barak came to dinner, and they sat at a table with the secretary, one on one side of the secretary and the other on the other side of the secretary.

After dinner, negotiators began meeting to discuss the issues involved in the settlement in a permanent status, and they met well into the night.

Negotiators are resuming their discussions this morning and will continue throughout the day.

The secretary expects to meet with some of the negotiators to start off, and I expect she'll see the leaders during the course of the day as well.

As far as briefings here go, just take this opportunity to announce that this evening and tomorrow we'll treat Shabbat the way we did last weekend, so we'll do a briefing here this afternoon, in the late afternoon. We'll give you the final update before sundown tonight. And then we won't brief here again until Sunday morning.

With those updates, I'd be glad to take any questions you have.

QUESTION: Glad that religion has crept into the State Department.

The president, there are reports, which seem to be credible, that he's going to come back a few, maybe several hours early. So as we look ahead to Sunday, without a briefing for a while, what's your best advice?

BOUCHER: My best advice is to wait and see.

QUESTION: Will he come back -- will he come back early? He's already canceled one meeting out in Japan.

BOUCHER: Yes. I think most of those reports, Barry, are based on the statement that Mr. Lockhart made traveling with the president. I checked with Okinawa about an hour or so ago. They do not have a new schedule yet. But as they said, they are looking to compress the schedule in Japan and see when the president can return here. So we'll look forward to seeing them back.

QUESTION: How are we going to work that out, Richard, if the president -- if there is even -- and based on the guidance Joe is giving, there's some indication that the president may be back before a Sunday morning briefing. So how will we work that?

BOUCHER: If there is such news, obviously, we'll give it to you. And then we'll plan on doing a Sunday morning briefing to tell you what happens when he gets back. I expect that the Okinawa -- the traveling party with the president will put out the word on his exact travel plans.

QUESTION: How would you -- the meeting, the only meeting yesterday between the three people who are now leaders of their delegations, was that dinner, right?

BOUCHER: That was dinner, yes.

QUESTION: And you expect that -- you said that you expect that the secretary will see them again today, but separately, is that the…

BOUCHER: I don't know, probably separately. There's always the possibility of a three-way meeting, but I'm not aware of anything scheduled like that at this point. So I would expect to follow the pattern we followed in recent days.

QUESTION: Can you describe the mood at the top table at dinner?

BOUCHER: The mood at the top table. You know, it wasn't a working dinner. It wasn't a dinner to delve deeply into the issues. They discussed a variety of things, some involving Camp David talks, but also, you might say, the outside world. They talked about other things going on outside the confines as well.

QUESTION: There is something to life more than Camp David?

BOUCHER: Yes.

QUESTION: Without going into substance, is Madam Secretary dealing with negotiators -- dealing with the negotiators on every subject or is there one or two subjects are being put back until the president comes?

BOUCHER: There are discussions of all the core issues going on.

QUESTION: Can I follow up on the dinner? Were the two leaders engaging with each other? Were they talking? What was the dynamic between them?

BOUCHER: It was a dinner conversation. Sometimes people were talking, you know, the three of them, sometimes to others, sometimes individually to the secretary, sometimes to each other. So it was, you know, it was a normal discussion involving, you know, issues of the world as well as some of the Camp David things as well as everything else.

Not a -- not a working dinner. I don't want to try to claim that the…

QUESTION: Do you agree with Joe's old appraisal of the batting average of reports from outside here as about four out of 10? Four hundred is good enough for the Hall of Fame, but not good enough for journalists.

BOUCHER: Well, I think you're probably still in the Hall of Fame, but I don't think -- I don't think all those reports out there are accurate, and I wouldn't want to lead you in one direction or the other.

QUESTION: Any comment on the report this morning -- it was reported by AP, I guess it came out of Jerusalem, that Barak is ready and willing to allow some kind of self-governance in parts of East Jerusalem?

BOUCHER: I'm not going to get in to any particular position of any particular leader on the issues. I know there's a lot of reports out there. And all I can tell you is some of them may be right and some of them are wrong.

HEMMER: Richard Boucher, a State Department spokesman there at Camp David, briefing reporters who have gathered there. Precious little new information that we have learned. Although he does indicate the discussions do continue on, quote, "all of the core issues."

The summit has been tight-lipped regarding news leaks throughout the 11 days there meeting in Camp David, Today is no exception.

There have been reports, though, that President Clinton, now in Okinawa for that G-8 summit, may cut his trip to Japan early and come back to Camp David and continue talks there. But again, according to Richard Boucher anyway, that is on a wait-and-see basis. And we will wait and see.

IN THE MONEY continues from New York in two minutes, Quick break here.

(COMMERCIAL BREAK)

KEENAN: Well, time now to check some other stories making news this morning. And for that we go back to Bill in Atlanta -- Bill.

HEMMER: OK, Bill and Terry, thanks again. Good morning, once again as well.

A wildfire racing across tinder dry canyons and mesas drives a thousand tourists from a national park, this is southwestern Colorado.

Rosa Linda Roman, of our affiliate KOAT, now with the latest from Mesa Verde National Park. Hello.

ROSA LINDA ROMAN, KOAT REPORTER: Hi, Bill.

There are a lot of very disappointed tourists heading up this road, just like these folks from Washington State. They thought they would spend the day at Mesa Verde National Park, but they were wrong, the park is completely closed, and it is closed for good reason.

A fire that began yesterday afternoon quickly spread from 50 acres to about 500 acres. As a precaution, they closed the park and evacuated some 1500 park visitors. So far, no structures have been destroyed by the fire. And right now, the only resource threatened is the campground itself.

Of course, the biggest concern was protecting the ancient cliff dwelling ruins, but we spoke to a Park Service archaeologist just a few minutes ago, and he tells us no major historical sites are threatened at this time. Still, they are not taking any chances. Some 500 firefighters and support personnel will be out here today to tackle this blaze.

Now, the good news this morning is that overnight they did make some progress fighting this fire, but the bad news is they were hoping to get it contained today. It looks like that is not going to happen for another couple of days.

Reporting live from Mesa Verde National Park, I Rosa Linda Roman.

HEMMER: Quickly here, before we let you go, wasn't it just a few years ago that national park, that same area, suffered another blaze?

ROMAN: That's right, and a lot of firefighters headed out here to make sure that those ruins weren't affected then, and they were not. And they are hoping -- crossing their fingers that it doesn't happen this time.

HEMMER: All right, we will as well. Rosa Linda Roman, of our affiliate KOAT there in Mesa Verde, thanks.

Now to Washington. On Capitol Hill, a bill giving tax relief to married Americans is now headed to President Clinton. The Senate, just a short time ago, gave its endorsement to the so-called "marriage penalty" bill. The measure already was passed by the House. It would cut taxes for almost all married couples beginning this year at a cost of nearly $300 billion over a 10-year period. President Clinton says he will veto that bill, though, in its current form. He is favoring more provisions for prescription medication.

Also, the House has taken a couple of major steps towards easing some long-standing U.S. sanctions against Cuba by convincing margins too. The House members voted to lift rules that would limit food and drug sales to Cuba, as well as those that restrict travel to the communist country.

That vote followed some emotional debate on the floor as well.

(BEGIN VIDEO CLIP)

REP. ROBERT MENENDEZ (D), NEW JERSEY: The last thing you would want to do is to give subsidies to a dictatorship that rations, uses food and rations its people as a form of control, which is exactly what Castro does. He uses rationing as a form of control over his people. So this isn't about selling to the average Cuban, which I probably would be for, this is about selling to the regime!

REP. CAL DOOLEY (D), CALIFORNIA: A policy of isolation has done nothing to advance democracy over the past 40 years. It is time for us to adopt a policy that will let us flood Cuba with U.S.-produced rice, with U.S.-produced wheat, with U.S.-produced cattle product, beef products. That is going to do more to achieve our objectives.

(END VIDEO CLIP)

HEMMER: Now, despite their victories in the House, supporters of legislation to lift those sanctions against Cuba say they are unsure exactly what will get through Congress this year. Many lawmakers favor keeping those sanctions in place.

On a related matter, a Cuban baseball player with a promising career is with his family in Miami today getting phone calls from a number of Major League baseball teams. Andy Morales released from a detention center in Miami yesterday. It's the second time the former Cuban baseball team member has tried to defect in six weeks.

Under immigration policy, Cubans who reach U.S. soil are allowed to stay in the U.S. Morales caught the eye of baseball fans and teams when his team played against the Baltimore Orioles.

At Georgia's State Capitol, here in Atlanta, mourners saying goodbye to Senator Paul Coverdell, who died this past week of a brain hemorrhage. The body of the late Georgia senior senator lying in state today. Thousands expected to turn out to pay their respects to Coverdell. A memorial service for the 61-year-old Republican senator will be held in Atlanta tomorrow, followed by a private ceremony. Republican presidential candidate George W. Bush, Senate Majority Leader Trent Lott, and other political leaders expected to attend tomorrow's memorial service, 61 years of age.

That does it from me here, back to New York now, more with Bill and Terry.

TUCKER: All right, terrific. Thanks, Bill.

Well, lets get back to Andy.

Andy, you were talking before we went away to get the developments at Camp David about Verizon.

SERWER: Right, Verizon. Yes, I know Camp David took a little precedence there.

Well, back to Verizon. This, of course, is the combination of GTE and Bell Atlantic we're talking about, issuing a statement this morning at exactly 7:32 a.m., suggesting that it' numbers are on target, its business is on target, saying we'll be more explicit about this on August 8 when it announces earnings.

But I was sort of surprised and I think the Street was, Terry and Bill, by the strength of this message, saying that, you know, things really are OK. And the stock is on the move: Verizon is risin' -- love that one. And, you know, because essentially they're saying we're going to meet our numbers on that day.

KEENAN: And you also want to look at an interesting development with Palm and 3Com. One's going out of the S&P, one's going in.

SERWER: This has got to be a first, guys. I mean, I have never heard of a company doing a spinoff, and that spunoff company replacing it in the S&P 500. Is that fratricide? No, it's patricide or matricide, right?

TUCKER: Exactly. It's one or -- parenticide, whatever it is.

urn:contentItem:5XWG-PMX1-JBHT-D380-00000-00Romania ∙ Between the Presidency of the Council of the EU and National Enforcement2019-01-01T00:00:00Z2020-10-05T22:22:12ZLexisNexisPg. 317Romania ∙ Between the Presidency of the Council of the EU and National EnforcementBogdan Marius ChirițoiuVlad Dan RomanBerlinFULL TEXT

The year 2019 started for the Romanian Competition Council (NCA, or the Authority) in the same fashion as for the whole Romanian central administration, namely under the umbrella of the Council of the EU Presidency. Besides the very consistent antitrust, mergers and acquisitions, state aid and regulatory portfolio, the NCA has been contributing to political and legislative developments taking place at the EU level, under the six-months rotating chairmanship. In terms of legislation, the Authority has been involved in promoting more transparency and fairness for the online platforms environment, while the policy debates related to the role of competition rules for both digital markets and industrial policy.

Besides the EU-wide policy implications of its work, the Authority has been effective in enforcing its traditional mandate of protecting domestic consumers; the past months count for some of the highest fines delivered by the NCA in its history ie totaling €53 million for nine insurance companies and the representative trade association.

I. The Presidency of the Council of the EU

1. The Legislative Dimension – A Digital Affair

The start of the six months period came with a joint task for the NCA, namely to consolidate a team of governmental bodies (Ministry of Foreign Affairs, Ministry of Economy) in negotiating within and for the Council of the EU (the Council), what at that time was the European Commission Proposal for a Regulation promoting fairness and transparency for business users of online intermediation services.1 The negotiations took place between early January and mid-February, ending with an agreement between the two co-legislators.2 This whole process amounted to approximatively 25 meetings in different formats: working groups and COREPER meetings, technical or political trilogues. Also, during these months, stakeholders from all areas of interest have been in contact with the Authority leadership, with a view to an informed and fit-for-purpose policymaking.

In more substantive terms, the NCA (through the Permanent Representation of Romania to the EU) has been involved in handling and reaching a compromise in relation to specific or complementary competition policy issues. The range of covered topics includes: the way platforms use their ranking system, the employment of self-preferencing by vertically integrated companies, data access rules, business strategies involving parity clauses and sector-specific unfair trading practices. Given the fact that the Regulation is of horizontal impact and gathers in its scope of application almost all online intermediation services and search engines, the main regulatory outcome relates to transparency.

The high standard of transparency prescribed by the two legislators comes in line with the European Commission’s (the Commission) initial proposal3 and with the mandates given by the majority of the Member States during the working party/COREPER negotiations4, for which the Council Presidency acted as an honest broker. To this extent, it was for the members of the European Parliament to try and stretch the boundaries of the Regulation by proposing substantive obligations or bans in relation to specific practices eg disclosure of all ranking parameters, a ban on wide parity clauses, a so-called ‘black-list’ of unfair trading practices (UTPs), consent for the usage of business data or restrictions for any platform which would consider employing self-preferencing as a commercial strategy.5

Even though most of these practices could amount to harmful market behaviour, the fact that the Commission’s proposal has been designed as horizontal, no-threshold model, allowed it to accommodate, to a large extent, only transparency requirements; in terms of mechanism design, competition law remains the main instrument to address situations in which such practices, when employed by dominant undertakings, become (or not) anticompetitive.

As a consequence, even though the transparency criteria might seem as the ‘lowest hanging fruit’ to be picked by the co-legislators in a very short and pressuring negotiations context (the end of term for the European Parliament), this comes to complement the current antitrust instruments by better opening up business models and practices.

Having an absolute approach, ie without considering market power and other relevant criteria, could amount to a situation in which SMEs might be deprived by perfectly legitimate business conduct options and, on the other hand, welcome in some aspects a per setype of analysis, without using a balance of the pro and anticompetitive effects of a business conduct against each other (ie substantive regulation may not take into consideration criteria like the ones in Article 101(3) TFEU / CJEU-allowed efficiencies in Article 102 TFEU).

Leaving aside the doctrinal debates incumbent upon the past negotiations, there are some main takeaways which will help NCAs become better enforcers when addressing ‘102’ cases. For example, in the circumstances of favouring their own products, vertically integrated online intermediary service providers must indicate, according to the new law, the main commercial, economic and legal grounds for this practice; moreover, compliance with the same criteria is binding when using broad or narrow parity clauses. Opening the data debate in relation to intra-group or third-party data transfer, the online intermediary service providers will, in specific cases, disclose these operations and will detail both the destination of the data and the possibility for some users to activate an opt-out clause. Touching upon the UTPs debate, commercial practices such as the imposition of retroactive clauses at the expense of users shall be banned in platform-to-business contractual relationships (this being the only substantive ban when it comes to specific trading practices). At the same time, both online intermediary service providers and search engines will reveal the main search parameters and in some cases the reasons for their use.

Furthermore, these regulatory prescriptions will aid policy makers’ and enforcers’ understanding of the business models and incentives driving the platform economy.

A year and a half after the date of applicability, it will be for the next Commission to assess whether the Regulation is still fit for purpose. Even though for the moment this particular piece of legislation comes as complementary to competition law, the review clause might open up the debate about a more substantive regulatory regime. If this is the case, these new proposals should follow a thorough and complete impact analysis, without excluding the competition law framework and the enforcement efforts carried within the European Competition Network (ECN) community.

2. Policy Debates – On Tech Giants and EU Industrial Champions

Besides the above-mentioned Regulation, which has been negotiated in the Competitiveness and Growth Council (Internal Market) format, the Authority had been guiding the work of the Competition Working Party.

Even though there was no legislative file on the table, as the Council Regulation (EU) 2018/1911 on the application of Articles 107 and 108 of the TFEU to certain categories of horizontal State aid (the Enabling Regulation) was agreed during the Austrian Presidency of the Council, there were different policy matters to be addressed.

The political positions surrounding the need for a new industrial policy and the debate fostered by the Commission in regard to competition in the digital era, created the premises for the two working group meetings, chaired by the Romanian Presidency.

With a view to the first matter, the Friends of industry declaration6 and the Franco-German Manifesto7 opened up a new forum of competition debate, besides the ECN given the fact that policy instruments such as the merger review or State aid control were found to be discussed in different political forums (within or outside the Council). DG COMP presented its place in the industrial policy ‘constellation’ debate by relating to the tools it uses in fostering competitiveness within the internal market. As it can be inferred from the Member States’ position which followed - codified in the Council conclusions on an EU Industrial Policy Strategy8 - there is currently no appetite to mandate the next Commission with a view of making major changes in merger control (ie only 7 acquisitions out of 3,000 mergers have been prohibited in last 10 years)9 and to the State aid regime. The Member States have pleaded for a rather holistic regime where competition policy should be complemented by targeted tools addressing market distortions in/by foreign economies, an advanced EU internal market integration or more initiatives like the Important Projects of Common European Interest. On the other hand, distinct intergovernmental positions might keep the debate open and bring it to different levels of the EU decision-making process.

One such very recent position10 aligns Poland with France and Germany, and aims at a targeted measure for recalibrating EU competition rules. A new approach towards the merger control is being envisaged, eg reviewed focus on efficiencies, higher scrutiny on foreign State-owned undertakings or strengthened political input in merger cases. The document also promotes joint ventures that would foster the development of EU global capacities. In the same line of action, with regard to big tech, matters such as predatory acquisitions, systemic actors and data sharing are at the forefront of the enforcement and regulatory endeavor.11

Another very important topic debated during the Working Party on Competition related to the digital age and the implications it brings for the antitrust community. The most important developments which have been discussed related to the outcomes from DG COMP’s continuous interest in digital-related policy matters, especially the special advisers’ report 'Competition policy for the digital era’.12 Also, the Commission has been contributing with centralised data regarding the state of play13 in areas where it applies competition law.

II. Law Enforcement – We All Need Insurances

Following an investigation formally initiated in 2015, the Romanian Competition Council has revealed an anticompetitive exchange of information carried by several undertakings active in the car insurances market (ie compulsory motor third party liability insurances), and which had the direction of rising the prices for their services, at the expense of lower consumer costs. The association has been also held liable for infringing the law as a result of facilitating the coordination of the members’ unlawful conduct. The anticompetitive practice at stake led to a reduction in competition on the relevant market from October 2012 to November 2016 (more the four years), as insurance companies ceased to follow independent business strategies and involved themselves in a collusive setup, under the umbrella of the industry association.

The fine (ie approximatively €53 million) amounted to the second largest in the history of the NCA, after the one imposed on six oil companies in 2011, which totalled a bit over €200 million.

From the very first days of the investigation (the dawn raids), the suspicions related to an extended form of information sharing, eg sales, prices, products and customer types. This alleged exchange took place between the undertakings, without having set safeguards (eg clean-team strategy) to avoid the sharing of sensitive information.

During the antitrust procedures, one of the nine undertakings involved opted to cooperate with the Authority through the leniency procedure. Thus, besides admitting its participation in the illegal exchange of information, the undertaking provided the case-handlers with relevant evidence for proving the facts of the infringement.

Complementing its line of enforcement, the Romanian NCA together with the national Financial Supervisory Authority, involved in analysing other structural factors which lead to market imbalances, made a number of recommendations most of which were introduced into primary and secondary legislation.14 The NCA has had a preliminary structural approach towards the market in 2016 when it delivered the results of a market inquiry and proposed specific solutions for the different issues. This has been a decisive incentive for the legislative changes that were made in Romania in 2016 and 2017. For example, one of the main findings of the market inquiry was that dissimilar conditions apply to equivalent transactions depending on who pays the repair costs - the owner or the insurance companies (higher in the second scenario). Moreover, in order to decrease the prices, the NCA argues that it is necessary to proportionally increase the number vehicles in circulation that have a valid insurance. For the moment, many cars do not have a valid insurance because owners have only concluded short-term contracts without renewing them. The Authority showed regulatory preference for a system in which individuals should not be allowed to conclude one-month insurance contracts, but instead have minimum period set at six months.15

One major issue16 that was not tackled is the misalignment of incentives resulting from the unrestrained choice of the car owners to perform the repairs, which are then covered through payment by the insurer. This misalignment of interests ie ease in dealing with the price parameter by consumers v. insurance companies’ need to lower costs, frustrates any efficiency gaining efforts on behalf of the undertaking due to the inflated prices which occur.

III. Concluding Remarks

The past months have been a great opportunity for the NCA to broaden the scope of its activity, and, correspondently, its expertise. The Authority has been engaged in discussions relating to big picture political matters, such as the future of digital markets and industrial policy. This path-dependent narrative process is to be continued during the next Council Presidencies and by the new European Commission.

Now calibrating back to subsidiarity, the NCA will continue its efforts to better understand digital markets; this exercise has already been carried out during the tech mergers the NCA previously analysed17 and through the attendance in the relevant ECN working parties. Furthermore, the recent inquiry into the sharing economy sector18 is meant to better grasp the market specificities and the different regulatory burdens that confront undertakings. The Authority is also formally investigating eMAG, the regional e-commerce market player, for a possible breach of its special responsibility duties.

Summing up, it can be said that in terms of digital issues, the trend started with the ECN Plus Directive19 (ie enabling NCAs to be better enforcers) ended in the right place. The transparency obligations imposed by the Platform-to-Business Regulation will give NCAs better standing in documenting and proving antitrust infringements specific to the digital age. At the same time, it seems that the industrial policy debate at the Council level has more of an inclusive than coercive approach when addressing the competition chapter. However, this does not prevent like-minded groups of Member States from fostering the debate further. Finally, on the national enforcement side, the Romanian NCA is aiming at investigating novel types of infringements. It will thus be fulfilling its role in both ensuring a level playing field for competing undertakings and in protecting consumer welfare.
